{"uri": "8115653864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "13:31:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T13:31:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T13:31:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://theprint.in/entertainment/factbox-how-to-vote-for-your-favourite-in-eurovision-2024/2074051/", "title": "Factbox-How to vote for your favourite in Eurovision 2024", "body": "Roughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malm\u00f6 during the week for the 68th edition of the competition.\n\nThe event will kick off on May 7 at 1900 GMT for the first semi-final, followed by a second semi-final two days later.\n\nThe Grand Final will be held on Saturday, May 11 at 1900 GMT.\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest 2024 will take place in Malm\u00f6, Sweden's third-largest city with a population of 362,000. The city also hosted Eurovision in 1992 and in 2013.\n\nSweden has hosted Eurovision seven times in total, counting in 2024. Stockholm, the capital, hosted the competition in 1975, 2000, and 2016 and Gothenburg in 1985.\n\nThe concert venue is Malm\u00f6 Arena with a capacity of up to 15,500.\n\nViewers decide the results of the two semi-finals and can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or via a Eurovision app.\n\nViewers in the 15 countries taking part in Semi-Final 1 are eligible to vote alongside three of the countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom.\n\nViewers in the 16 countries taking part in Semi-Final 2 are eligible to vote alongside three of the other countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - France, Italy and Spain.\n\nIn the final, audience votes will make up half of the result, while juries of five music professionals in each participating country will make up the other half.\n\nThe juries will rank the songs based on composition and originality of the song, quality of the stage performance, the artists' vocal capacity, and their overall impression of the act.\n\nNon-participating countries around the world will also be able to vote, and will collectively have the weight of one additional voting country.\n\nNew to this year's Eurovision, viewers outside the participating countries can vote 24 hours prior each semi-final and the Grand final.\n\nCyprus, Serbia, Lithuania, Ireland, Ukraine, Poland, Croatia, Iceland, Slovenia, Finland, Moldova, Azerbaijan, Australia, Portugal, and Luxembourg.\n\nMalta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Israel, Norway, and the Netherlands.\n\nThe top 10 from each semi-final will participate in the final.\n\nThe previous year's winner and host nation Sweden has automatic entry to the final as well as the \"Big Five\" countries: United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain.\n\nThe \"Big Five\" countries are France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom, which bring the biggest financial contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).\n\nSince 2000, these countries have secured themselves an automatic spot in the Grand Final.\n\nThe song contest will be broadcast by all 37 participating countries. It will also be streamed on YouTube.\n\nBookmakers have Croatia, Switzerland and Ukraine as the top three favourites to win, while streaming data from Spotify suggests a strong chance for the Netherlands, Italy or host nation Sweden.\n\nThe song contest will be presented by Swedish comedian and actress Petra Mede and Swedish-American actress Malin \u00c5kerman.\n\nThe Eurovision song contest is one of the world's largest television events, and has been held annually since 1956.\n\nEurovision features live music performances from most European countries and beyond, including Israel and Australia.\n\nOriginally it started as a technical experiment for transnational broadcast television with only seven countries competing: the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Italy.\n\nThe show reached 162 million people in 2023 through public service markets.\n\nSweden and Ireland are leading with seven wins each. France, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have each won five times, with the Netherlands as the most recent of the four countries to win in 2019.\n\nSwedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool for the second time with her song \"Tattoo\". She is the only person after Ireland's Johnny Logan to win the contest twice.\n\n(Reporting by Isabelle Yr Carlsson and Louise Breusch Rasmussen; Editing by Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen, Sharon Singleton {"uri": "8117008418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "08:54:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T08:54:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T08:54:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/regionals/wexford/lifestyle/retro-chart-15-of-irelands-eurovision-songs-have-reached-number-one/a355973760.html", "title": "Retro chart: 15 of Ireland's Eurovision songs have reached number one", "body": "Ireland has won a record-equalling seven times since first entering the Eurovision Song Contest almost 60 years ago, but 15 of our entries have topped the Irish charts.\n\nAs Eurovision fever gripped the country in the sixties, five Irish Eurovision entries made number one even before Dana secured the country's first win with \"All Kinds Of Everything\" in 1970.\n\nChart pickings have been far leaner in more recent years, reflecting Ireland's demise as a Eurovision superpower.\n\nIt's been all of 13 years since the last Irish Eurovision number one - Jedward's \"Lipstick\". The brothers reached No. 5 the following year with their second Eurovision entry \"Waterline\", but since then no Irish Eurovision song has even made the top ten.\n\nFive of Ireland's seven Eurovison winners reached number one in their home country. Among the two that didn't was Charlie McGettigan and Paul Harrington's \"Rock 'n' Roll Kids\", despite the song's huge popularity and its record total of 226 points in the Eurovision final. But the omission from our fifteen is easy to explain: Charlie and Paul had to compete with \"Riverdance\", the most successful Eurovision interval act of all time.\n\n\"Riverdance\" spent a record 18 weeks lodged at number one; \"Rock 'n' Roll Kids\" had to settle for seven weeks in the top ten, without ever securing the coveted top spot.\n\nEimear Quinn's \"The Voice\", Ireland's Eurovision winner in 1996, also failed to top the charts, peaking at number three. It was a sign of the turning tide in Irish Eurovision fortunes. A year after Quinn scored Ireland's seventh win in the competition, Marc Roberts came close, finishing runner-up with \"Mysterious Woman\". Since then it's been a downward curve, with Ireland failing to even compete in the final on eleven occasions.\n\nOne thing our list of 15 chart-toppers reveals is that Eurovision voters and the Irish public don't always see eye to eye.\n\nChris Doran's \"If My World Stopped Turning\" finished second last in the 2004 final with just 7 points (the winner had 280), but the song was a No. 1 hit in Ireland.\n\nSandie Jones' \"Ceol an Ghr\u00e1\", the only song as Gaeilge to represent Ireland in the history of the Eurovision, was number one in 1972 but finished 15th out of 18 songs in the contest final.\n\nUp to 1998 every single Irish Eurovision entry made the charts, with just four falling outside the top ten. Since 1999, six songs have failed to chart at all: The Mullans' \"When You Need Love\", Eamonn Toal's \"Millennium of Love\", Gary O'Shaughnessy's \"Without Your Love\", Dervish's \"They Can't Stop The Spring\", Brendan Murray's \"Dying To Try\" and Sarah McTernan's 2019 entry \"22\". If you can remember all six, you are a true Irish Eurovision superfan!", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112418305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "14:00:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T14:00:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T13:59:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.meathchronicle.ie/2024/05/05/eurovision-organisers-say-israel-exclusion-would-have-been-political-decision/", "title": "Eurovision organisers say Israel exclusion would have been 'political decision' | Meath Chronicle", "body": "Eurovision organisers say Israel exclusion would have been 'political decision' RSS Syndicated Content Published: Sun 5 May 2024, 2:36 PM Last updated: Sun 5 May 2024, 2:53 PM\n\nBy Naomi Clarke, PA Senior Entertainment Reporter\n\nOrganisers of the Eurovision Song Contest have said excluding the Israeli broadcaster Kan from the competition would have been a \"political decision\".\n\nThere have been calls for fans and participants to boycott the music competition taking place in Malmo, Sweden, next week after it was confirmed Israel would be competing amid the ongoing conflict in the Gaza strip.\n\nSpeaking on Sunday Morning With Trevor Phillips, Jean Philip De Tender, the deputy director general of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) which organises Eurovision, said it based its decision to include Kan on the competition rules in place.\n\nHe said: \"I fully agree it is a family event and the great thing about this music competition is that it's all about values.\n\n\"It's about uniting onstage all of these young talents, these participants, and they do great. It's about diversity and inclusion.\n\n\"But there are competition rules and you need to follow the competition rules and take decisions based on these competition rules.\n\n\"If you were to exclude Kan outside of these competition rules, that would have been a political decision, as such, which we cannot take.\"\n\nHe also noted the EBU, an apolitical member organisation, is \"in line\" with other international federations including sports bodies who are allowing Israel to participate in events.\n\nFollowing the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war, Queers for Palestine circulated a letter signed by actors Indya Moore, Brigette Lundy-Paine and Maxine Peake calling for UK entrant Olly Alexander to stop participating.\n\nIn March, Alexander along with Irish hopeful Bambie Thug and other Eurovision artists released a joint statement, backing \"an immediate and lasting ceasefire\" but refusing to boycott the event.\n\nThat same month, Israel unveiled its new entry song as Hurricane, performed by singer Eden Golan.\n\nHer original track, October Rain, had caused controversy as the lyrics were thought to reference the Hamas attacks of October 7 before being changed following the backlash.\n\nDiscussing the backlash, De Tender said: \"We do understand the concerns and the deeply held views that many people have around the war in the Middle East and I think nobody can remain untouched by the profound suffering of everybody involved in that war.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a music event which is organised and co-produced by 37 public broadcasters, so it's not a competition between nations or governments.\n\n\"We do understand that there was some concern around Israel participating, but when our governing bodies, because we're a member led organisation, reviewed the participation list of this year, they concluded that Kan, which is the Israeli public broadcaster, met all of the obligations compared to the competing rules.\"\n\nIn 2022, EBU announced that Russia would no longer be participating in Eurovision following the invasion of Ukraine.\n\nA statement at the time said the EBU's executive board had made the decision following a recommendation by the Eurovision governing body, known as the reference group, based on \"the rules of the event and the values of the EBU\".\n\nOn Sunday, De Tender said the situation between Russia and Israel was \"different\" as in Russia's case there was a \"broad consensus within the membership of the EBU that they could not participate\".\n\nHe added that the three Russian members of the EBU had already been \"excluded\" from the EBU membership in the weeks after the war broke out due to breaching \"member obligations\".\n\nThe 37 Eurovision entries are set to perform across two semi-finals next week on Tuesday and Thursday in a bid to compete for a place in the grand final on Saturday.\n\nAlexander is set to perform his dance-infused track Dizzy on behalf of the UK during the Tuesday semi-final, but he is already through to the final along with the other members of the \"big five\" - France, Germany, Italy and Spain - as well as last year's winner Sweden, who get to go through automatically.\n\nDe Tender said the preparations are going \"very well\" as they have been planning the music spectacle in Sweden for the past year after Loreen won the competition with her hit song Tattoo.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Sun 5 May 2024, 2:36 PM Last updated: Sun 5 May 2024, 2:53 PM", "source": {"uri": "meathchronicle.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Meath Chronicle"}, {"uri": "8116367737", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "23:07:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T23:07:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T23:06:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/regionals/wexford/lifestyle/retro-chart-15-irish-eurovision-songs-have-reached-number-one/a355973760.html", "title": "Retro chart: 15 Irish Eurovision songs have reached number one", "body": "Ireland has won a record-equalling seven times since first entering the Eurovision Song Contest almost 60 years ago, but 15 of our entries have topped the Irish charts.\n\nAs Eurovision fever gripped the country in the sixties, five Irish Eurovision entries made number one even before Dana secured the country's first win with \"All Kinds Of Everything\" in 1970.\n\nChart pickings have been far leaner in more recent years, reflecting Ireland's demise as a Eurovision superpower.\n\nIt's been all of 13 years since the last Irish Eurovision number one - Jedward's \"Lipstick\". The brothers reached No. 5 the following year with their second Eurovision entry \"Waterline\", but since then no Irish Eurovision song has even made the top ten.\n\nFive of Ireland's seven Eurovison winners reached number one in their home country. Among the two that didn't was Charlie McGettigan and Paul Harrington's \"Rock 'n' Roll Kids\", despite the song's huge popularity and its record total of 226 points in the Eurovision final. But the omission from our fifteen is easy to explain: Charlie and Paul had to compete with \"Riverdance\", the most successful Eurovision interval act of all time.\n\n\"Riverdance\" spent a record 18 weeks lodged at number one; \"Rock 'n' Roll Kids\" had to settle for seven weeks in the top ten.\n\nEimear Quinn's \"The Voice\", Ireland's Eurovision winner in 1996, also failed to land the Irish charts top spot, peaking at number three. It was a sign of the turning tide in Irish Eurovision fortunes. A year after Quinn scored Ireland's seventh win in the competition, Marc Roberts came close, finishing runner-up with \"Mysterious Woman\". Since then it's been a downward curve, with Ireland failing to even reach the final on eleven occasions.\n\nOne thing our list of 15 chart-toppers reveals is that Eurovision voters and the Irish public don't always see eye to eye.\n\nChris Doran's \"If My World Stopped Turning\" finished second last in the final with just 7 points (the winner had 280), but the song was a No. 1 hit in Ireland.\n\nSandie Jones' \"Ceol an Ghr\u00e1\", the only song as Gaeilge to represent Ireland in the history of the Eurovision, was number one in 1972 but finished 15th out of 18 songs in the contest "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/27770446/britains-ultimate-eurovision-superfans-land-sweden/", "title": "Britain's ultimate Eurovision superfans land in Sweden", "body": "BRITAIN'S ultimate Eurovision superfans have landed in Sweden for this year's contest.\n\nA group of fanatics, draped in sequins and sparkles inspired by the competition, arrived at Copenhagen airport before travelling to the venue in Malm\u00f6 ahead of the semi-final.\n\nOne of the Eurovision lovers who made the journey said: \"The flight laid on for us today was the ultimate treat for any Eurovision fan who loves to celebrate the glitz, glamour, and unity of Eurovision.\n\n\"I can't believe what an amazing experience it's been so far, and we haven't even left the airport yet.\"\n\nIt comes after a poll found six and a half million Brits will be attending a Eurovision party this year.\n\nMore than a third (35 per cent) of the 2,000 adults polled will be tuning into the singing contest this year, with 36 per cent of those either hosting their own festivities or celebrating at someone else's home.\n\nAnd one in five will be clad in iconic Eurovision looks - with D'Nash, the 2007 Spanish entrant, Brotherhood of Man, the UK winners of 1976, and Ireland's 2021 entrant, Jedward, being the most popular.\n\nClosely followed by outfits inspired by Belarus' 3 + 2, iconic Swedish band ABBA and Celine Dion's 1974 entry for France.\n\nAs well as dressing up, 38 per cent will serve food inspired by the competing countries, such as Italy, Spain, and Greece.\n\nMichael Brown, director of cabin services at easyJet, said: \"We are proud to be part of the Eurovision phenomenon, providing a glittering platform for fans to start their Eurovision journey.\n\n\"Our Super Fan Flight to Copenhagen promises to be a memorable adventure - a high-flying act of its own.\n\n\"Our mission is to connect people and cultures together, and we're proud to be the Official Airline of the Eurovision Song Contest who share this passion.\"\n\nThe research also found 39 per cent love the Eurovision song contest - with 23 per cent becoming a bigger fan of the event after it was hosted in Liverpool last year.\n\nThe songs (31 per cent), commentary (24 per cent) and the outfits (21 per cent) are the top reasons why.\n\nAnd 27 per cent have even been inspired to visit new countries because of Eurovision, with Italy, Greece and Spain topping the list.\n\nIt also emerged 42 would enjoy being in the live audience - because of the sense of unity between nations (21 per cent), to celebrate the diversity (19 per cent) and to be around like minded people (12 per cent).\n\nWhen it comes to the UK's entry this year, 64 per cent don't think we are likely {"uri": "8117430892", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:07:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:07:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:07:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.svgeurope.org/blog/headlines/live-from-malmo-excitement-builds-for-eurovision-song-contest-2024/", "title": "Live from Malm\u00f6: Behind the scenes of the Eurovision Song Contest 2024", "body": "Following Loreen's win in Liverpool in 2023, Sweden has the honour of hosting the Eurovision Song Contest for a record seventh time.\n\nHosted by Swedish broadcaster SVT in collaboration with the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), the 68th Eurovision Song Contest is set to take place in the Malm\u00f6 Arena on Saturday 11 May, with semi-finals scheduled for Tuesday 7 May and Thursday 9 May. The three live shows are expected to attract 162 million viewers.\n\nSVT is working in partnership with facilities provider NEP and with Eurovision Services, the one-time broadcasting arm of the EBU but that has been owned by Munich-based venture capital firm Dubag Group since February 2023. The EBU remains Eurovision's main customer and the Song Contest the largest event it works on.\n\n\"I've loved Eurovision since I was a little boy and I still have to pinch myself that I get to help produce Eurovision as a job,\" says Lennard Bartlett, project leader at Eurovision Services. \"It's a great privilege and I'm very proud of my Eurovision Services team and EBU and BBC colleagues for what we achieved together last year. Over to you SVT - bring it on.\"\n\nEurovision Services provides distribution of the produced world feed and is producer of the live voting element of the final in which 37 live feeds from participating members need intricate coordination with belt and braces backup.\n\nSpeaking from the Eurovision Services truck located in the OB compound 20m outside of the Malm\u00f6 Arena, Bartlett says: \"It is the biggest live music event in the world by audience and no other show attempts live voting on this scale.\"\n\nThe world feed itself remains in 1080i 50 SDR after an assessment by the EBU after the 2023 event in Liverpool found there was not sufficient demand for a 4K UHD HDR (or even a HD HDR) production among its public service broadcaster community.\n\nThat said, production values are being upgraded with capture for the first time in Progressive Segmented Frame (PsF), a means of acquiring, producing and distributing a progressive scan from interlace equipment.\n\n\"The intent is to add a more filmic look to performances,\" says Bartlett. \"Inside the arena you can really tell that the standards of lighting, staging and sound quality will be top notch in terms of production standards. You can see that too in monitors from the OB compound during rehearsals that this is going to be a very high-quality show.\"\n\nRoe Visual is the official supplier of all LED kit for the song contest; Creative Technology Sweden is responsible for the installation.\n\nThis comprises around 1,000sqm of LED screen, including a stage floor LED of 186sqm and a backdrop LED screen of 340sqm. Hanging from the ceiling of the arena are five LED cubes totalling 460sqm.\n\nA 6-person stage management team leads the three live shows and manage a further 36 crew who have just 55 seconds to reset the stage between each of the 37 songs. These movements have been carefully choreographed and rehearsed, just like everything else in the live shows.\n\nEurovision Services' facility is connected to NEP's OB truck via a Technical Operations Centre (TOC) and manages onward distribution over fibre and/or via satellite to all EBU members. Signal redundancy is provided from two teleports including one in Geneva.\n\nSignals for the live voting components are contributed via satellite or direct fibre connection or video over IP.\n\n\"We require each of the 37 participating members to provide us with a main feed and a back-up link,\" he adds.\n\n\"It is the biggest live music event in the world by audience and no other show attempts live voting on this scale\"\n\nSecurity is another crucial part of the Eurovision Services operation and it is the piece of the puzzle that shifts most year on year.\n\nBartlett explains: \"We can't go into detail on the mechanisms we have in force for obvious reasons, but it is an area we reassess regularly to make sure we have the latest encryption methods and that our kit is patched with the latest updates to the highest specification basically to ensure we are protected. We've taken aboard information provided by SVT, EBU and other security agencies to ensure we're operating within the evolving cybersecurity picture.\"\n\nThis is Bartlett's second Song Contest as project lead but the 12th for lead engineer Felix Berndt. Many of the team producing in Malm\u00f6 are veterans of the 2013 show also hosted in Malm\u00f6 and of the 2016 event in Stockholm.\n\n\"We've a very experienced team and it all has a very family feel,\" he says. \"The vibe is definitely building. The city is getting prepared and hardcore fans are arriving. The Eurovision Village and Eurovision Street and other dedicated areas are buzzing. It promises to be a huge production.\"\n\nIn one change to the format, artists from France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the UK, plus Sweden, will each perform their entries live during the semi-finals. The so-called Big Five get a 'bye' into the final but will showcase their entries to viewers live alongside the competing acts.\n\nTwenty-four-year-old Swiss rapper Nemo is the bookies favourite to win this year.\n\nEurovision Services are next in action in Germany for the Euros and then again in Paris at the Olympics.", "source": {"uri": "svgeurope.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "SVG {"uri": "8117035300", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "09:11:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T09:11:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:10:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13394877/eurovision-act-palestine-scarf-keffiyeh-protest-israel.html", "title": "Eurovision act rebuked after breaking strict rule in protest of Israel", "body": "Organisers said they 'regret' his choice to 'compromise the non-political nature'\n\nEurovision organisers rebuked one of the Eurovision 2024 opening acts for wearing a keffiyeh during the first semi-final last night.\n\nSwedish singer Eric Saade, who was one of three former contestants opening the contest in Malmo, tied the scarf - which has become a symbol of support for Palestine amid the conflict in the Middle East - around his wrist.\n\nSaade, who is of Palestinian origin, came third for Sweden at the 56th Eurovision Song Contest in 2011 and has repeatedly expressed his opposition to Israel's involvement this time around.\n\nA spokesperson for the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises the event, said: 'The Eurovision Song Contest is a live TV show.\n\n'All performers are made aware of the rules of the Contest, and we regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.'\n\nSwedish singer Eric Saade has been rebuked by Eurovision organisers for wearing a keffiyeh while opening the first semi-final\n\nThe scarf which was tied round his wrist has become a symbol of support for Palestine amid the conflict in the Middle East\n\nSaade was joined by Eleni Foureira (left) and Chanel (centre) to open the event in Malmo, Sweden\n\nSaade was joined by fellow song contest alums Eleni Foureira, who came second in 2018 for Cyprus, and Chanel, who finished third for Spain in 2022, when he appeared with the keffiyeh wrapped around his wrist in clear view.\n\nIt is not the only difficulty the event has faced regarding the conflict in Gaza since opting to include Israel in the competition as usual.\n\nBritish representative Olly Alexander was one of nine entrants to sign a statement in March which read: 'In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent.\n\n'It it important to us to stand in solidarity with the oppressed and communicate our heartfelt wish for peace, an immediate lasting ceasefire, and the safe return of all hostages. We stand united against all forms of hate, including antisemitism and islamophobia.\n\n'We firmly believe in the unifying power of music, enabling people to transcend differences and foster meaningful conversations and connections.\n\n'We feel it is our duty to create and uphold this space, with a strong hope that it will inspire greater compassion and empathy.'\n\nThe Years & Years star had been under scrutiny as a group of 450 queer artists, individuals and organisations signed an open letter asking the singer to withdraw from the contest over Israel's war with Gaza.\n\n(L-R) Foureira, Chanel and Saade - without the keffiyeh - during a rehearsal of the semi-final\n\nBritish representative Olly Alexander (pictured) was one of nine entrants to sign a statement in March which read: 'In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent'\n\nHe also performed in Tuesday's semi-final, despite automatically qualifying for Saturday's showpiece\n\nIn an individual statement he wrote: 'I wholeheartedly support action being taken to demand an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza, the return of all hostages and the safety and security of all civilians in Palestine and Israel.\n\n'I know some people will choose to boycott this year's Eurovision and I understand and respect their decision.\n\n'As a participant I've taken a lot of time to deliberate over what to do and the options available to me. It is my current belief that removing myself from the contest wouldn't bring us any closer to our shared goal.'\n\n'I hope and pray that our calls are answered and there is an end to the atrocities we are seeing taking place in Gaza.\n\n'I'd like to thank the many signatories of this letter whose work I deeply admire and respect and hope that we can continue to work together in creating a better world for all of us.'\n\nLast year the BBC faced calls to drop Alexander as their Eurovision entry, after it emerged he'd signed a letter calling Israel an 'apartheid regime.'\n\nThe statement, which was published on October 20, almost two weeks after Hamas' October 7 attack, also says that Israel has 'terrorised' Palestinian people and there is now a 'genocide' taking place 'in real time'.\n\nRead More How Israel's Eurovision contestant has faced death threats and fears of a terror attack, but declares: 'I'm not worried - but I am prepared'\n\nThe BBC is not planning on taking any action as the singer signed the letter weeks before he was unveiled as the UK's Eurovision act, the Telegraph reported.\n\nSo, the It's A Sin actor is all set to represent the UK in Saturday's final and has promised to 'fly the flag for the UK in the gayest way possible'.\n\nAlthough UK entries automatically get a place in the final, Alexander did perform his song, Dizzy, in the first semi-final, with fans split over whether the 33-year-old has what it takes to bring the trophy home with him after the May 11 showpiece.\n\nWhile half seemed to love the song and raved about the expressive staging, others observed Alexander's vocals seemed slightly shaky.\n\nWhether he will be joined by the Israeli contestant in Malmo's final will be determined tomorrow in the second semi-final.\n\nIsrael has faced multiple threats of disqualification from this year's Eurovision, after two proposed songs were reportedly rejected due to their 'political nature'.\n\nOne track supposedly made references to the victims of Hamas' attack on southern Israel on October 7.\n\nEventually Israel submitted a new song, titled Hurricane, but reportedly kept some of the lyrics from its predecessor, and it will be performed by Eden Golan.\n\nIsrael has faced multiple threats of disqualification from this year's Eurovision , after two proposed songs were reportedly rejected due to their 'political nature'. Pictured: Israeli entrant, Eden Golan\n\nGulan will perform Hurricane on Thursday as she vies for a place in the final\n\nBecause of security fears, Israel's competitor has reportedly been told to stay in her hotel room in Malmo before competing in the second semi-final on Thursday.\n\nDemonstrations calling for Israel to be excluded are expected to be held in the Swedish city around the performance.\n\nAlready through to Saturday's final - where only flags of the competing countries are allowed in the audience - from Tuesday are: Croatia, Cyprus, Finland, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine.\n\nThey will be alongside whoever succeeds on Thursday and the 'Big Five' (France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the UK) who do not need to get through {"uri": "8115976516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:01:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:01:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:00:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/05/07/im-competing-eurovision-dont-think-israel-be-20754863/", "title": "'I'm competing in Eurovision - but I don't think Israel should be'", "body": "Ireland's Eurovision 2024 entry Bambie Thug has spoken out about the controversy surrounding Israel's inclusion in the competition, stating they don't agree with the European Broadcasting Union's decision.\n\nThe 31-year-old singer will be taking to the stage in Malmo, Sweden, with their song Doomsday Blue for a chance to perform in the Grand Final on Saturday, alongside the UK's entry Olly Alexander and the host country's Marcus and Martinus, after Loreen's second win last year.\n\nBambie and It's A Sin star Olly, 33, have been amongst acts facing immense backlash for refusing to boycott the Song Contest, with fans urging them to step back in a protest against Israel's inclusion, amid the ongoing war.\n\nThe war against Hamas has killed more than 35,000 people in Palestine, and injured a further 77,000 in Gaza, according to figures obtained by Al Jazeera, however, the EBU have doubled down on their position to include Israel's act Eden Golan.\n\nIn a shared statement, Years & Years frontman Olly and Bambie joined entrants from Norway, Portugal, San Marino, Switzerland, Denmark, Lithuania and Finland to address the controversy, saying they do 'not feel comfortable being silent' and 'stand united against all forms of hate'.\n\nThey added that 'we feel it is our duty to create and uphold this space, with a strong hope that it will inspire greater compassion and empathy.'\n\nAttention Eurovision fans! To keep you up to date on everything going on in Malm\u00f6, we're hosting a party for everybody (well, maybe just Eurovision fans) over on WhatsApp.\n\nWe'll send you all the drama, memes and iconic moments from the live shows, plus any gossip from behind the scenes\n\nYou can also get involved by sending us your reactions to your favourite acts and voting in our polls, as we get closer to finding out who will be the winner of Eurovision 2024.\n\nJust click the link here, select 'Join Chat' and you're in!\n\nBambie has now spoken about the immense criticism they've been receiving, telling Metro.co.uk: 'We couldn't stay silent on the matter. I basically said what I wanted to say in my statement, but it is down to the EBU and it is down to even my broadcaster.\n\n'I'm getting a lot of targeted abuse that I don't think it's entirely fair, actually, when I'm not the one that's making the decisions, but I am extremely pro Palestine and it is disappointing that the EBU has made this this decision because I don't think it's correct.'\n\nFollowing backlash, and horrific transphobic hate, non-binary artist Bambie has taken a break from social media, and is trying to heal while going to therapy.\n\nThey went on: 'It's a lot to take, from the transphobic abuse online and also just coming for my character in terms of this boycott thing.\n\n'My sister would often call me up and say one of the comments in like a silly voice to try and make me not feel it as much but I've had to stop looking at them because even subconsciously, if you're seeing that all the time, it's not doing you any good, certainly not doing me good for my mental health.'\n\nThe Tsunami singer went on: 'I'm in therapy at the moment for a lot of trauma, so I just need to really bubble myself, because otherwise I wouldn't get through this period.\n\n'I really need to prioritise the fact that I am healing and also the fact that I just don't need to see all that abuse because I know who I am. I know where I stand.\n\n'People online can be really, really, really nasty, and I think they forget that there's a person behind the screen, especially when you become in the public eye.\n\n'So I'm okay, I'm prioritising my healing. It is difficult but I'm here for progression of myself and healing of myself and that's all I can really do, work on me.'\n\nEurovision has sparked immense backlash in recent months over including Israel in the Song Contest, with more than 2,000 artists from Iceland, Finland, and the host country Sweden signing open letters asking for Israel to be banned.\n\nProtests in some of those countries have called for Israel to be suspended from the Song Contest following Israel's retaliation in Gaza after the Israel-Hamas conflict began on October 7.\n\nStars including Dame Helen Mirren, Boy George and Sharon Osbourne are amongst those who have signed an open letter supporting the country's inclusion, after it was shared on non-profit body Creative Community For Peace, who campaign against cultural boycotts of Israel.\n\nThere was further controversy over Israel's entry Eden Golan singing October Rain, which contained lyrics that described the situation around the Hamas attack that killed around 1,200 people and took hundreds hostage.\n\nIsrael's public broadcaster Kan later agreed to change the lyrics to the song, and said they had reached out to the songwriters to 'readjust the texts, with full artistic freedom' before being sent to the EBU for approval.\n\nThe earlier statement shared by Eurovision entrants including Olly and Bambie read: 'We want to begin by acknowledging the privilege of taking part in Eurovision.\n\n'In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent. It is important to us to stand in solidarity with the oppressed and communicate our heartfelt wish for peace, an immediate lasting ceasefire, and the safe return of all hostages.\n\n'We stand united against all forms of hate, including antisemitism and Islamophobia.'\n\nIt continued: 'We firmly believe in the unifying power of music, enabling people to transcend differences and foster meaningful conversations and connections.\n\n'We feel it is our duty to create and uphold this space, with a strong hope that it will inspire greater compassion and empathy.'\n\nTheir statement came as Jean Philip De Tender, Deputy Director General of the EBU, said: 'The European Broadcasting Union acknowledges the depth of feeling and the strong opinions that this year's Eurovision Song Contest - set against the backdrop of a terrible war in the Middle East - has provoked.\n\n'We understand that people will want to engage in debate and express their deeply held views on this matter. We have all been affected by the images, stories and the unquestionable pain suffered by those in Israel and in Gaza.\n\n'However, we wish to address the concerns and discussions surrounding this situation, especially the targeted social media campaigns against some of our participating artists.\n\n'The decision to include any broadcaster, including the Israeli broadcaster Kan, in the Eurovision Song Contest is the sole responsibility of the EBU's governing bodies and not that of the individual artists. These artists come to Eurovision to share their music, culture, and the universal message of unity through the language of music.'\n\nThe statement stressed the EBU's previous explanations for the inclusion of Israeli broadcaster Kan, saying: 'Constructive debate is a positive consequence of such decisions.\n\n'However, while we strongly support freedom of speech and the right to express opinions in a democratic society, we firmly oppose any form of online abuse, hate speech, or harassment directed at our artists or any individuals associated with the contest. This is unacceptable and totally unfair, given the artists have no role in this decision.'\n\nThe statement ended: 'The EBU is dedicated to providing a safe and supportive environment for all participants, staff, and fans of the Eurovision Song Contest. We will continue to work closely with all stakeholders to promote the values of respect, inclusivity, and understanding, both online and offline.\n\n'We urge everyone to engage in respectful and constructive dialogue and support the artists who are working tirelessly - on what is a music and entertainment show - to share their music with the world.'\n\nBambie earlier told Late Late host Patrick Kielty: 'I stand with anyone doing the boycott. I think if I wasn't in the competition, I would also be boycotting. There are a lot of moving parts.\n\n'At the end of the day, without the group of us who is pro-Palestine, it is less competition for the other side to win and it's less of solidarity there. Obviously it's incredibly heavy and I am extremely behind everybody.'\n\nThey went on to echo the sentiment that they don't believe the EBU are 'making the right decision'.\n\nElsewhere in the interview with Metro.co.uk, Bambie spoke about feeling confident in their performance and proud of their feat in getting to Eurovision.\n\nThey said: 'I'm an independent artist and other than this I would have never been put in front of so many people, so soon, unsigned or anything, so that's incredible.\n\n'I think it's a feat in itself to get there, and for us to be in the top 10 after my country not being in the top 10 or in the final for 10 years, and even just for the alt scene, and the queer scene and goths, it's great that we're there.\n\n'Seeing that the doors are opening for more not-so-Normcore music is really encouraging, and I've gotten a lot of love since being involved and people finding my art, finding my old songs and it's been a good boost because it is hard grinding this plane independently so I'm proud of myself regardless.'\n\nAfter seeing idols Conchita Wurst and Celine Dion take to the Eurovision stage, Bambie is now bringing in their own genre - Ouija Pop.\n\n'Ouija Pop is any music that I touch,' they laughed. 'It's no constraints, no rules, genre blending and tinged with a cult language because even if I'm writing a pop song, there's a cult language in there, I just can't get away from it, I don't want to.'\n\nDespite smashing barriers and gender norms, Bambie has somehow been on the end of shocking abuse from a priest earlier this year, who said Ireland is 'finished as a country'.\n\nHe hit out at Bambie, saying, according to The Mirror: 'The poor devil can neither sing nor dance,' going on: 'I don't care what [they] dressed like, but on [their] back... there was a slogan and I said to myself, \"Is this what we need now to win the Eurovision\".'\n\nIn the bizarre rant, he reportedly went on to say: 'Do we need somebody now to shove this orientation in our faces to get votes. And [they] spoke about you know that [they are] neither here nor there - adults who know what I'm talking about. [They're] sort of somewhere in the middle... binary, non-binary I can't get my head around. It reminds me of bale, hay or straw. But that's okay too. I have no problem.'\n\nAt the time, Bambie laughed on X: 'They're making sermons about Bambie Thug,' and has since vowed to Metro.co.uk that they'll 'put more queer everywhere'.\n\n'It is wild,' Bambie reflected on the 'sermon', explaining: 'I really only started going back to Ireland this year, I've lived in London for 11 years, and I think in a queer bubble you forget that a lot of the world is backwards in their consciousness.\n\n'It was like as if I was watching something from 15 years ago, they had a whole sermon about me which is great, you know, they're talking about that in the Church, but... it's funny to think that they're still having these conversations because the whole thing wasn't even about my gender identity.\n\n'It was the fact that I had the word queer on my back of my coat, that's what he was talking about. And I'm just like, it's 2024.\n\n'Also, I just don't understand how you can be a preacher for a religion and then try and parade this religion as all loving and all this and then act like that, which I see like a lot from people who are very staunch in their beliefs sometimes and it just doesn't really add up for me.\n\n'So I don't know, he can watch while I do amazing and put more queer everywhere.'\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest Semi-Finals air on Tuesday, May 7, and Thursday, May 9, at 8pm on BBC One and iPlayer. The Grand Final airs on Saturday, May 11, at 8pm on BBC One and iPlayer.\n\nIf you've got a celebrity story, video or pictures get in touch with the Metro.co.uk entertainment team by emailing us {"uri": "8112263860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:29:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:29:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T11:29:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/05/05/eurovision-organisers-say-israel-exclusion-would-have-been-political-decision/", "title": "Eurovision organisers say Israel exclusion would have been 'political decision'", "body": "There have been calls for fans and participants to boycott the music competition taking place in Malmo amid the ongoing conflict in the Gaza strip.\n\nOrganisers of the Eurovision Song Contest have said excluding the Israeli broadcaster Kan from the competition would have been a \"political decision\".\n\nThere have been calls for fans and participants to boycott the music competition taking place in Malmo, Sweden, next week after it was confirmed Israel would be competing amid the ongoing conflict in the Gaza strip.\n\nSpeaking on Sunday Morning With Trevor Phillips, Jean Philip De Tender, the deputy director general of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) which organises Eurovision, said it based its decision to include Kan on the competition rules in place.\n\nHe said: \"I fully agree it is a family event and the great thing about this music competition is that it's all about values.\n\n\"It's about uniting onstage all of these young talents, these participants, and they do great. It's about diversity and inclusion.\n\n\"But there are competition rules and you need to follow the competition rules and take decisions based on these competition rules.\n\n\"If you were to exclude Kan outside of these competition rules, that would have been a political decision, as such, which we cannot take.\"\n\nHe also noted the EBU, an apolitical member organisation, is \"in line\" with other international federations including sports bodies who are allowing Israel to participate in events.\n\nFollowing the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war, Queers for Palestine circulated a letter signed by actors Indya Moore, Brigette Lundy-Paine and Maxine Peake calling for UK entrant Olly Alexander to stop participating.\n\nIn March, Alexander along with Irish hopeful Bambie Thug and other Eurovision artists released a joint statement, backing \"an immediate and lasting ceasefire\" but refusing to boycott the event.\n\nThat same month, Israel unveiled its new entry song as Hurricane, performed by singer Eden Golan.\n\nHer original track, October Rain, had caused controversy as the lyrics were thought to reference the Hamas attacks of October 7 before being changed following the backlash.\n\nDiscussing the backlash, De Tender said: \"We do understand the concerns and the deeply held views that many people have around the war in the Middle East and I think nobody can remain untouched by the profound suffering of everybody involved in that war.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a music event which is organised and co-produced by 37 public broadcasters, so it's not a competition between nations or governments.\n\n\"We do understand that there was some concern around Israel participating, but when our governing bodies, because we're a member led organisation, reviewed the participation list of this year, they concluded that Kan, which is the Israeli public broadcaster, met all of the obligations compared to the competing rules.\"\n\nIn 2022, EBU announced that Russia would no longer be participating in Eurovision following the invasion of Ukraine.\n\nA statement at the time said the EBU's executive board had made the decision following a recommendation by the Eurovision governing body, known as the reference group, based on \"the rules of the event and the values of the EBU\".\n\nOn Sunday, De Tender said the situation between Russia and Israel was \"different\" as in Russia's case there was a \"broad consensus within the membership of the EBU that they could not participate\".\n\nHe added that the three Russian members of the EBU had already been \"excluded\" from the EBU membership in the weeks after the war broke out due to breaching \"member obligations\".\n\nThe 37 Eurovision entries are set to perform across two semi-finals next week on Tuesday and Thursday in a bid to compete for a place in the grand final on Saturday.\n\nAlexander is set to perform his dance-infused track Dizzy on behalf of the UK during the Tuesday semi-final, but he is already through to the final along with the other members of the \"big five\" - France, Germany, Italy and Spain - as well as last year's winner Sweden, who get to go through automatically.\n\nDe Tender said the preparations are going \"very well\" as they have been planning the music spectacle in Sweden for the past year after Loreen won the competition with her hit song Tattoo.", "source": {"uri": "shropshirestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Shropshire Star"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest", "type": It's about diversity and inclusion.\n\n\"But there are competition rules and you need to follow the competition rules and take decisions based on these competition rules.\n\n\"If you were to exclude Kan outside of these competition rules, that would have been a political decision, as such, which we cannot take.\"\n\nHe also noted the EBU, an apolitical member organisation, is \"in line\" with other international federations including sports bodies who are allowing Israel to participate in events.\n\nFollowing the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war, Queers for Palestine circulated a letter signed by actors Indya Moore, Brigette Lundy-Paine and Maxine Peake calling for UK entrant Olly Alexander to stop participating.\n\nIn March, Alexander along with Irish hopeful Bambie Thug and other Eurovision artists released a joint statement, backing \"an immediate and lasting ceasefire\" but refusing to boycott the event.\n\nThat same month, Israel unveiled its new entry song Hurricane, performed by singer Eden Golan.\n\nHer original track, October Rain, had caused controversy as the lyrics were thought to reference the Hamas attacks of October 7 before being changed following the backlash.\n\nDiscussing the backlash, De Tender said: \"We do understand the concerns and the deeply held views that many people have around the war in the Middle East and I think nobody can remain untouched by the profound suffering of everybody involved in that war.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a music event which is organised and co-produced by 37 public broadcasters, so it's not a competition between nations or governments.\n\n\"We do understand that there was some concern around Israel participating, but when our governing bodies, because we're a member led organisation, reviewed the participation list of this year, they concluded that Kan, which is the Israeli public broadcaster, met all of the obligations compared to the competing rules.\"\n\nIn 2022, EBU announced that Russia would no longer be participating in Eurovision following the invasion of Ukraine.\n\nA statement at the time said the EBU's executive board had made the decision following a recommendation by the Eurovision governing body, known as the reference group, based on \"the rules of the event and the values of the EBU\".\n\nOn Sunday, De Tender said the situation between Russia and Israel was \"different\" as in Russia's case there was a \"broad consensus within the membership of the EBU that they could not participate\".\n\nHe added that the three Russian members of the EBU had already been \"excluded\" from the EBU membership in the weeks after the war broke out due to breaching \"member obligations\".\n\nThe 37 Eurovision entries are set to perform across two semi-finals next week on Tuesday and Thursday in a bid to compete for a place in the grand final on Saturday.\n\nAlexander is set to perform his dance-infused track Dizzy on behalf of the UK during the Tuesday semi-final, but he is already through to the final along with the other members of the \"big five\" - France, Germany, Italy and Spain - as well as last year's winner Sweden, who get to go through automatically.\n\nDe Tender said the preparations are going \"very well\" as they have been planning the music spectacle in Sweden for the past year after Loreen won the competition with her hit song {"uri": "8115451677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "11:31:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T11:31:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T11:30:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13391175/How-vote-favourite-Eurovision-2024.html", "title": "How to vote for your favourite in Eurovision 2024", "body": "By Isabelle Yr Carlsson\n\nMALM\u00d6, Sweden, May 7 (Reuters) - The world's biggest live music event, Eurovision Song Contest, will take place in Sweden in the second week of May with 37 participating countries.\n\nRoughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malm\u00f6 during the week for the 68th edition of the competition.\n\nWHEN IS THE EUROVISION SONG CONTEST 2024?\n\nThe event will kick off on May 7 at 1900 GMT for the first semi-final, followed by a second semi-final two days later.\n\nThe Grand Final will be held on Saturday, May 11 at 1900 GMT.\n\nWHERE IS EUROVISION BEING HELD?\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest 2024 will take place in Malm\u00f6, Sweden's third-largest city with a population of 362,000. The city also hosted Eurovision in 1992 and in 2013.\n\nSweden has hosted Eurovision seven times in total, counting in 2024. Stockholm, the capital, hosted the competition in 1975, 2000, and 2016 and Gothenburg in 1985.\n\nThe concert venue is Malm\u00f6 Arena with a capacity of up to 15,500.\n\nHOW DOES VOTING WORK?\n\nViewers decide the results of the two semi-finals and can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or via a Eurovision app.\n\nViewers in the 15 countries taking part in Semi-Final 1 are eligible to vote alongside three of the countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom.\n\nViewers in the 16 countries taking part in Semi-Final 2 are eligible to vote alongside three of the other countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - France, Italy and Spain.\n\nIn the final, audience votes will make up half of the result, while juries of five music professionals in each participating country will make up the other half.\n\nThe juries will rank the songs based on composition and originality of the song, quality of the stage performance, the artists' vocal capacity, and their overall impression of the act.\n\nEach country will award points from 1 to 8, 10 and 12.\n\nNon-participating countries around the world will also be able to vote, and will collectively have the weight of one additional voting country.\n\nNew to this year's Eurovision, viewers outside the participating countries can vote 24 hours prior each semi-final and the Grand final.\n\nWHO COMPETES IN THE FIRST SEMI-FINAL?\n\nCyprus, Serbia, Lithuania, Ireland, Ukraine, Poland, Croatia, Iceland, Slovenia, Finland, Moldova, Azerbaijan, Australia, Portugal, and Luxembourg.\n\nWHO COMPETES IN THE SECOND SEMI-FINAL?\n\nMalta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Israel, Norway, and the Netherlands.\n\nWHO COMPETES IN THE GRAND FINAL?\n\nThe top 10 from each semi-final will participate in the final.\n\nThe previous year's winner and host nation Sweden has automatic entry to the final as well as the \"Big Five\" countries: United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain.\n\nThere will be 26 acts in total in the final.\n\nWHY THE 'BIG FIVE'?\n\nThe \"Big Five\" countries are France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom, which bring the biggest financial contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).\n\nSince 2000, these countries have secured themselves an automatic spot in the Grand Final.\n\nHOW TO WATCH IT\n\nThe song contest will be broadcast by all 37 participating countries. It will also be streamed on YouTube.\n\nWHO IS THE FAVOURITE TO WIN EUROVISION?\n\nBookmakers have Croatia, Switzerland and Ukraine as the top three favourites to win, while streaming data from Spotify suggests a strong chance for the Netherlands, Italy or host nation Sweden.\n\nWHO ARE THE PRESENTERS?\n\nThe song contest will be presented by Swedish comedian and actress Petra Mede and Swedish-American actress Malin \u00c5kerman.\n\nEUROVISION HISTORY\n\nThe Eurovision song contest is one of the world's largest television events, and has been held annually since 1956.\n\nEurovision features live music performances from most European countries and beyond, including Israel and Australia.\n\nOriginally it started as a technical experiment for transnational broadcast television with only seven countries competing: the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Italy.\n\nThe show reached 162 million people in 2023 through public service markets.\n\nWHICH COUNTRIES HAVE WON THE MOST EUROVISIONS?\n\nSweden and Ireland are leading with seven wins each. France, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have each won five times, with the Netherlands as the most recent of the four countries to win in 2019.\n\nWHO WON LAST YEAR?\n\nSwedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool for the second time with her song \"Tattoo\". She is the only person after Ireland's Johnny Logan to win the contest twice.\n\n(Reporting by Isabelle Yr Carlsson and Louise Breusch Rasmussen; Editing by Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen, Sharon Singleton {"uri": "8117299360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:48:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:48:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13395563/What-protests-planned-weeks-Eurovision-Sweden.html", "title": "What protests are planned for this week's Eurovision in Sweden?", "body": "By Isabelle Yr Carlsson\n\nMALM\u00d6, Sweden, May 8 (Reuters) - The world's biggest live music event, the Eurovision Song Contest, is taking place in Sweden this week with 37 participating countries. Roughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malmo during the week for the 68th edition of the competition, along with large protests against Israel's participation due to the war in Gaza.\n\nWHEN IS THE EUROVISION SONG CONTEST 2024? The event kicked off on Tuesday with the first semi-final, and will be followed by a second semi-final on Thursday.\n\nThe Grand Final will be held on Saturday, May 11 at 1900 GMT.\n\nWHERE IS EUROVISION BEING HELD?\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is taking place in Malmo, Sweden's third-largest city with a population of 362,000. The city also hosted Eurovision in 1992 and in 2013. Sweden has hosted Eurovision seven times in total, counting 2024. Stockholm, the capital, hosted the competition in 1975, 2000 and 2016 and Gothenburg in 1985. The concert venue is the Malmo Arena which has a capacity of up to 15,500.\n\nWHAT DEMONSTRATIONS ARE EXPECTED? Several protests are planned in central Malmo this week after organizer European Broadcasting Union (EBU) resisted calls to exclude Israel over its devastating military campaign in Gaza, triggered by Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel. Protests against Israel's participation which are expected to draw tens of thousands of people are scheduled for 1300 GMT on Thursday and Saturday. Pro-Israel supporters have planned a protest for Thursday at 1600 GMT. A vessel from Swedish NGO 'Ship to Gaza' is scheduled to arrive in Malmo harbour on Wednesday, with a call for solidarity with the people of Gaza.\n\nWHAT SECURITY MEASURES ARE TAKEN?\n\nSwedish police said security will be higher than in 2013 when Malmo last hosted the Eurovision. It has been reinforced by officers from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nAuthorities have said the threat level for terrorist or cyber attacks is high.\n\nVisitors will have to pass through metal detectors before entering Malmo arena, and will not be allowed to bring bags into the venue.\n\nOnly the national flags of the participating countries and the Pride flag are allowed inside the venue, while flags, symbols, clothing, items and banners likely to be to used promote other causes during the TV broadcast will be removed.\n\nHOW DOES VOTING WORK?\n\nViewers decide the results of the two semi-finals and can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or via a Eurovision app. Viewers in the 15 countries taking part in Semi-Final 1 were eligible to vote alongside three of the countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom.\n\nViewers in the 16 countries taking part in Semi-Final 2 are eligible to vote alongside three of the other countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - France, Italy and Spain.\n\nIn the final, audience votes will make up half of the result, while juries of five music professionals in each participating country will make up the other half.\n\nThe juries will rank the songs based on composition and originality of the song, quality of the stage performance, the artists' vocal capacity, and their overall impression of the act.\n\nEach country will award points from 1 to 8, 10 and 12.\n\nNon-participating countries around the world will also be able to vote, and will collectively have the weight of one additional voting country.\n\nNew to this year's Eurovision, viewers outside the participating countries can vote 24 hours prior each semi-final and the Grand final.\n\nWHO SECURED A SPOT IN THE GRAND FINAL FOLLOWING THE FIRST SEMI-FINAL?\n\nCroatia, Cyprus, Finland, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine.\n\nAustralia, Azerbaijan, Iceland, Moldova, and Poland did not make it through to the final.\n\nWHO WILL COMPETE IN THE SECOND SEMI-FINAL ON THURSDAY?\n\nMalta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Israel, Norway, and the Netherlands.\n\nWHO COMPETES IN THE GRAND FINAL?\n\nThe top 10 from each semi-final will participate in the final.\n\nLast year's winner and host nation Sweden has automatic entry to the final as well as the \"Big Five\" countries: United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain.\n\nThere will be 26 acts in total in the final.\n\nWHY THE 'BIG FIVE'? The \"Big Five\" countries are France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom, which make the biggest financial contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).\n\nSince 2000, these countries have secured themselves an automatic spot in the Grand Final.\n\nHOW TO WATCH IT\n\nThe song contest will be broadcast by all 37 participating countries. It will also be streamed on YouTube.\n\nWHO IS THE FAVOURITE TO WIN EUROVISION?\n\nBookmakers have Croatia, Switzerland, Italy, Ukraine and Ireland as the top five favourites to win, while streaming data from Spotify also suggests a strong chance for the Netherlands or host nation Sweden.\n\nWHO ARE THE PRESENTERS?\n\nThe song contest will be presented by Swedish comedian and actress Petra Mede and Swedish-American actress Malin Akerman.\n\nEUROVISION HISTORY\n\nThe Eurovision song contest is one of the world's largest television events, and has been held annually since 1956.\n\nEurovision features live music performances from most European countries and beyond, including Israel and Australia.\n\nOriginally it started as a technical experiment for transnational broadcast television with only seven countries competing: the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Italy.\n\nThe show reached 162 million people in 2023 through public service markets.\n\nWHICH COUNTRIES HAVE WON THE MOST EUROVISIONS?\n\nSweden and Ireland are leading with seven wins each. France, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have each won five times, with the Netherlands as the most recent of the four countries to win in 2019.\n\nWHO WON LAST YEAR?\n\nSwedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool for the second time with her song \"Tattoo\". She is the only person after Ireland's Johnny Logan to win the contest twice. (Reporting by Isabelle Yr Carlsson and Louise Breusch Rasmussen; Editing by Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen, Sharon Singleton, Christina Fincher and Toby Chopra)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/eurovision-regret-singers-stage-palestinian-231502862.html", "title": "Eurovision 'regret' as singers take the stage in Palestinian scarfs", "body": "Eurovision's organisers have said they \"regret\" that an artist chose to wear a Keffiyeh at the event's opening performances on Tuesday night.\n\nSwedish pop star Eric Saade, who is of Palestinian origin, donned the scarf on his wrist as he opened the first semi-final of the 68th Eurovision Song Contest in Malmo, Sweden.\n\nThe Middle Eastern headdress has become a commonly used symbol of pro-Palestinian support throughout the ongoing war between Israel and Hamas and is frequently worn by demonstrators worldwide.\n\nA spokesperson for the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises the event, said: \"The Eurovision Song Contest is a live TV show.\n\n\"All performers are made aware of the rules of the Contest, and we regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"\n\nSaade was among three former contestants who kicked off the first Eurovision semi-final in Malm\u00f6 amid heightened tensions over Israel's involvement.\n\nSaade, who was placed third for Sweden in 2011, has condemned the EBU's handling of this year's controversy and has repeatedly stated he opposes Israel's involvement in the competition.\n\nSimilarly to Saade, an American Eurovision fan worked her way around the organiser's Palestinian flag ban by donning a distinctive Keffiyeh over her outfit.\n\nMonica Ruiz, a 33-year-old library worker from Boston, chose to wear the scarf around her shoulders and paired it with large watermelon earrings, also a symbol used in pro-Palestine protests.\n\n\"It's very complicated this year,\" the Eurovision attendee told The Telegraph, explaining that many people will have \"strong feelings\" about the controversy surrounding Israel's involvement.\n\nShe said: \"We have friends who have bowed out of participating in any Eurovision this year in response to the inclusion [of Israel].\n\n\"I think that personally, it is hard to see a country be celebrated on an international stage while they are also being tried for genocide by the International Criminal Court.\"\n\nExplaining her decision to make a political statement at the music event, she said: \"As a person with Indigenous roots, I am going to stand for Indigenous rights around the world.\"\n\nIn late January, the UN-run International Court of Justice (ICJ) ruled that Israel must act to prevent genocide in Gaza but stopped short of calling for an immediate ceasefire after South Africa brought a case against the country.\n\nOnly flags of participating countries are allowed\n\nThe 68th Eurovision Song Contest has been plagued by rows over Israel's participation amid the country's ongoing military campaign against Hamas in Gaza, now in its seventh month.\n\nOrganisers announced last week that they reserve the right to remove any Palestinian flags and pro-Palestine symbols at the show this week in Sweden, reinforcing that it is a non-political event.\n\nMichelle Roverelli, the head of communications for event organisers the EBU, said ticket holders are only allowed to bring and display flags representing countries that take part in the event, as well as the rainbow-coloured flag.\n\nIt came after more than 1,000 Swedish musicians wrote an open letter calling for Israel to be banned.\n\nAt the event, which runs from Tuesday to Sunday, pro-Palestinian groups are expected to stage large protests in Malm\u00f6 to raise awareness of the cause and demonstrate against Israel's involvement.\n\nThe involvement of Eden Golan, this year's performer for Israel, while the war in Gaza continues has divided politicians and celebrities.\n\nThe 20-year-old will perform the song October Rain, which was taken by some to be a reference to the Hamas attack of October 7, on Thursday.\n\nUK in first semi-final\n\nMeanwhile, this year's first semi-final on Tuesday night saw performances by Ireland's non-binary contestant, Bambi Thug, as well as Olly Alexander for the UK.\n\nThe Years & Years singer, 33, previously sparked an anti-semitism row after The Telegraph revealed he had signed a letter calling Israel an \"apartheid regime\" and condemning \"Zionist propaganda\".\n\nHe broke down in tears during an interview with The Times, published last week, in which he addressed the controversy and said he had \"struggled\" during a performance at a pre-Eurovision party.\n\nHe has since said he respects fans who are boycotting the competition but branded attacks on him \"extreme.\"\n\nThe first night also saw performances by Ukraine's duo Jerry Heil and Alyona Alyona and Croatia's Baby Lasagna, who is tipped as a potential favourite to win.\n\nIsrael has qualified for every Eurovision final since 2015. It came third last year, with its most recent win coming in 2018 with Netta Barzilai's song Toy.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": {"uri": "8116375660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "23:26:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T23:26:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T23:16:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/ireland-croatia-qualify-eurovision-final-230558390.html", "title": "Ireland and Croatia qualify for Eurovision final", "body": "Ireland has broken its Eurovision \"curse\", qualifying for the contest's grand final for the first time since 2018.\n\nAppropriately enough, it did so with the help of a \"gremlin goblin witch\" - aka singer Bambie Thug, whose electro-metal anthem Doomsday Blue is now among the favourites to win.\n\nOther acts who made it through Tuesday's first semi-final included Croatia's Baby Lasagna and Finland's Windows95Man, as fans revelled in the year's most out there performances.\n\nHowever, it was bad news for Eurovision fanatics in Australia. Their act, Electric Fields, failed to qualify, as did entries from Moldova and Iceland.\n\nMeanwhile, organisers had to apologise after one of Tuesday's performers displayed a pro-Palestinian symbol.\n\nEric Saade, who was among the show's opening acts, wore a keffiyeh - a type of scarf commonly used by people who want to show they are pro-Palestinian - on his arm.\n\nA spokeswoman for the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) said: \"The Eurovision Song Contest is a live TV show.\n\n\"All performers are made aware of the rules of the contest, and we regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"\n\nAhead of the event at Sweden's Malm\u00f6 Arena, fans were warned not to bring Palestinian flags, symbols or bags into the audience. Strict security checks were carried out on members of the audience.\n\nThe run-up to the contest has been characterised by opposition to Israel's participation, amid concerns over the humanitarian cost of the war in Gaza.\n\nIreland's Bambi told reporters they were \"ordered\" to remove political gestures from their outfit ahead of the semi-final performance.\n\nTheir costume had originally included an ancient Celtic writing known as Ogham - which they said had spelt \"ceasefire\" and \"freedom for Palestine\".\n\nOgham is an ancient Irish alphabet, represented by a series of marks on stones and it is the earliest written source of the Irish Language, dating back to the 4th Century AD.\n\n\"It was very important for me because I am pro-justice and pro-peace, unfortunately I had to change those messages today... [an] order from the EBU,\" Bambie said.\n\nIsrael's representative, 21-year-old Eden Golan, has reportedly been confined to her hotel room while she is not performing, due to heightened security concerns.\n\nShe will make her debut during Thursday's second semi-final.\n\nThe political row did not overshadow Tuesday's opening semi-final, where 18 acts performed, including the UK's entrant Olly Alexander - who has previously called for \"an immediate and lasting ceasefire\" in Gaza, but refused calls to boycott the event.\n\nThe singer put on an energetic performance of his synth-pop single Dizzy, using camera effects and intricate choreography to make it look as though he was in a spaceship hurtling towards earth.\n\nDressed in a white singlet, red trousers, and distressed boots, he danced so hard that the battery pack for his microphone detached from his costume. He was seen clasping it in his right hand for the final moments of the performance.\n\nDespite the mishap, the UK did not have to worry about the public vote on Tuesday. It is one of five countries that qualifies automatically for the final, due to its financial contribution to the contest.\n\nSweden, who were last year's winners, also get a free pass.\n\nThe 10 acts who succeeded in Tuesday's public vote were:\n\nGoing home were Moldova, Iceland, Australia, Poland and Azerbaijan.\n\nThe results were something of a shock for Iceland's Hera Bj\u00f6rk and Moldova's Natalia Burdu.\n\nBoth were former Eurovision contestants, who were hoping to capitalise on their association with the contest, and perhaps improve upon their previous scores.\n\nHowever, it was not to be. Their songs were ranked poorly with bookmakers and fans alike and, in the end, the public vote could not save them.\n\nCroatia's Baby Lasagna are currently the favourites, and they sailed through the semi-final with the agreeably daft foot-stomper Rim Tim Tagi Dim.\n\nThe song tells the story of a farm boy setting out for the big city (sample lyric: \"I'm a big boy now and I sold my cow\") - and is allegedly about the damaging effects of Croatia's brain drain.\n\nEqually entertaining is Finland's Windows95Man, who spends his stage time \"arguing\" with Eurovision officials about whether he can perform naked from the waist down.\n\nA well-known performance artist and DJ at home, he makes ample use of stage props to cover his modesty... before triumphantly donning a pair of jean-shorts for the song's climax.\n\nLuxembourg, meanwhile, made a triumphant return to Eurovision after a gap of 31 years.\n\nThe country, which has won five times, pulled out after being disqualified from the 1994 contest and resisted attempts to lure them back... Until now.\n\nMarking the 40th anniversary of their last win, they entered the slinky pop anthem Fighter, sung by 23-year-old Tali Golergant - and duly went through to the final.\n\nIreland will also be delighted by their success. Tied with Sweden as the most successful country in Eurovision history (with seven wins each), it has failed to qualify in eight of the last 10 competitions.\n\nThe selection of Bambie Thug, a non-binary artist whose song dabbles in the occult, was condemned by some priests in the predominantly Catholic country - but its creative staging and unlikely fusion of musical genres have made it a favourite amongst fans.\n\n\"I wanted to showcase all the facets of myself like spoken word poetry, singing, jazzy crooning, metal, screaming, I squeeze it all in,\" Bambie told the BBC earlier this week.\n\nThe first semi-final was themed around the idea that \"you don't have to win the contest to be a winner\".\n\nAs a result, organisers asked back some of the competition's most famous runners-up, including Eleni Foureira (Cyprus, 2018), Eric Saade (Sweden, 2001) and Chanel (Spain, 2022) - all of whom have gone on to achieve international success.\n\nThe trio opened the show with a medley of their Eurovision songs; while the interval saw the return of Sweden's Benjamin Ingrosso.\n\nThe singer came seventh at the 2018 contest - a respectable placing, unless you come from Europe's most competitive Eurovision participant.\n\n\"In Sweden, if you don't come top five, you're the worst, so I was a disappointment,\" Ingrosso recently told the official Eurovision Song Contest podcast.\n\nDespite the ignominy, his career has gone from strength to strength - and he recently enjoyed a viral hit with the slinky pop song, Kite.\n\nBut the real star of the half-time show was Ireland's Johnny Logan.\n\nThe crooner was the first person ever to win Eurovision twice, with What's Another Year in 1980 and Hold Me Now in 1987.\n\nHe travelled to Malm\u00f6 to honour Swedish pop diva Loreen, who last year equalled his Eurovision record with her second victory.\n\nOn stage, he sang a lush, orchestral version of her 2012 entry Euphoria.\n\nBehind the scenes, he has also praised Ireland's entry, calling Bambie Thug a potential winner.\n\n\"The one thing about the Eurovision Song Contest is that every year people try to copy the song that won before, because they think that's the secret to winning it,\" he told Ireland's Sunday World newspaper.\n\n\"This year's Irish entry doesn't do that. It's probably the best and most original entry that Ireland has had for as long as I can remember.\"\n\nThe audience will get to decide whether he's right at Eurovision's grand final on Sunday night.\n\nBefore then, however, is Thursday's second semi-final.\n\nThere, 16 acts will compete for the remaining 10 places in the contest - including hotly-tipped singers from Finland (Nemo), Israel (Eden Golan) and Greece (Marina Satti).\n\nSweden is hosting the contest in the coastal city of Malm\u00f6.\n\nIt follows in the footsteps of Liverpool, which held last year's competition on behalf of 2022 winners Ukraine, who were unable to do so during the ongoing war with Russia.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
