{"uri": "2024-05-349310964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:05:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:05:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:48:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/world/pro-palestine-protest-sweden-largest-ever-israel-eurovision-3046469", "title": "Pro-Palestine protest in Sweden 'to be largest ever' as Israel competes in Eurovision", "body": "Protests have been planned in central Malmo on Thursday and Saturday, coinciding with the competition's second semi-final and the grand final, after Eurovision organiser European Broadcasting Union (EBU) resisted calls to exclude Israel over its devastating military campaign in Gaza.\n\nStoppa Israel, the organisation behind the protests, said it expects Thursday's demonstration to be the biggest, when Israeli contestant Eden Golan is scheduled to perform her song \"Hurricane\".\n\n\"A lot of Swedish cities have pro-Palestinian demonstrations every weekend, but we are expecting a lot more people tomorrow [Thursday],\" Pia Jacobsen, a spokesperson at Stoppa Israel, told .\n\n\"We have numbers everywhere between 10,000 up to 40,000, and we have buses from almost all over south of Sweden, and from Denmark, Germany, Holland, and Norway.\"\n\nSwedish police said security will be higher than in 2013 when Malmo last hosted the Eurovision, with officers called in from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nHeavily armed police officers, some appearing to carry rifles, have been patrolling the city, with images showing police snipers atop a building earlier this week as the contest kicked off on Tuesday. Surveillance cameras have been installed near the concert venue and police said officers will use drones to monitor crowds, with attendees expected to pass through airport-style security controls including scanners and no bags allowed.\n\nSweden was already on high alert with the terror threat level at four out of five following a spate of Quran-burning incidents that have sparked outrage and triggered protests in many Muslim-majority countries.\n\nThe UK Foreign Office issued a new travel warning on Wednesday for anyone travelling to Sweden during Eurovision, saying clashes were possible where \"more than one protest happens at the same time, on opposing issues\".\n\nJimmy Modin, a spokesperson for the Swedish police, told that the protests in Malmo this week presented no specific threat to the Eurovision contest.\n\n\"We can never rule out that anything could happen,\" he said, but added: \"At this point there is nothing that points to the demonstrations getting out of hand or becoming violent.\n\n\"There has been a couple of months where we had a lot of demonstrations in Malmo and some of them have been loud, but they have largely gone without disturbances of the peace.\"\n\nOn the presence of armed officers, he said: \"Police officers in Sweden are always carrying a weapon, some of our patrols during Eurovision will have bigger, heavier weaponry. But it's nothing to be alarmed about, it's just precaution from our side.\n\n\"We want to make everybody feel safe and secure and focus on having a good time during Eurovision.\"\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war is the second conflict to rock the colourful song competition, after Russia was expelled in 2022 over its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nCampaigners have pointed to what they describe as the hypocrisy of allowing Israel to compete in Eurovision, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu comes under increasing pressure to not go ahead with a planned offensive in the southern Gazan city of Rafah.\n\nThe war has killed more than 34,800 Palestinians, according to Gaza health officials, and has driven some 80 per cent of Gaza's population of 2.3 million Palestinians from their homes. About 1.3 million Palestinians have sought refuge in Rafah.\n\nMr Netanyahu has insisted on carrying out military offensives to destroy the Hamas militant group in Gaza, following the 7 October attack on southern Israel in which about 1,200 people were killed and 252 taken hostage.\n\nEurovision bills itself as a non-political event and says its rules does not allow political statements or even slogans.\n\nIt did not stop Eric Saade, a former Swedish Eurovision contestant, from wearing a keffiyeh, a scarf associated with the Palestinian cause, around his wrist as he performed in Tuesday's show. Afterwards, organisers said: \"We regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"\n\nBambie Thug, the first Irish Eurovision Song Contest finalist since 2018, criticised organisers for asking them to alter a pro-Palestinian message. The 31-year-old said they were forced to change their body paint in Ogham script - an early medieval alphabet - which translated to ceasefire and freedom, a nod to the situation in Gaza. EBU said it was against the rules.\n\nMs Golan, 20, was asked to change her original song \"October Rain\" after it caused controversy, as the lyrics were thought to reference the 7 October Hamas attacks. She has reportedly been advised to remain in her hotel room for the duration of her visit in Malmo, aside from performances and official events, following death threats online.\n\nJewish Eurovision fans have described feeling anxious about displaying obvious signs of their support for Israel in Malmo. \"We will be 'toned down', we won't speak in Hebrew out on the streets as loudly as we are used to, nor will we walk around with an Israeli flag,\" Miki Israeli, who flew to the city with her friends, told the Israeli newspaper Haaretz.\n\nProtester Ms Jacobsen expressed sadness over reports that Jewish people felt unsafe in Malmo, saying the demonstrations were \"not against Jews\".\n\n\"The only thing we want to do is to tell the world to not forget Palestine, show the Palestinian people that they are not alone,\" she added.\n\nPlanning for the demonstrations in Malmo has been ongoing for months, with the campaign increasing in number with \"more and more organisations standing behind our platform\", Ms Jacobsen said.\n\nThe protest on Saturday will go ahead even if Israel do not make it to the final, she added.\n\nShe said the demonstrations, which will take place in central Malmo away from the Eurovision venue, will be peaceful, as supporters wanted to highlight how \"absurd\" it was for Israel to particiapte in the competition when it was \"committing a genocide\" against the Palestinian people.\n\n\"It makes us feel sick that they are allowed to participate during those circumstances,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "8117582144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:43:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:43:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:43:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://theprint.in/entertainment/factbox-what-protests-are-planned-for-this-weeks-eurovision-in-sweden/2075776/", "title": "Factbox-What protests are planned for this week's Eurovision in Sweden?", "body": "Roughly 100,000 visitors from 89 countries are expected in host city Malmo during the week for the 68th edition of the competition, along with large protests against Israel's participation due to the war in Gaza.\n\nThe event kicked off on Tuesday with the first semi-final, and will be followed by a second semi-final on Thursday.\n\nThe Grand Final will be held on Saturday, May 11 at 1900 GMT.\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is taking place in Malmo, Sweden's third-largest city with a population of 362,000. The city also hosted Eurovision in 1992 and in 2013.\n\nSweden has hosted Eurovision seven times in total, counting 2024. Stockholm, the capital, hosted the competition in 1975, 2000 and 2016 and Gothenburg in 1985.\n\nThe concert venue is the Malmo Arena which has a capacity of up to 15,500.\n\nSeveral protests are planned in central Malmo this week after organizer European Broadcasting Union (EBU) resisted calls to exclude Israel over its devastating military campaign in Gaza, triggered by Hamas' Oct. 7 attack on Israel.\n\nProtests against Israel's participation which are expected to draw tens of thousands of people are scheduled for 1300 GMT on Thursday and Saturday. Pro-Israel supporters have planned a protest for Thursday at 1600 GMT.\n\nA vessel from Swedish NGO 'Ship to Gaza' is scheduled to arrive in Malmo harbour on Wednesday, with a call for solidarity with the people of Gaza.\n\nSwedish police said security will be higher than in 2013 when Malmo last hosted the Eurovision. It has been reinforced by officers from neighbouring Denmark and Norway.\n\nAuthorities have said the threat level for terrorist or cyber attacks is high.\n\nVisitors will have to pass through metal detectors before entering Malmo arena, and will not be allowed to bring bags into the venue.\n\nOnly the national flags of the participating countries and the Pride flag are allowed inside the venue, while flags, symbols, clothing, items and banners likely to be to used promote other causes during the TV broadcast will be removed.\n\nViewers decide the results of the two semi-finals and can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or via a Eurovision app.\n\nViewers in the 15 countries taking part in Semi-Final 1 were eligible to vote alongside three of the countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom.\n\nViewers in the 16 countries taking part in Semi-Final 2 are eligible to vote alongside three of the other countries pre-qualified for the Grand Final - France, Italy and Spain.\n\nIn the final, audience votes will make up half of the result, while juries of five music professionals in each participating country will make up the other half.\n\nThe juries will rank the songs based on composition and originality of the song, quality of the stage performance, the artists' vocal capacity, and their overall impression of the act.\n\nNon-participating countries around the world will also be able to vote, and will collectively have the weight of one additional voting country.\n\nNew to this year's Eurovision, viewers outside the participating countries can vote 24 hours prior each semi-final and the Grand final.\n\nWHO SECURED A SPOT IN THE GRAND FINAL FOLLOWING THE FIRST SEMI-FINAL?\n\nCroatia, Cyprus, Finland, Ireland, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine.\n\nAustralia, Azerbaijan, Iceland, Moldova, and Poland did not make it through to the final.\n\nWHO WILL COMPETE IN THE SECOND SEMI-FINAL ON THURSDAY?\n\nMalta, Albania, Greece, Switzerland, Czech Republic, Austria, Denmark, Armenia, Latvia, San Marino, Georgia, Belgium, Estonia, Israel, Norway, and the Netherlands.\n\nThe top 10 from each semi-final will participate in the final.\n\nLast year's winner and host nation Sweden has automatic entry to the final as well as the \"Big Five\" countries: United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain.\n\nThe \"Big Five\" countries are France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom, which make the biggest financial contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).\n\nSince 2000, these countries have secured themselves an automatic spot in the Grand Final.\n\nThe song contest will be broadcast by all 37 participating countries. It will also be streamed on YouTube.\n\nBookmakers have Croatia, Switzerland, Italy, Ukraine and Ireland as the top five favourites to win, while streaming data from Spotify also suggests a strong chance for the Netherlands or host nation Sweden.\n\nThe song contest will be presented by Swedish comedian and actress Petra Mede and Swedish-American actress Malin Akerman.\n\nThe Eurovision song contest is one of the world's largest television events, and has been held annually since 1956.\n\nEurovision features live music performances from most European countries and beyond, including Israel and Australia.\n\nOriginally it started as a technical experiment for transnational broadcast television with only seven countries competing: the Netherlands, Switzerland, Belgium, Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Italy.\n\nThe show reached 162 million people in 2023 through public service markets.\n\nSweden and Ireland are leading with seven wins each. France, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands have each won five times, with the Netherlands as the most recent of the four countries to win in 2019.\n\nSwedish singer Loreen won last year's competition in Liverpool for the second time with her song \"Tattoo\". She is the only person after Ireland's Johnny Logan to win the contest twice.\n\n(Reporting by Isabelle Yr Carlsson and Louise Breusch Rasmussen; Editing by Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen, Sharon Singleton, Christina Fincher and Toby Chopra)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@theprint.in", "name": "Reuters", "type": "author", {"uri": "8115955314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:45:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:45:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:44:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.thepinknews.com/2024/05/07/every-eurovision-2024-entry-and-video/", "title": "Here's every single Eurovision 2024 song contest entry and video - you're welcome", "body": "Olly Alexander will be representing the UK with his single \"Dizzy\" (YouTube/ Eurovision Song Contest)\n\nThe 2024 Eurovision Song Contest is right around the corner, and the world's most-watched music competition is religiously marked in the calendars of the legions of queer fans who adore the camp, glitzy song contest.\n\nThe best party of the year is fast approaching in May, tickets are selling like hot cakes and, following Loreen's victory in Liverpool last year, Eurovision will move to Malm\u00f6, in Sweden.\n\nAs each country hosts their national qualifying contest, we're slowly learning more about the songs and artists competing for the coveted crown, including Ireland's non-binary entry and the UK's very own Olly Alexander, of Years & Years and It's a Sin fame.\n\n37 countries will be battling it out for the crown this year, with two semi-finals set to take place on 7 and 9 May ahead of the grand final on 11 May.\n\nThe draw on 30 January will decide which of the two semis each country will participate in - with the exception of the 'Big Five' countries of the UK, France, Germany, Spain and Italy, which all have an automatic place in the final.\n\nOn March 26 2024, Eurovision announced the running order the various countries will appear on stage - and which of the two semi-finals each country will star in: you can read more here. Want to know which of the 37 artists are members of the LGBTQ+ community? There are eight LGBTQ+ acts in total, you can find out here.\n\nBesa, dressed in glitzy all-gold outfit, won the hearts of the voting population in Albania with her song \"Zemr\u00ebn N'dor\u00eb, at the National Final Performance.\n\nHowever, this isn't the track she'll perform at Eurovision 2024: she'll be singing \"Titan\".\n\nLadaniva have dropped the video energetic song Jako, ahead of their trip to Malm\u00f6 in May. The duo is made up of Armenian vocalist Jaklin Baghdasaryan and French multi-instrumentalist Louis Thomas.\n\nAccording to the official Eurovision website: \"From traditional Balkan melodies to the rhythms of maloya, jazz and reggae, the duo's songs have been said to transcend borders, blending traditional Armenian tunes with inspirations drawn from their extensive travels across Latin America, Africa and R\u00e9union Island.\"\n\nPop star and professional dancer Kaleen will be competing on behalf of Austria. Presenting a techno-inspired pop track, \"Games\", she's elated to \"show the world\" what she can do.\n\n\"I haven't fully grasped the fact yet, that I'll be standing on that stage as an artist myself. I am in love with this world of lights and cameras and believe it's a privilege to take the audience on a journey,\" she said.\n\nElectronic duo Electric Fields will represent Australia in the Eurovision Song Contest with the song One Milkali (One Blood).\n\nIn a first for the Eurovision Song Contest, the song will incorporate Yankunytjatjara; an Aboriginal language of the Anangu peoples, one of the oldest living cultures on earth.\n\nFahree was born in Baku in 1995 and was brought up in an artistic family; his father was a jazz drummer, while his grandfather was a respected actor. His song \"\u00d6z\u00fcnl\u0259 Apar\" will be performed alongside Ilkin Dovlatov: renowned for his contributions to Azerbaijani music as a mugham vocalist.\n\nHaving already released two studio albums, Mustii is a familiar figure in Belgian pop culture, and he's made a for himself as a judge on Drag Race Belgique. His Eurovision 2024 song \"Before The Party's Over\" is a belter.\n\nAlongside his musical escapades, he's known for an array of theatre and television productions, including La Tr\u00eave, Grave, Un Petit Boulot, and L'\u00e9change des Princesses.\n\nCroatia will be represented by Baby Lasagna - a project by musician Marko Puri\u0161i\u0107 - with the song \"Rim Tim Tagi Dim\", a track representing a young person's journey from Croatia in search of a bright future in another country.\n\n\"The title is the name of the folklore dance that comes from the village where the song's hero is from,\" Puri\u0161i\u0107 said in an interview about the title \"Rim Tim Tagi Dim\".\n\nAlthough born and raised in Australia, Kapsis is of both Cypriot and Greek descent and has appeared on The Jennifer Hudson Show and various Nickelodeon programmes.\n\nShe wrote her debut single, \"Who Am I?\" at the age of 12, which she released in 2022, followed by \"No Boys Allowed\" and \"Disco Dancer\".\n\nRepresenting Czechia at Eurovision 2024 is the Brighton-based Aiko, who explores love, solitude and self-understanding through her music.\n\nShe's already made history both in the US and at home as the first Czech artist to grace the advertising placards of the world-famous Times Square in New York.\n\nSinger, musical theatre actress and model SABA will be representing Denmark at this year's Eurovision Song Contest, having made her debut on stage in the musical Hair in 2023.\n\nSABA, real name Anna Saba Lykke Oehlenschl\u00e6ger, took over from her pregnant sister in the role of Dionne in February 2023.\n\nHip-hop group 5Miinust and folk duo Puuluup will be representing Estonia with the song \"(Nendest) narkootikumidest ei tea me (k\u00fcll) midagi\", reportedly breaking the record for longest song title in Eurovision.\n\nThe song, which translates to \"We (sure) know nothing about (these) drugs\", was written by members of both groups, and was reportedly inspired by a comment one of them had made about drugs during a car trip.\n\nWindows95man, an alter ego of Finnish DJ Teemu Keisteri, is made for Eurovision. His performance sees him wear a retro Windows95 t-shirt and scandalously short jorts as he dances with pyrotechnics attached to his hips.\n\nWindows95man has teamed up as a duo with Henri Piispanen who dominates singing their effortlessly catchy, upbeat track \"No Rules.\"\n\nSlimane started performing in the piano bars of Paris' Pigalle district, and went on to win The Voice France in 2016.\n\nHe's since sold two million albums, and secured five Nouvelle Radio des Jeunes music awards and a Victoire de la Musique.\n\nNutsa Buzaladze is no stranger to competition: She finished in the top 12 in American Idol in 2023, performing \"Can't Get You Out Of My Head\" with none other than Aussie pop queen Kylie.\n\nIsaak Guderian, known as Isaak, began his career as a street musician, going on to star in the German version of The X Factor, singing a cover of the Oasis song \"Wonderwall\". Isaak went on to win the contest Show Your Talent in 2021.\n\nIsaak will be performing poppy ballad \"Always On The Run\" at this year's Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nMarina Satti will represent Greece in Eurovision 2024, 50 years to the day since the country first participated.\n\nHer song-writing style combines the Greek, Arabic and Balkan musical traditions that she grew up around, having released her first full-length album, Yenna, in 2022. She's singing \"Zari\" in Eurovision 2024.\n\nHera Bj\u00f6rk \u00de\u00f3rhallsd\u00f3ttir (born 29 March 1972) also represented Iceland in the Eurovision Song Contest 2010. \"Scared of Heights\" was written by Ferras Alqaisi, Jaro Omar, Michael Burek, and \u00c1sd\u00eds Mar\u00eda Vi\u00f0arsd\u00f3ttir.\n\nSelf-described \"ouija pop\" singer Bambie Thug, from Cork, will be heading to Malmo to represent Ireland. Bambie is the first non-binary artist to ever represent the country at Eurovision.\n\nBambie, who uses they/them pronouns, will enter the contest with their 2023 song \"Doomsday Blue\" from their EP, Cathexis.\n\nSpeaking to PinkNews last November, Bambie shared how realising that they are non-binary changed the way they approach their music.\n\n\"I allowed myself to be more free as a person and therefore more free in my music,\" they shared. \"Bambie Thug the project is two-and-a-half years old now, and it's been steadily going up.\n\n\"Something in the universe said, 'OK, now you have aligned. You are ready'.\"\n\nEden Golan was named winner of Israel's national selection competition, HaKokhav HaBa, in February.\n\nShe'll be attempting to become the fifth Israeli act to win Eurovision, with previous winners for Israel including Netta in 2018 and trailblazing trans artist Dana International in 1998.\n\nAfter rock band M\u00e5neskin shot to fame after winning for Italy in 2021, the country has some big shoes to fill. Thankfully, chart-topping Angelina Mango could bag that coveted \"douze points\" with her single \"La noia\".\n\nAngelina Mango rose to fame in 2023, when two of her singles rose to number one in the Italian singles chart. She has since gone on to perform in a sell-out tour, achieve two gold records, and amass an enormous audience on TikTok.\n\nLatvia has gone for a classic ballad for its entry this year, with singer-songwriter Dons singing the song \"Hollow\".\n\nAccording to the singer, \"Hollow\" explores the feeling of being held \"hostage to your own insecurities, demons, inner feelings, relationships, and views\".\n\nSilvester Belt is no stranger to a competition, having taken part in Lithuanian singing competitons A\u0161 - superhitas and The X Factor.\n\nDescribing queer icon Troye Sivan as his \"all-time inspiration\", Silvester Belt will be performing electro pop single \"Luktelk\" at this year's Eurovision.\n\n23-year-old singer Tali will be the first act to represent Luxembourg at Eurovision in more than three decades with her track \"Fighter\".\n\n25-year-old Sarah Bonnici won the Malta Eurovision Song Contest 2024 in February with her track \"Loop\" after securing the highest number of points from the jury and public votes.\n\nPerforming \"In The Middle\", this will be Natalia Barbu's second appearance at Eurovision, with the singer previously representing Moldova in 2007.\n\nThe singer's entry to this year's competition is apparently a call for \"intimacy and understanding\".\n\nCombining mainstream pop with hardcore and punk sounds, Joost Klein had a number one hit in Germany, Switzerland and Austria with his track \"Friesenjung\".\n\nRacking up over 100 million streams worldwide, it took home the accolade for best song in Germany's 1LIVE Krone radio awards. He'll be singing \"Europapa\" at Eurovision 2024.\n\nFolk-rock band G\u00e5te won Norway's national selection competition Melodi Grand Prix 2024.\n\nThe group is an established name in Norway and consists of members Gunnhild Sundli, Magnus B\u00f8rmark, Jon Even Sch\u00e4rer, Mats Paulsen, and John Stenersen.\n\nPolish singer-songwriter will represent Poland this year with song \"The Tower\", in a style she describes as \"cosmic pop\".\n\nThe 24-year-old singer described the song as a \"manifesto of freedom and strength\".\n\n\"It is realising our own strength, fullness, and that our limitations are our creation,\" LUNA said in an interview. \"The tower is a place or state that we build ourselves.\"\n\n\"Grito\" was written by Iolanda Costa alongside Alberto Hern\u00e1ndez. In a recent interview she explained that she wrote the song after being invited to participate in Festival da Can\u00e7\u00e3o 2024, and described it as \"a scream of self defence and trusting in yourself\".\n\nSpanish rock band Megara will be representing San Marino at this year's Eurovision, with \"11:11\", a song which fuses elements of rock, metal, dance and electronica sounds.\n\nThe band has previously explained their reluctance to be \"pigeonholed\" into any one genre of music, stating their style is \"the perfect mix between the sinister and cotton candy\".\n\nSerbian singer-songwriter will be representing the country with the song \"Ramonda\", named after the flower Natalie's ramonda.\n\nThe flower is seen to represent the Serbian people's struggles and victory during World War One, due to its ability to revive itself even after it's completely dried out.\n\nTeya Dora was chosen to represent Serbia during Eurovision this year after she went viral on TikTok with her 2023 single D\u017eanum.\n\nCombining pop and opera to create a unique sound, Raiven is a mezzo-soprano singer, as well as an author, songwriter and harpist.\n\nShe's represented Slovenia three times at Eurovision, singing \"\u010crno Bel\" in 2016, \"Za\u017earim\" in 2017, and \"Kaos\" in 2019.\n\nSynth-pop duo Nebulossa will be representing Spain this year with the song \"Zorra\".\n\nThe song name itself was subject to controversy in the run-up to Eurovision, translating to \"vixen\" and often used as a misogynistic insult. The song, with themes of women's empowerment, aims to reappropriate the slur, which was allowed to be included in the lyrics by the European Broadcasting Union.\n\nEurovision 2024 hosts Sweden are placing their hopes on twins Twins Marcus & Martinus, who rose to fame as one of Scandinavia's biggest pop sensations after winning Norway's 'Junior MGP' in 2012.\n\n\"The Code\", by Swiss singer Nemo, is described as a song that explores their experience coming out as non-binary, with the singer explaining that they didn't \"feel like a man or a woman... I had to break a few codes\".\n\n\"'The Code' is about the journey I started with the realisation that I am neither a man nor a woman,\" Nemo explained in an interview.\n\n\"Finding myself has been a long and often difficult process for me. But nothing feels better than the freedom I have gained by realising that I am non-binary.\"\n\nAlyona and Alyone & Jerry Heil will aim to become Ukraine's fourth winning Eurovision entry with their track \"Teresa & Marias\".\n\nThe song addresses the strength of women amid Ukraine's ongoing war with Russia, with the duo stating: \"On behalf of women, we are talking about the importance of unity for significant actions and victories. And even though we, as Ukrainians, wrote this song about Ukraine, everyone can recognise themselves in the lyrics.\n\n\"We're talking about unification because that's what creates synergy and brings much more results.\"", "source": {"uri": "thepinknews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PinkNews | Latest lesbian, gay, bi and trans news | LGBTQ+ news"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8112279796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:45:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:45:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T11:45:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/entertainment/2024/0505/1447490-eurovision-organisers-on-decision-not-to-exclude-israel/", "title": "Eurovision organisers on decision not to exclude Israel", "body": "Organisers of the Eurovision Song Contest have said excluding the Israeli broadcaster Kan from the competition would have been a \"political decision\".\n\nThere have been calls for fans and participants to boycott the music competition taking place in Malmo, Sweden, next week after it was confirmed Israel would be competing amid the ongoing conflict in the Gaza strip.\n\nSpeaking on Sunday Morning With Trevor Phillips, Jean Philip De Tender, the deputy director general of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) which organises Eurovision, said it based its decision to include Kan on the competition rules in place.\n\nHe said: \"I fully agree it is a family event and the great thing about this music competition is that it's all about values.\n\n\"It's about uniting onstage all of these young talents, these participants, and they do great. It's about diversity and inclusion.\n\n\"But there are competition rules and you need to follow the competition rules and take decisions based on these competition rules.\n\n\"If you were to exclude Kan outside of these competition rules, that would have been a political decision, as such, which we cannot take.\"\n\nHe also noted the EBU, an apolitical member organisation, is \"in line\" with other international federations including sports bodies who are allowing Israel to participate in events.\n\nFollowing the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war, Queers for Palestine circulated a letter signed by actors Indya Moore, Brigette Lundy-Paine and Maxine Peake calling for UK entrant Olly Alexander to stop participating.\n\nIn March, Alexander along with Irish hopeful Bambie Thug and other Eurovision artists released a joint statement, backing \"an immediate and lasting ceasefire\" but refusing to boycott the event.\n\nThat same month, Israel unveiled its new entry song as Hurricane, performed by singer Eden Golan.\n\nHer original track, October Rain, had caused controversy as the lyrics were thought to reference the Hamas attacks of 7 October before being changed following the backlash.\n\nDiscussing the backlash, De Tender said: \"We do understand the concerns and the deeply held views that many people have around the war in the Middle East and I think nobody can remain untouched by the profound suffering of everybody involved in that war.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a music event which is organised and co-produced by 37 public broadcasters, so it's not a competition between nations or governments.\n\n\"We do understand that there was some concern around Israel participating, but when our governing bodies, because we're a member led organisation, reviewed the participation list of this year, they concluded that Kan, which is the Israeli public broadcaster, met all of the obligations compared to the competing rules.\"\n\nIn 2022, EBU announced that Russia would no longer be participating in Eurovision following the invasion of Ukraine.\n\nA statement at the time said the EBU's executive board had made the decision following a recommendation by the Eurovision governing body, known as the reference group, based on \"the rules of the event and the values of the EBU\".\n\nOn Sunday, De Tender said the situation between Russia and Israel was \"different\" as in Russia's case there was a \"broad consensus within the membership of the EBU that they could not participate\".\n\nHe added that the three Russian members of the EBU had already been \"excluded\" from the EBU membership in the weeks after the war broke out due to breaching \"member obligations\".\n\nThe 37 Eurovision entries are set to perform across two semi-finals next week on Tuesday and Thursday in a bid to compete for a place in the grand final on Saturday.\n\nIreland's Bambie Thug will perform fourth in the first semi-final on Tuesday.\n\nDe Tender said the preparations are going \"very well\" as they have been planning the music spectacle in Sweden for the past year after Loreen won the competition with her hit song Tattoo.\n\nSource: Press {"uri": "8117608496", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:00:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:00:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:00:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.vox.com/world-politics/24151274/eurovision-song-contest-politics-russia-ukraine-gaza-israel-palestine", "title": "Eurovision says it's \"apolitical.\" History says otherwise.", "body": "The song contest will be thousands of miles away -- in Malmo, Sweden -- but fury over the war is expected to be palpable in the small Scandinavian city, whose population will swell with both Eurovision fans and protesters. Over 1,000 artists in the host country signed a letter calling for Israel's disqualification for its \"brutal warfare in Gaza,\" according to the Guardian, and pro-Palestinian groups are lobbying state broadcasters not to air the event and calling on artists to refuse to participate.\n\nAlready, Swedish pop star Eric Saade appeared wearing a keffiyeh -- a traditional scarf that has come to symbolize resistance to Israel's incursion into Gaza -- around his wrist during a performance on Tuesday night. A spokesperson for European Broadcasting Union (EBU) -- which organizes the event -- issued their \"regrets\" over the decision, according to the BBC. Saade has appeared as a Eurovision competitor before but was a guest performer last night.\n\nPolitics intruding on Eurovision isn't new, despite its stated desire to stay above the fray.\n\nIn 2022, the contest disqualified Russia over its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nNonetheless, the EBU has rejected demands from pro-Palestinian activists, maintaining that it is a music event that keeps political messages away from the stage. Sweden will bring additional police from Denmark and Norway to Malmo, and the Eurovision Song Contest is expected to continue with the usual participants, including Israel, which has won Eurovision four times since joining the contest in 1973.\n\nThe EBU did require Israel to revise its entry this year, though, which was a song initially called \"October Rain,\" featuring the lyrics \"those that write history, stand with me.\" The song appeared to be a reference to Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel that killed more than 1,100 people and led to the kidnapping of some 240, dozens of whom are still held hostage.\n\nThe reference to the attack was deemed too political by the EBU, and thus ineligible for the competition. Israel initially refused to sanitize its entry, even threatening to pull out of the competition, but revised it after involvement from President Isaac Herzog. The new song, which will be performed by Eden Golan, is now a romantic ballad entitled \"Hurricane,\" and the opening line was changed to \"writer of my symphony, play with me.\"\n\nThe controversy over Israel's song and the protests looming over this year's event underscore how much politics encroaches on an event that seeks to promote a utopian vision of global comity. But as Tess Megginson, a PhD candidate studying European history at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, argues, the song contest, founded during the Cold War with seven European countries and initially excluding the Soviet Union, has always been a space for political performance. In an interview with Today, Explained host Sean Rameswaram, she explained that while some of today's controversy is unique, the contest had some of its most contentious political moments after the dissolution of the Soviet Union.\n\nThis conversation has been edited for length and clarity. You can listen to a longer version of Megginson's interview and highlights from Eurovision on Today, Explained. -- Haleema Shah, producer\n\nYou wrote in the Washington Post that politics at Eurovision is nothing new, using the '90s as an example.\n\nI would argue the 1990s are actually some of the most political years of the contest, and this actually isn't always a bad thing.\n\nAs soon as you have the Eastern European countries start joining, hosts are talking about welcome to the rest of Europe, and now we're finally unified. And you have all these songs about peace and unity and breaking down walls. Some of these do quite well in the contest, some of them don't. In 1990, the first competition held in Eastern Europe, in Zagreb, the winning entry was Italy with \"Insieme: 1992.\" The hook in the chorus is \"unite, unite Europe,\" and it got a very good reception and won the competition.\n\nIt is a really beautiful time in the contest, but also in the '90s you have the Yugoslav wars. And this is the first time that we actually see a country banned from the competition. Yugoslavia was banned from the contest shortly after the 1992 competition because of the siege of Sarajevo. UN sanctions are imposed against Yugoslavia, and Bosnia is able to participate in the competition, but Yugoslavia cannot. Even though Bosnia is not participating with a song entry, they're still able to vote in the contest [and] call into the contest while under siege.\n\nWow.\n\nThe phone line initially disconnects and it goes dead. And there's just this silence that falls over the audience. Soon they're able to reconnect, and there's a loud applause and cheering from the audience as they're able to give their points for the contest. It's a really beautiful moment of solidarity for people who were at war and under occupation. And it's something that, even though it's a very political moment, it's quite a beautiful moment in the contest's history.\n\nThese political moments we're talking about -- the fall of the Berlin Wall, the fall of communism, the genocide in Bosnia -- they all happened on the continent of Europe. But here, now, in 2024, we've got this controversy and calls for a boycott that relate to something happening in the Middle East. Is there a precedent for that at Eurovision?\n\nYeah. Boycotts in Eurovision are almost as old as the contest itself, starting in the 1970s. In 1975, Turkey invaded Cyprus, and Greece boycotted the contest. The following year, Greece submits a song that is a very anti-war song and clearly referencing Turkey's presence in Cyprus, and Turkey boycotts the contest. So that's kind of the first example we see of these big boycotts.\n\nMore recently [there have] been calls to boycott Azerbaijan because of their treatment of their viewers who vote for Armenia. They've threatened to block the Armenian broadcast before. And of course, when they hosted the contest in 2012, there was a big outcry because they displaced a lot of people living in a community in Baku because they were building a stadium just to host the Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nWow.\n\nAnd then of course, Russia's the big one that you see a lot in the conversation because of its invasion of Ukraine, finally banned from the competition in 2022.\n\nIt sounds like it's par for the course to have this level of controversy and calls for boycotts and tensions between nations at Eurovision. Does that make this current controversy less exceptional?\n\nNot necessarily. I think there's also been a long and unique history with Israel's participation in the contest. As the first non-European country to participate, it's also had relative success since it joined.\n\nIt's won the contest four times and hosted it three times. All the way back in 1978, we started seeing these controversies arise with Israel's participation. In 1978, they actually won the competition, but in Jordan, which was a member of the EBU, although not participating in the contest, they didn't air the Israel entry. And when it became clear that Israel was going to win the contest, they cut the broadcast short and announced Belgium as the winner in Jordan.\n\nWhat? They just lied?!\n\nYep, they lied to people in Jordan and said Belgium had won the contest. I don't know when they found out that wasn't true.\n\nWhen they got Wikipedia.\n\nYeah. Pre-Internet, it was a lot easier to get away with that sort of thing.\n\nHow does Eurovision typically handle the boycotts and the tensions between these nations?\n\nNot very well. They officially market themselves as an apolitical contest. So when politics enter the contest, they are not happy about it. One kind of fun example is in 2015, they introduced what they called \"anti-booing technology.\"\n\nYou couldn't hear the crowd booing the Russian entry during the contest. I don't think it's been used since then, but I wouldn't be surprised if they use a similar thing this year.\n\nAnd another thing is fines -- they do really like to fine their members. In 2019, when Israel hosted the contest, there were calls to boycott and move the contest out of Israel. Icelandic performers held up Palestinian flags and the Icelandic broadcaster ended up getting a huge fine from the EBU for doing that.\n\nDo you think Eurovision this year will end up transcending our current geopolitical situation?\n\nThere are a couple signs we can look for to see how Europeans are reacting to Israel's participation. The first is going to be the live audience reaction. This is going to be more difficult for us to see as viewers; we're probably going to have to rely on things like social media and journalists on the ground to hear how the audience is reacting to Israel participating.\n\nBut we're also going to see this maybe with the other performers, if they, say, wave Palestinian flags like we saw in 2019. Also, when the votes are given out at the end of the competition, are people going to boo countries that give Israel top votes? We'll have to see.\n\nA second thing, of course, is the popular vote. Will people vote for Israel or will this be a protest vote against them? If there's a big difference between the jury vote for Israel and the popular vote, that's probably a sign that people are not voting for Israel because they don't agree with what they're doing in Gaza.\n\nThe third thing to see is viewership. If the boycott is effective, there'll probably be a stark decline in viewership in certain countries. Obviously, there are other factors at play here. So if a country, a participant, doesn't make the finals, there could be a decline in viewership because of that, but if we see a significant decline, I would probably argue that it's the boycott.", {"uri": "8115416546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "11:08:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T11:08:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T11:08:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://bnn-news.com/politico-who-would-lead-the-eu-if-the-decision-was-based-on-eurovision-success-256756", "title": "Politico: Who would lead the EU if the decision was based on Eurovision success? - Baltic News Network", "body": "According to the latest Eurobarometer poll, the European Union (EU) elections are of concern to around 60% of EU citizens, but the Eurovision vote is the one that Europe is most worried about, which is why Politico, on Tuesday, the 7th of May, by studying and analysing Eurovision data, is reporting on what would happen if the Eurovision votes had more political influence in the EU, calculating how many seats countries would get in the European Parliament (EP) if the Eurovision vote were to decide everything.\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest has been contested by different countries, with Germany having participated the most - 66 times - followed by the United Kingdom, France, Belgium, Switzerland and the Netherlands. Spain and Sweden have participated 62 times. Norway, Finland, Ireland, Austria, Portugal and Denmark have participated more than 50 times. Italy, Greece, Cyprus, Luxembourg and Malta also have a significant number of participants.\n\nSweden and Ireland have the most Eurovision wins with seven each. The UK has also won five times, but its withdrawal from the EU rules it out.\n\nOn the other hand, 18 countries have had the embarrassment of receiving zero points in the finals, led by Norway and Austria with four each.\n\nAccording to Eurovision data from the last decade,\n\nSweden and Italy are the main contenders for EU leadership in terms of total points,\n\nand Malta and Cyprus are also strong contenders. By contrast, Germany's position suggests that it should step back from the reins.\n\nAccording to Politico's calculations, Sweden should have 94 seats in the EP instead of the current 21, and Italy 80 instead of the current 76, but Germany should have only 12 instead of 96.\n\nLuxembourg and Slovakia are at the bottom of the rankings. Although Luxembourg currently have six and Slovakia 15 seats, they should both have only one seat. Luxembourg is participating in this year's contest, so it could move up, while Slovakia is not participating and has not done so since 2012.\n\nMeanwhile, Latvia should take 13 of the current nine seats.\n\nEurovision and the EU share common features, as both are exclusive clubs that enjoy enlargement.\n\nBut unlike EU accession talks, Eurovision accession talks move quickly and Eurovision, which started with just seven countries in 1956, has over the years had entries from 52 countries, not all of them European, but also, for example, Australia.\n\nOver the years, Sweden has been successful thanks to the broad support of voters from the bloc, which is predominantly made up of northern European allies, although this has caused some controversy, for example last year the public Learn more\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest is back for its 68th year, and the 2024 competition takes viewers to Sweden. We've compiled everything you need to know about how to watch Eurovision from anywhere in the world.\n\nCreated in 1956, Eurovision originally had just seven countries submit songs to perform in competition with each other. Now, more than 30 countries compete yearly (this year, 37 countries will participate). Fans and juries from competing nations vote to determine the ultimate winner each year. Sweden's Loreen won the 2023 competition for her song \"Tattoo,\" and Ukraine and Italy won in 2022 and 2021, respectively. Ireland and Sweden hold the joint record for most Eurovision wins, with seven each.\n\nWith the exception of a 2020 Covid-related cancellation, the competition has been held every year since its inception, making it one of the most popular and longest-running non-sports-related annual competitions. If you can't wait to tune in, we've got you covered. Below, we have a breakdown of everything you need to know about watching Eurovision, including free live streaming options and a schedule for the week.\n\nPeacock is the US live streaming home to Eurovision. Plans start at $5.99 a month for the ad-supported tier. You can upgrade to an ad-free version for $11.99 a month. Peacock is the US streaming hub for many live global competitions and will provide extensive Olympics coverage later this summer.\n\nEurovision airs on the BBC in the UK. This means that viewers can live stream it for free through BBC iPlayer. You just need to create an account to start streaming this English language option.\n\nIn France, Eurovision will air on France TV. This free streaming option only requires you to register for an account, and then you're good to enjoy the competition.\n\nEurovision live streams on RTVE Play in Spain. This is another free streaming option that only requires account creation.\n\nIn addition to the global broadcasts, the competition will be live-streamed through Eurovision's YouTube channel in select regions (excluding the US and many other countries where a viewing option is available through traditional broadcasting methods). If you find yourself in an area where you can't access any Eurovision streams or hope to tap into one of the above methods, you can try out a VPN.\n\nShort for virtual private networks, VPNs are handy tools to temporarily alter your device's virtual location so that you can access websites that vary in availability from region to region. VPNs are popular options for people looking to boost their online privacy and have access to their usual websites and apps while traveling. Interested in learning more? "BRITAIN'S ultimate Eurovision superfans have landed in Sweden for this year's contest.\n\nA group of fanatics, draped in sequins and sparkles inspired by the competition, arrived at Copenhagen airport before travelling to the venue in Malm\u00f6 ahead of the semi-final.\n\nThe mega fans boarded an easyJet flight, the official airline of the contest, from London Gatwick at the crack of dawn which descended into singalongs to get the party started.\n\nThe flight featured dedicated themed baggage drop, fancy dress, and a talent show at 40,000 feet, hosted by Drag Race star Tia Kofi.\n\nOne of the Eurovision lovers who made the journey said: \"The flight laid on for us today was the ultimate treat for any Eurovision fan who loves to celebrate the glitz, glamour, and unity of Eurovision.\n\n\"I can't believe what an amazing experience it's been so far, and we haven't even left the airport yet.\"\n\nIt comes after a poll found six and a half million Brits will be attending a Eurovision party this year.\n\nMore than a third (35 per cent) of the 2,000 adults polled will be tuning into the singing contest this year, with 36 per cent of those either hosting their own festivities or celebrating at someone else's home.\n\nAnd one in five will be clad in iconic Eurovision looks - with D'Nash, the 2007 Spanish entrant, Brotherhood of Man, the UK winners of 1976, and Ireland's 2021 entrant, Jedward, being the most popular.\n\nClosely followed by outfits inspired by Belarus' 3 + 2, iconic Swedish band ABBA and Celine Dion's 1974 entry for France.\n\nAs well as dressing up, 38 per cent will serve food inspired by the competing countries, such as Italy, Spain, and Greece.\n\nMichael Brown, director of cabin services at easyJet, said: \"We are proud to be part of the Eurovision phenomenon, providing a glittering platform for fans to start their Eurovision journey.\n\n\"Our Super Fan Flight to Copenhagen promises to be a memorable adventure - a high-flying act of its own.\n\n\"Our mission is to connect people and cultures together, and we're proud to be the Official Airline of the Eurovision Song Contest who share this passion.\"\n\nThe research also found 39 per cent love the Eurovision song contest - with 23 per cent becoming a bigger fan of the event after it was hosted in Liverpool last year.\n\nThe songs (31 per cent), commentary (24 per cent) and the outfits (21 per cent) are the top reasons why.\n\nAnd 27 per cent have even been inspired to visit new countries because of Eurovision, with Italy, Greece and Spain topping the list.\n\nIt also emerged 42 would enjoy being in the live audience - because of the sense of unity between nations (21 per cent), to celebrate the diversity (19 per cent) and to be around like minded people (12 per cent).\n\nWhen it comes to the UK's entry this year, 64 per cent don't think we are likely to win - with 43 per cent blaming this on the bad track record.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8115386575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "10:51:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T10:51:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T10:51:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/uk-news/eurovision-fans-flight-contest-music-29124421", "title": "Eurovision super fans descend into singalongs on flight to Malmo", "body": "Britain's ultimate Eurovision superfans have touched down in Sweden for this year's contest. A group of enthusiasts, adorned in sequins and sparkles inspired by the competition, arrived at Copenhagen airport before making their way to the venue in Malmo ahead of the semi-final.\n\nThe die-hard fans boarded an easyJet flight, the official airline of the contest, from London Gatwick at the break of dawn which quickly turned into a singalong to kickstart the festivities. The flight featured a dedicated themed baggage drop, fancy dress, and a talent show at 40,000 feet, hosted by Drag Race star Tia Kofi.\n\nOne of the Eurovision devotees who made the journey said: \"The flight laid on for us today was the ultimate treat for any Eurovision fan who loves to celebrate the glitz, glamour, and unity of Eurovision. I can't believe what an amazing experience it's been so far, and we haven't even left the airport yet.\"\n\nThis comes after a survey found that six and a half million Brits will be attending a Eurovision party this year. More than a third (35 per cent) of the 2,000 adults surveyed will be tuning into the singing contest this year, with 36 per cent of those either hosting their own festivities or celebrating at someone else's home.\n\nAnd one in five will be dressed in iconic Eurovision looks - with D'Nash, the 2007 Spanish entrant, Brotherhood of Man, the UK winners of 1976, and Ireland's 2021 entrant, Jedward, being the most popular.\n\nFollowing closely are costumes inspired by Belarus' 3 + 2, the legendary Swedish band ABBA and Celine Dion's 1974 entry for France. In addition to dressing up, 38 per cent of fans will serve food inspired by the competing countries, such as Italy, Spain, and Greece.\n\nMichael Brown, director of cabin services at easyJet, expressed: \"We are proud to be part of the Eurovision phenomenon, providing a glittering platform for fans to start their Eurovision journey. Our Super Fan Flight to Copenhagen promises to be a memorable adventure - a high-flying act of its own. Our mission is to connect people and cultures together, and we're proud to be the Official Airline of the Eurovision Song Contest who share this passion.\"\n\nThe study also revealed that 39 per cent of respondents love the Eurovision song contest, with 23 per cent becoming bigger fans after Liverpool hosted the event last year. The songs (31 per cent), commentary (24 per cent) and the outfits (21 per cent) are the top reasons why.\n\nFurthermore, 27 per cent have been inspired to visit new countries because of Eurovision, with Italy, Greece and Spain topping the list. It also emerged that 42 would enjoy being in the live audience due to the sense of unity between nations (21 per cent), celebrating diversity (19 per cent) and being around like-minded people (12 per cent).\n\nWhen it comes to the UK's entry this year, 64 per cent don't think we are likely to win, with 43 per cent attributing this to our poor track record. In the initial number of three guests, three former Eurovision contestants who did not win the festival but obtained excellent results - the Spanish-Cuban Chanel Terrero, the Greek-Albanian Eleni Foureira and the Swede Eric Saade -, the Swedish performer appeared with a Palestinian scarf wrapped around the left wrist.\n\nWith the gala still underway, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) was quick to regret what happened. A spokeswoman told reporters: \"The Eurovision Song Contest is a live television programme. \"All artists know the rules of the contest and we regret that Eric Saade has decided to compromise the apolitical nature of the event.\" Before the semi-final at the Malm\u00f6 Arena, the pavilion that hosts the galas during the week, Eurofans were warned not to bring Palestinian flags or symbols.\n\nEric Saade, whose mother is Swedish and whose father is Palestinian, sang Popular, the song with which he came third in Eurovision in 2011, with his scarf always visible, ignoring the express prohibition. On the same stage, Chanel, accompanied by twelve dancers, did a powerful reinterpretation of SloMo, the song with which she won third place in the 2022 contest. Eleni Foureira, who won second place for Cyprus in 2018, performed the explosive song Fuego that earned him that place in the record.\n\nAmong the ten representatives who managed to qualify for the final on Saturday the 11th thanks to the audience's televoting are two who appear in the quintet of favorites to win the crystal microphone, according to the betting houses: the Croatian Baby Lasagna and the Ukrainians Alyona Alyona\n\nThis last country returns to the Eurovision contest after 31 years of absence, being one of the seven founding countries of the festival and having won it five times. Luxembourg has managed to qualify with the singer Tali, who performs Fighter in French and English.\n\nEach one made themselves noticed in their own way, as expected, the representatives of Finland and Ireland. Finnish DJ and visual artist Windows95man sings the techno-inspired No Rules! and in the staging - in which he emerges from inside a kind of egg - he is wearing flesh-colored underwear that leads one to believe that he is not wearing them. The Irish Bambie Thug combines pop, rock, techno and derivatives singing at the top of her voice Doomsday Blue, an ode to the queer community with a stage design in which religious elements are appreciated.\n\nAlong with the other ten who qualify in the second semi-final (on Thursday the 9th) there will be 20 qualifiers who, added to the Big Five (Germany, Spain, France, Italy and the United Kingdom), who due to their greatest financial contribution to the European Union of Broadcasting (EBU) go directly to the final, like the host country, in this case Sweden, there will thus be 26 countries to compete in the grand final on Saturday.\n\nIn Thursday's semifinal, the representative of Israel, Eden Golan, competes to reach the final, who this week in Malm\u00f6 limits her outings beyond rehearsals and official appointments, due to the tension derived from Israel's participation in the musical contest while it continues. the deadly military campaign against Hamas in Gaza.\n\nViewers decide the results of the two semi-finals with their vote, and can vote up to 20 times, either by phone, text message or through the Eurovision app. In the first semi-final, viewers from the 15 participating countries and those from three pre-qualified for the grand final voted: Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom. {"uri": "8115911875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:14:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:14:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:14:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/northumberland-twin-brothers-hit-eurovision-29125094", "title": "Twin brothers with hit Eurovision Song Contest podcast heading to Sweden", "body": "After a few drinks on Eurovision night, you might think you're seeing double but it's actually twin brothers who are broadcasting live from the competition in Sweden as part of their popular podcast.\n\nUniversity of Sunderland students Callum and James Rowe, 27, from Cramlington, are heading to Malm\u00f6 in Sweden to cover this year's Eurovision Song Contest as the producers of the world's most listened to independent Eurovision podcast, The Euro Trip.\n\nCallum is studying Journalism at the University of Sunderland, and his twin brother James graduated from Sunderland with a degree in Media Production in 2022. Both are massive Eurovision fans and wanted to take their passion for pop - and journalism - to Sweden.\n\nREAD MORE: Who is Olly Alexander? UK Eurovision act at Malmo contest with song Dizzy Keep up to date with all the latest breaking news and top stories from the North East with our free newsletter\n\nTurning to the University of Sunderland's Development Office for help, the brothers were able to apply for a Futures Fund scholarship. The Fund, which supports current University of Sunderland students and recent graduates, offers up to \u00a32,500 for students to develop their careers and aspirations.\n\nNow, after successfully gaining their University's support, Callum and James will be at the world's biggest showcase for pop music on Saturday May 11.\n\n\"Being in Malm\u00f6 means I have the chance to work closely with artists, songwriters, members of international broadcasting delegations and other industry professionals to help cement myself as a trusted member of the worlds of journalism and Eurovision,\" says Callum. \"When I graduate this summer having this trip to Sweden on my CV as a real-world example of working as a journalist will be a huge selling point as I take my first steps into my career.\"\n\nAlongside brother James, Callum produces weekly episodes of podcast The Euro Trip. He says: \"Each episode is listened to by more than 1,000 people. During Eurovision week last year, we made daily episodes which saw our episode listenership more than double.\"\n\n\"The Euro Trip is the world's leading independent Eurovision podcast,\" adds James. \"The podcast was something I started doing alongside my studies, using the skills I was learning on my course and applying them to the real world.\"\n\nJames now works as a freelance audio producer for BBC Sport, Radio Newcastle and Hits Radio North East, but he is still committed to working alongside his brother on their Eurovision podcast.\n\n\"The podcast is something I am hugely proud of,\" says James. \"I still use it as a calling card and it stands front and centre on my CV.\n\n\"Callum and I have become a trusted name within the Eurovision media space, often appearing on outlets such as BBC News as experts on the contest.\"\n\nBefore working as a freelance producer, James volunteered at the University's community radio station, Spark, and Callum is continuing that family tradition.\n\n\"I'll be reporting live on-air for Spark about everything happening in the world of Eurovision,\" he says. \"The University of Sunderland has given me so much so far, so I see it as vital for me to give back and continue to support the University.\n\n\"I pour every ounce of my enthusiasm for Eurovision, journalism and storytelling into the work I do. A week in Sweden doing what I love is the next step on my journey to become a full-time journalist.\"\n\nAlistair Robinson, Senior Lecturer in Journalism and Public Relations at the University of Sunderland, backed the brothers' funding application. He says: \"I'm delighted we've been able to help Callum and James with this opportunity. They are Eurovision experts and have developed an extraordinary specialism in Eurovision reporting.\n\n\"I've taught Callum for three years now and he has produced consistently excellent work, on a range of subjects, not just pop music or Eurovision. Since graduating, James has further honed his skills in the industry. They make a formidable team.\"\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest final takes place in Malm\u00f6 in Sweden on Saturday May 11.", "source": {"uri": "chroniclelive.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-05-349445264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "19:46:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T19:46:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:21:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://cybernews.com/news/eurovision-faces-heightened-cyber-risks/", "title": "Eurovision faces heightened cyber risks | Cybernews", "body": "Eurovision has said it was closely working with security teams to protect the world's largest music competition from cyber attacks amid warnings of increased risks.\n\nThe 68th Eurovision Song Contest has kicked off in the Swedish city of Malm\u00f6 amidst increased security concerns fuelled by geopolitical tensions including Israel's assault on Gaza and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nAs one of the world's most watched non-sporting events - 162 million people tuned in to see the live broadcast last year - it is also a prime target for threat actors posing both conventional and cyber risks.\n\nCyber threats vary from the lower-impact distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks to potentially extremely damaging \"hijacking\" of the broadcast, according to the 23-page-long intelligence report released by the Swedish police last week.\n\nCybersecurity experts note the voting system could be a potential target, especially during Saturday's grand finale, while Malm\u00f6 police chief Petra Stenkula told the Swedish broadcaster SVT that disinformation was one of the biggest concerns.\n\nSVT is hosting this year's Eurovision, which is organized by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU). The event's representatives said they were aware of the risks and have taken the necessary steps to address them.\n\n\"We are working closely with SVT's security team and the relevant authorities and expert partners to ensure we have the appropriate measures in place to protect from such risks,\" the song contest's spokesperson said in an email.\n\nThey said that Eurovision's partner responsible for the voting, the Germany-based firm Digame, undertakes \"great efforts\" to protect the competition's voting system. \"However, we can't divulge any information about the measures and processes that are implemented to safeguard the public vote,\" the spokesperson said.\n\nRon Meyran, the head of cyber intelligence at cybersecurity firm Radware, said network operators should be \"particularly concerned\" about protecting broadcast networks, streaming services, voting platforms, ticketing operations, control systems, and other related infrastructure.\n\n\"When successful, these types of threats can easily result in reputational loss and the promotion of political propaganda at an event that was created to unite people through music and art,\" Meyran said.\n\nOverall security has been tightened in Malm\u00f6, where some 100,000 visitors were expected for the Eurovision Song Contest and the largest ever police operation in southern Sweden was set in motion, including reinforcements from neighboring Denmark and Sweden.\n\nMix of threats\n\nWhile the police said there were no specific threats to Eurovision, Sweden has been on a terror level four out of five since August last year. The threat level was raised to \"high\" following a spate of Quran burnings in the country that angered the Muslim community.\n\nSweden was a \"priority target\" for violent jihadist groups, according to the police threat assessment for Eurovision.\n\nThe EBU's decision to allow Israel to participate in Eurovision has led to ire in some circles, with detractors accusing the organizers of double standards after Russia was banned from the competition in 2022 following its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThe organizers said the situation between Russia and Israel was different and Eurovision was a \"non-political event.\"\n\nIn turn, Israel agreed to change its original entry called \"October Rain\" - widely interpreted as a reference to the October 7th Hamas attacks - into a more neutral \"Hurricane\" following a backlash.\n\nThe cybersecurity advisory released by Radware said Eurovision could be targeted by pro-Palestinian hacktivists, but also by Russia-linked threat actors over Sweden's support for Ukraine and the fact it has recently joined Nato.\n\n\"With attackers leveraging new tools and generative artificial intelligence to automate attacks, it has become increasingly easier for cybercriminals and even average citizens to carry out disruptive attacks,\" the advisory read.\n\n\"Toolkits, attack services and initial access are widely available for download or purchase across the internet and - as a result of the growing cyber conflict between Russia and the rest of the world - attack techniques have improved,\" it said.\n\nIn addition to cyberattacks, the Swedish police also cited general disruption and unrest as potential risks for Eurovision.\n\nOn Saturday, a large protest demanding Israel's removal from the contest is planned in Malm\u00f6, which is home to large Muslim and Palestinian communities. There are also calls to boycott Eurovision itself over its stance on Israel.\n\nHigh-profile targets\n\nCyberattacks are the \"main worry\" for organizers of Eurovision, the UK's national broadcaster BBC said last year when it hosted the event in Liverpool on behalf of Ukraine. Ukraine could not host the event itself due to the ongoing Russian invasion.\n\nThe Ukrainian folk-rap band Kalush Orchestra won the 2022 contest in Turin, Italy, which pro-Russian hacker group Killnet tried and failed to disrupt by launching a DDoS attack on the voting system. The Italian police said it had blocked its infiltration attempts.\n\nIn 2019, the hackers managed to disrupt the online stream of the Eurovision semi-finals in Israel by inserting warnings of a missile strike and images of blasts in Tel Aviv, the host city. The Israeli government blamed the incident on Hamas.\n\nOther high-profile entertainment and sports events will be facing an increased risk of cyberattacks this year. The Paris 2024 Olympics is getting ready for \"unprecedented\" cyberthreats, its organizers said.\n\nOrganized crime, activists, and state actors will be the main source of risks during the games later in the summer, they said.\n\nThey also said Paris 2024 was working \"hand in hand\" with the French National Agency for Information Security (ANSSI) and cybersecurity companies Cisco and Eviden to limit the impact of these potential attacks.\n\nWell-known European film festivals, including the Cannes Film Festival opening next week on May 14th, could also pose opportunities for threat actors.\n\nThe effects of the AI-generated content, an emerging threat, were already put on display earlier this week, when hyper realistic fake pictures of singers Katy Perry and Rihanna at the Met Gala went viral, despite neither actually attending the New York's premier fashion event.\n\nMore from Cybernews:\n\nLockBit gang leader exposed in FBI ransomware breakthrough\n\nBiometric gate glitch causes chaos in major UK airports\n\nMediExcel exposes 500K patient documents", "source": {"uri": "cybernews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Cybernews"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Before then though there will be two semi-finals - and for the first time the United Kingdom will be performing.\n\nThe first semi-final takes place on Tuesday, May 7, while the second is held on Thursday, May 9. Only ten countries from each show will progress to the grand final which means 17 representatives will be axed.\n\nAs mentioned this time around there will be some changes to how the semi-finals pan out and the Big Five - which is the UK, France, Germany, Italy, Spain - will all be performing as well to give them a fairer standing in the eyes of the audience. Try WalesOnline Premium for FREE by clicking here for no ads, fun puzzles and brilliant new features.\n\nREAD MORE: Graham Norton says 'it's so perfect' as he reveals identity of Eurovision 2024 spokesperson\n\nLATEST: Eurovision fans say their 'jaws dropped' as Olly Alexander releases UK entry\n\nEvery year the Big Five have received a free pass to the final because of their contribution to the European Broadcasting Union (EBU). The host nation joins the Big Five in progressing to the finals as a courtesy from the contest but this year all six countries will perform in the semi-finals.\n\nIn previous years, only a short clip of their rehearsal performances was shown during the semi-finals. In a historic move for the contest, The Big Five and the host nation will perform regardless of their already qualifying conditions to evenly balance all of the acts in the eyes of the audience.\n\nEbba Adielsson, executive producer of the Eurovision Song Contest 2024 said: \"We think that this change gives the Big Five countries and the host country a fairer playing field in the grand final, as they now have the opportunity to perform 'for real' on stage in the semi-finals.\n\n\"It is also a win for both the audience in the arena and the viewers at home, in that they get to see all the acts competing this year live before the grand final.\" You can keep up to date with the latest TV and showbiz news by signing up to the newsletter here.", "source": {"uri":
