{"uri": "8117652940", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:29:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:29:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:28:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/music-news/eurovision-song-contest-2024-preview-boycott-israel-gaza-1235892260/", "title": "Eurovision 2024: What to Know Ahead of the Beloved But Controversial Song Contest", "body": "Taylor Swift's Feud With Scooter Braun to Be Featured in New Season of 'vs' on Discovery+ U.K., Max\n\nThe world's largest live music contest is back. The Eurovision Song Contest, a springboard to fame for some of the biggest acts in the world - legendary Swedish band ABBA, or more recently, Italian glam rock band M\u00e5neskin, for example - will return to screens on Saturday, May 11, to do what it does best: providing the most eccentric performances Europe has to offer.\n\nFrom perfectly garish outfits and heartfelt ballads to synchronized dance numbers and heavy metal guitar solos, the event is set to feature the wackiest of the continent's music scene as thousands of fans flock to the Malm\u00f6 Arena.\n\nSweden became host after its homegrown star Loreen triumphed last year in Liverpool, England.\n\nBut this year's Contest - like in 2023, where Ukraine was forced to pass hosting privileges onto the U.K. - is one backdropped by war. However, the threat of mass boycott has not, to the outrage of some, convinced organizers to deviate from regular programming.\n\nHere's what you need to know about Eurovision 2024 ahead of its second semi-final and the Grand Final on the weekend.\n\nIsrael's participation this year has caused widespread controversy, and even some of Eurovision's most loyal fans have vowed to boycott the event. The war in Gaza, which has killed over 30,000 men, women, and children in the territory, has prompted outrage. The conflict escalated in October when Hamas militants launched an attack and murdered 1,200 people at an Israeli music festival. The retaliation from Israel has involved a near-constant barrage of airstrikes on Gaza since the Hamas incursion.\n\nBut Eurovision organizers are standing firm on Israel's inclusion in the event. The European Broadcasting Union (EBU) has also warned viewers not to direct abuse at the Israeli entrant this year, 20-year-old Eden Golan. \"We would like to stress that any decisions regarding participation are the responsibility of the EBU's governing bodies, not the individual artists,\" the EBU said. \"We are firmly against any form of abuse or harassment directed at participants, online or offline, and are committed to fostering a safe, respectful and inclusive environment.\"\n\nIt added that there should be a \"constructive dialogue and support\" for those competing, underlining the Contest's mission to be \"United By Music.\"\n\nIsraeli President Isaac Herzog ordered \"necessary adjustments\" to Golan's initial entry to ensure his country could compete. The lyrics to \"October Rain\" seemingly referenced the Hamas attack. Golan will now perform a romantic ballad called \"Hurricane.\"\n\nBut other performers are already making a political stance. The EBU was forced to release a statement saying that they \"regret\" the opening act from former Swedish Eurovision contestant Eric Saade on Tuesday night. Saade, who is not competing in the Contest, had the keffiyeh symbol, commonly used by those in support of Palestine, on his arm as he performed his 2011 entry \"Popular.\"\n\nA spokeswoman for the EBU said: \"The Eurovision Song Contest is a live TV show. All performers are made aware of the rules of the contest, and we regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.\"\n\nSaade took to Instagram to question if freedom is \"controversial\" and why people keep asking if it is \"political.\"\n\nAhead of the shows, fans have been warned not to bring Palestinian flags, symbols, or bags as \"vigorous security checks\" will take place.\n\nEagle-eyed TV fans may recognize Olly Alexander from Channel 4's award-winning drama It's A Sin. But he was also the frontman of British pop band Years & Years before he began performing under his own name. He is an interesting choice as Britain's entrant this year -- a far bigger name than previous contestants were before their big Eurovision break, like Sam Ryder or Mae Muller, who are good examples of the not-quite-yet-established musicians the U.K. normally opts for.\n\nThe singer will be performing his dance track \"Dizzy,\" but has had to wade through myriad criticism to retain his spot in the final.\n\nMore than 450 queer artists, individuals and organizations called on him to not perform amid the conflict in Gaza.\n\nAlexander soon shared a statement on Twitter, formerly X, to say: \"I wholeheartedly support action being taken to demand an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza, the return of all hostages, and the safety and security of all civilians in Palestine and Israel.\"\n\nHe added: \"It is my current belief that removing myself from the contest wouldn't bring us any closer to our shared goal. Instead, I've been speaking with some of the other EV contestants and we've decided that by taking part we can use our platform to come together and call for peace.\"\n\nThe British star has separately added, in a glimpse of the BBC documentary Olly Alexander's Road to Eurovision '24, that the criticism has been \"extreme.\"\n\n\"I understand where that sentiment is coming from but I think it's not correct,\" he said. \"It's an incredibly complicated political situation, one that I'm not qualified to speak on. The backdrop to this is actual immense suffering. It's a humanitarian crisis, a war. It just so happens there's a song contest going on at the same time that I'm a part of.\"\n\nBy now, there is normally a clear star that the bookies are tipping to be the country to beat. But while there is some buzz around a few contestants, no one performance is standing out quite yet.\n\nCroatia's entrant, an act called Baby Lasagna, has garnered some attention in the run-up thanks to the song title \"Rim Tim Tagi Dim.\" The bleach-blond frontman has said the title does not translate as anything but is just a catchy riff, yet a serious theme about the economic migration of young Croatians lies beneath the performance.\n\nSwitzerland's act is also attracting some bets. \"The Code,\" by non-binary performer Nemo, tells the story of their gender identity. Italy's TikTok-famous contestant Angelina Mango could follow in the footsteps of M\u00e5neskin with her song \"La Noia.\"\n\nEurovision features an intricate voting system. The final leaderboard is determined by a combination of votes cast by viewers and a jury of music professionals in each participating country. Audiences at home can phone in to cast their vote and, notably, they cannot vote for their own country.\n\nIn a recent change, those watching in the rest of the world can now cast their vote via app or website in the days before the semi-finals and final. But, crucially, their collective vote holds the weight of only one additional country. Last year, Sweden's winner earned 583 points, ahead of Finland with 526 points. Israel placed third with 362 points.\n\nThe Eurovision audience is growing, and it's becoming a staple in the music calendar all over the globe.\n\nLast year, more than 160 million people watched the contest, according to the organizers. Iceland, Finland, Norway, and victor Sweden all had more than 80 percent of their TV-viewing populations tuned in. Media coverage of the event has grown 20 percent year-on-year, the EBU also said, with over 150,000 articles written about the Eurovision Song Contest in May 2023 alone.\n\nEven though only 37 countries took part last year, people from 144 different countries had their say and voted for the winner.\n\nIn the U.S., the Eurovision Song Contest will only be streaming on Peacock. Participating countries will be airing the event on their public broadcasting networks, such as the U.K.'s BBC.\n\nIn Sweden, the Eurovision Grand Final kicks off at 9 p.m. local time, which is 8 p.m. in London. L.A. viewers can watch at 12 p.m. on Saturday, and those in New York from 3 p.m.", "source": {"uri": "hollywoodreporter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hollywood Reporter"}, "authors": {"uri": "8117277850", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:35:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:35:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:34:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/tv/27793922/eurovision-2024-betting-odds-favourite-country-act-win-final/", "title": "This is who is being predicted to scoop the Eurovision 2024 crown", "body": "IT'S THAT time of year again when Eurovision fever is well and truly upon us.\n\nBut there can only be one winner, and there is already one country that is being tipped to scoop the crown.\n\nAccording to Ladbrokes betting shop, it will be Croatia's Baby Lasagna who will be named the champion of Eurovision with even-money odds.\n\nTheir track is called Rim Tim Tagi Dim and has already gone down a treat with fans online.\n\nAlex Apati of Ladbrokes said: \"Croatia already beginning to pull away as clear favourites to win in Sweden.\"\n\nFlying the flag for Switzerland is Nemo with their song The Code.\n\nThe singer is no stranger to a TV competition, finishing fifth in the second season of The Masked Singer Switzerland.\n\nIn their music, Nemo deals with personal themes such as gender identity, mental health and finding your place in this world.\n\nAs one of Eurovision's 'big five' Italy won an automatic place in the final.\n\nRepresenting them is rising star Angelina Mango with her song La Noia.\n\nHer music is a mix that brings together different influences, including Italian and American rap, R&B and instrumental music.\n\nUkraine is hoping for another win with aloyna aloyna & Jerry Heil's song, Teresa & Maria.\n\nThe country won Eurovision in 2022, but were unable to host the contest the following year due to the ongoing conflict.\n\nBut while the singer teamed up with Dua Lipa's producer for the track, it appears his efforts might not be enough to take the top spot.\n\nYears and Years frontman Olly is the UK's most high-profile Eurovision entry in more than a decade.\n\nHe's already secured a place in the final at Malmo Arena as one the show's 'five big countries'.\n\nSadly, the odds so far aren't in Olly's favour and the UK are 5/1 to finish last, and 12/1 to score 'nil-point'.\n\nAlex Apati of Ladbrokes said: \"It looks like it'll be yet another disappointing Eurovision year for the UK, with Olly Alexander now just 12/1 for a nil point night.\"\n\nThe winner will be announced in the Eurovision final on May 11, 2024.\n\nThe main rules that artists have to follow to be eligible to compete in Eurovision are:\n\nIn the grand finale, each country can vote for their favourite along with a jury of five industry professionals and the viewers.\n\nPoints are given on a scale of 1 -8, 10 or 12 points, but the jury cannot vote for their own country.\n\nViewers can vote through SMS, telephone or on the official Eurovision app.\n\nIf you weren't able to get a ticket to the live show in Sweden, never fear, there are plenty of {"uri": "8117363074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:26:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:26:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:26:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/eurovision-winners-countries-highest-scoring-122420971.html", "title": "Which countries have won Eurovision the most times?", "body": "The Eurovision Song Contest 2024 is under way in Malmo, Sweden, with fans excitedly preparing for this weekend's grand final.\n\nThe UK has had a tough time in the competition in recent years, with its last win 27 years ago. Hopes were briefly raised in 2022 with Sam Ryder and he ended up finishing second. But the golden streak ended last year, when Mae Muller finished 25 out of 26.\n\nHowever, fans reckon things could be different this year, with Olly Alexander flying the flag for the UK.\n\nSo how many times exactly has the UK won? And which countries tend to do the best? We have a look at some Eurovision's facts and figures.\n\nThink of Eurovision successes, and two countries come to mind - Ireland and Sweden. Both have been hugely successful at the contest and they have racked up an impressive seven victories each. All eyes will be on both at the final, as each attempts to edge past the other and become most successful Eurovision country of all time.\n\nWhile the UK hasn't seen a win in a while, it has won five times before. This is on a par with Luxembourg, France and the Netherlands, making the UK one of the sixth most successful Eurovision countries.\n\nWhile the Eurovision performances serve up all the sequins, glitter and pop anyone could want, it's the scoring that has many viewers gripped. Who will get the most? Which countries will back each other? And will anyone get the dreaded \"nul points\" on the night?\n\nStatistics show that Sweden has racked up the most points over the years, a whopping 6471. But the UK isn't far behind, as its in third place behind Italy (4859), with 4571 points over the years. This means the UK ranks third out of the 52 nations for the highest total winning points in Eurovision history.\n\nThe UK romped to victory for the first time in 1967, with Sandie Shaw and her song Puppet On A String. Two years later Lulu clinched the trophy with Boom Bang-a-Bang, but there was then a lull until 1976 when Brotherhood Of Man triumphed with Save Your Kisses For Me.\n\nIn 1981, winners Bucks Fizz provided one of Eurovision's standout moments with their skirt-rip move during Making Your Mind Up, which has remained one of the most memorable moments of the contest for the UK.\n\nOur last ever winner was in 1997, when Katrina & The Waves won with Love Shine A Light.\n\nOf the UK winners, Shaw, Brotherhood Of Man and Bucks Fizz all had number ones with their Eurovision tracks. Lulu's had a number two and Love Shine A Light was number three.\n\nThe Eurovision Song Contest started in the 1950s and although it has been held 64 times, so far there have been 67 winners because one year saw a four-way tie.\n\nBut, interestingly, while more than 50 countries have participated in the competition over the years, the majority of the wins come from the same few.\n\nStatistics show that close to 50% of Eurovision victories come from the top few countries - Sweden, Ireland, the UK, France, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. They are responsible for 48% of wins.\n\nPercentages may not add up to 100%, as they are rounded to the nearest percent.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo for Ireland with \"Together\" in Lisbon, Portugal, four years ago, where he came 16th.\n\nBambie has a chance to take Ireland to the win, which the country has not achieved since 1996 with Eimear Quinn's \"The Voice.\"\n\nDuring their first Eurovision performance, Bambie's male dancers looked almost devil-like with blue paint, highly exaggerated ears and fake teeth.\n\nTowards the end of the song, they also revealed the trans flag on their costume ahead of fire appearing to be set off around the stage.\n\nElsewhere on the night, Years and Years singer Olly Alexander delivered his first Eurovision performance, which featured upside-down locker room staging.\n\nCameras were rotated to give a spinning feel to Alexander and the dancers as the singer wore a white singlet, red trousers, and boots, which looked a little distressed at the Malmo Arena in Sweden.\n\nThe rendition of \"Dizzy\" was energetic, and it is the first time the UK, which is already through to the finals, has performed in a semi-final.\n\n33-year-old Alexander has come under intense pressure to boycott the competition in recent months due to Israel's involvement, which many Eurovision fans have objected to due to the country's ongoing war on Gaza.\n\nAlexander said in a recent interview that, while he believes his goals are the same as Queers for Palestine - \"a ceasefire, returning the hostages, the safety and security of all people in Gaza. All the Palestinians and the people in Israel\" - his participation or not in Eurovision \"isn't going to make a difference to those things, so that's why I'm still doing it\".\n\nOrganisers behind the Eurovision Song Contest have consistently rejected calls to ban Israel from competing amid its war on Gaza.\n\nWidespread protests are expected in Sweden on the night of the grand final, which is scheduled to take place on Saturday 11 May.\n\nHosting duties will be performed live from the Malm\u00f6 Arena by Swedish-American actor Malin \u00c5kerman and Eurovision veteran Petra Mede.", {"uri": "2024-05-349022073", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:48:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:48:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:39:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/culture/music/eurovision-2024-results-acts-final-3045972", "title": "Eurovision 2024 results: All the acts who qualified from semi-final 1", "body": "Following Loreen's triumphant victory in 2023 with her soul-stirring anthem, \"Tattoo\", excitement is building in the Swedish city with the announcement of the next ten finalists tomorrow after the last of the semi-finals.\n\nFive nations - known as the \"Big 5\" - including the UK, Italy, France, Spain, and Germany, will perform in the semi-final rounds but will receive automatic qualification. Meanwhile, the rest of the performers from across Europe will be subject to a vote as they hope they can make their way through the semi-finals and into the illustrious grand final.\n\nWith roots tracing back to its inception in 1956, Eurovision has evolved into an iconic celebration of music and cultural diversity, captivating audiences worldwide.\n\nBut Eurovision is never far from controversy, with the inclusion of Israel being met with criticism due to its continued war in Gaza, leading to petitions calling for the country's removal. Event organisers will hope the boycott of the competition will not affect viewing figures.\n\nEurovision enthusiasts who are not boycotting the show can watch the grand final on 11 May, which will be broadcast live on BBC One at 8pm, and is accompanied by streaming options on BBC iPlayer, BBC Radio 2, and BBC Sounds.\n\nWho gets automatic qualification?\n\nThis year marks a significant shift as the Big Five, along with host nation Sweden, will grace the semi-final stage for the first time. In Tuesday's semi-final, the UK, Germany, and Sweden showcased their talents alongside other contestants - but will still receive automatic qualification like in previous years.\n\nThe concept of the Big Five originated in 2000 following a rule change that allowed countries to secure a direct spot in the grand final as they contributed the most money to the competition. Initially the UK, Spain, France, and Germany were the only nations who bought a ticket to the show, but the group expanded in 2011 with the inclusion of Italy.\n\nUK - Olly Alexander - 'Dizzy'\n\nThe 33-year-old performer is gearing up to grace the stage with his song \"Dizzy\".\n\nIn the semi-final, Olly is seen captivating the audience with his dynamic dance moves and soulful vocals within a striking setting -- a sprawling room adorned with weathered tiles and shower heads.\n\nBefore his selection for Eurovision, Olly had already left a mark on the global music scene as the frontman of the band Years & Years, boasting three successful albums, two of which soared to the coveted number one spot on the UK album chart.\n\nTypically (except for 2022), the UK hover near the bottom of the leaderboard in Eurovision - and according to the bookies, this year will be no different, where he is ranked as an 81/1 outsider.\n\nSweden - Marcus & Martinus - 'Unforgettable'\n\nSweden stands as one of the most triumphant nations in the Eurovision Song Contest, boasting a remarkable tally of seven victories.\n\nThe Swedish act for this year's Eurovision, Marcus & Martinus, who have previously expressed their aspiration to win over ABBA enthusiasts in the competition - as the event commemorates the 50th anniversary of the iconic pop group's triumph in the competition.\n\nThe set of twins debut their performance of \"Unforgettable\" during Tuesday's semi-final, after having already secured a spot in Saturday's final, courtesy of Sweden hosting this year's event after winning the 2023 competition in Liverpool.\n\nSpain - Nebulossa - 'Zorra'\n\nNebulossa is a Spanish electropop duo hailing from Ondara - a Spanish village near Benidorm.\n\nHowever, the selection of their song, \"Zorra\", has sparked controversy within Spanish society. \"Zorra,\" which translates to \"vixen\" in English, carries connotations akin to derogatory terms like \"bitch\", and the decision to feature a song with such loaded language has prompted intense debate.\n\nWhile some view \"Zorra\" as a bold anthem for Spain's feminist movement -- a reclaiming of a term historically used to demean women -- others are deeply troubled by its use in a national competition. The song's portrayal of female empowerment clashes with the discomfort surrounding its potentially offensive nature.\n\nBut in typical Eurovision style, their controversial song was chosen at the Benidorm Fest 2024, granting them the honour of representing Spain in the Eurovision Song Contest 2024.\n\nFrance - Slimane - 'Mon Amour'\n\nFrance's Eurovision entry, \"\u00c9videmment\" by La Zarra, landed them in the 16th spot with 104 points way back in 2023. But this year, they are poised for a stronger showing with Slimane Nebchi - performing \"Mon Amour\" - who is one of the bookies' favourites to win Eurovision.\n\nFollowing his triumph on The Voice - France edition - in 2016, Slimane's sold two million albums and achieved two billion worldwide streams, and accumulated a staggering seven million social media followers.\n\nFrance T\u00e9l\u00e9visions handpicked Slimane internally to represent France at Eurovision 2024, with Silmane hoping to win over European audiences and secure France a top spot in the competition.\n\nGermany - Isaak Guderian - 'Always on The Run'\n\nGermany is showcasing \"Always on the Run\" by Isaak Guderian.\n\nGuderian, commonly known as Isaak, began his musical journey as a street musician, before he appeared on the TV talent show X Factor, delivering a memorable rendition of the Oasis hit \"Wonderwall\".\n\nAlthough he failed to impress and win the X Factor, he did not look back in anger, becoming a rock'n'roll star when he emerged victorious in Show Your Talent. He will now hope to impress Europe's Eurovision audience and become the first German winner of the competition since 2010.\n\nItaly - Angelina Mango - 'La Noia'\n\nWith an impressive track record boasting four platinum records, two gold records, and a sold-out tour, Angelina Mango emerged as one of Italy's standout stars of 2023.\n\nAt just 23 years old, she draws from a diverse range of influences including Italian and American rap, R&B, and instrumental music.\n\nMango's crowning achievement came with her victory at the prestigious Festival di Sanremo, which earns Italians the esteemed opportunity to represent Italy at Eurovision 2024 -- an opportunity she graciously accepted with her song \"La Noia\".\n\nNotably, Mango holds the distinction of being Italy's first female Eurovision representative since 2016 and the first female solo act to win Festival di Sanremo since 2014, symbolising an important milestone for female musicians in Italy.\n\nIolanda Costa, who hails from the coast town of Figueira da Foz, has made her mark on the Portuguese music scene, performing at the Festival da Can\u00e7\u00e3o with her entry \"Mar no fim\".\n\nThe recognition from her performance led to the release of her debut EP, Cura, in 2023, with the pinnacle of Costa's career climaxing in 2024 when she clinched victory at Festival da Can\u00e7\u00e3o with her emotive anthem \"Grito\" (Scream).\n\nGarnering unanimous acclaim from the juries and securing a commendable second place in the televote, Costa was selected to represent Portugal at Eurovision.\n\nSlovenia - Raiven - 'Veronika'\n\nRaiven burst onto the electro-pop scene in 2014, marking her debut in the vibrant musical landscape.\n\nHowever, it was her presence in Slovenia's esteemed national selection, EMA, that truly catapulted her into the spotlight of her country's music scene where she released \"\u010crno Bel, Za\u017earim\" and \"KAOS\".\n\nIn 2021, Raiven achieved a significant milestone by clinching victory at Slovenia's renowned music festival, Popevka, with her captivating song \"Volkovi\".\n\nUkraine - Alyona Alyona & Jerry Heil - 'Teresa & Maria'\n\nAlyona Alyona and Jerry Heil, the dynamic duo representing Ukraine in this year's Eurovision, made a bold pledge that has resonated deeply with the European audience: if they emerge victorious in the contest, they will sell the coveted trophy to aid in the reconstruction of bombed schools in Ukraine.\n\nHailed as \"Ukraine's most unlikely rap star\" in Vogue, Alyona has been lauded by Ukrainian media as \"the new rap star of Ukraine\" and \"the sensation of Ukrainian rap\".\n\nDrawing comparisons to the renowned Azealia Banks, Alyona Alyona has teamed up with Yana Oleksandrivna Shemaieva - otherwise known by her stage name Jerry Heil.\n\nBorn on 21 October, 1995, in Vasylkiv, a city adjacent to Kyiv, Heil launched a YouTube channel in 2012, sharing vlogs and musical covers. With over 34.9 million views and 395,000 subscribers on her YouTube channel, she will be hoping her global reach will help reach Eurovision voters and gain another victory for Ukraine.\n\nFinland - Windows95man - 'No Rules!'\n\nTeemu Keisteri - also known by his captivating stage persona Windows95man - is a Finnish visual artist and DJ.\n\nAs a DJ, Teemu's electrifying sets transport audiences back to the golden era of Eurodance and 90s techno,\n\nTeemu's latest triumph came with his participation in UMK 2024, Finland's national selection for Eurovision, where he teamed up with singer Henri Piispanen to deliver the electrifying anthem \"No Rules!\".\n\nAs Finland's representative in Eurovision, Teemu and Henri are poised to showcase their unique blend of techno and vocals to captivate Eurovision's audiences worldwide, in what will be an unforgettable entry.\n\nCyprus - Silia Kapsis - 'Liar'\n\nVasiliki Silia Kapsis, originally from Australia, is a Cypriot singer who unveiled her debut song, \"Who Am I?\", in 2022 - a poignant composition that she both wrote and composed at the age of 12.\n\nNow, Vasiliki embarks on a new chapter in her career as she represents Cyprus in the Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nWith her captivating presence and emotive performance, she is set to enchant audiences with her song \"Liar\".\n\nCroatia - Baby Lasagna - 'Rim Tim Tagi Dim'\n\nThe bookies' favourite at 2/1, Baby Lasagna - also known by Puri\u0161i\u0107 - is Croatia's selection for the Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nHis initial success in Croatia came from an impressive debut at number 24 on the HR Top 40 chart, marking Puri\u0161i\u0107's first chart entry in Croatia.\n\nFollowing this success, he released his Eurovision entry \"Rim Tim Tagi Dim\". Which soared to number one on the charts and captured the hearts of audiences nationwide.\n\nIreland - Bambie Thug - 'Doomsday Blue'\n\nHailing from Cork in Ireland, Bambie Thug is reshaping the musical landscape by blending the realms of pop, rock, electronic music and horror film, to create the unique sound she calls \"Ouija-pop\".\n\nHistorically, Eurovision thrives with performances by those who indulge in the weird and wonderful -- and Bambie Thug's song is certainly weird - so the bookies have ranked her as an outside favourite.\n\nThis is Ireland's first time back at the Eurovision finals after a series of acts failed to grab the attention of audiences, so Bambie Thug will be aiming to secure Ireland's first win since 1996.\n\nLuxembourg - TALI - 'Fighter'\n\nTali Golergant - known simply as Tali - is an artist born in Israel and now based in Luxembourg.\n\nIn December 2023, Tali emerged as one of the eight finalists in the prestigious Luxembourg Song Contest.\n\nTali's musical style is a fusion of pop, indie, and R&B, showcasing her diverse influences which include the likes of Lizzy McAlpine, Sara Bareilles, and Lady Gaga, and will represent Luxembourg in the Eurovision Song Contest 2024 with her song anthem \"Fighter\".\n\nWhen is the second semi-final?\n\nOn Thursday 9 May, viewers can tune in to the second Eurovision semi-final, which will be broadcast live on the BBC starting at 8pm. believed to be the world's most listened to independent Eurovision podcast.\n\nBoth massive Eurovision fans, the brothers wanted to take their passion for pop music to the iconic annual competition and turned to the University of Sunderland for help.\n\nCallum and James successfully secured \u00a32,500 from the University's Futures Fund Scholarship - available for current students and recent graduates to develop their careers - and are now set to see their dreams come true by taking their Eurovision podcast to the heart of the action.\n\nCallum said: \"Being in Malm\u00f6 means I have the chance to work closely with artists, songwriters, members of international broadcasting delegations and other industry professionals to help cement myself as a trusted member of the worlds of journalism and Eurovision.\n\n\"When I graduate this summer, having this trip to Sweden on my CV as a real-world example of working as a journalist will be a huge selling point as I take my first steps into my career.\"\n\nThe brothers produce the daily Euro Trip podcast each year in the weeks leading up to the contest.\n\nCallum said: \"Each episode was listened to by more than 1,000 people. During Eurovision week last year, we made daily episodes which saw our episode listenership more than double.\"\n\nSince graduating in 2022, James now works as a freelance audio producer for BBC Sport, Radio Newcastle and Hits Radio North East, but he is still committed to working alongside his brother on their Eurovision podcast.\n\nHe said: \"The Euro Trip is the world's leading independent Eurovision podcast.\n\n\"The podcast was something I started doing alongside my studies, using the skills I was learning on my course and applying them to the real world.\n\n\"The podcast is something I am hugely proud of and it stands front and centre on my CV.\n\n\"Callum and I have become a trusted name within the Eurovision media space, often appearing on outlets such as BBC News as experts on the contest.\"\n\nBoth brothers credit working on the University's student radio station, Spark, as the place they were able to hone their broadcasting skills.\n\nAlistair Robinson, Senior Lecturer in Journalism and Public Relations at the University of Sunderland, backed the brothers' funding application.\n\nHe said: \"I'm delighted we've been able to help Callum and James with this opportunity. They are Eurovision experts and have developed an extraordinary specialism in Eurovision reporting.\n\n\"I've taught Callum for three years now and he has produced consistently excellent work, on a range of subjects, not just pop music or Eurovision. {"uri": "8114518612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "22:22:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T22:22:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T22:21:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-07/why-is-australia-competing-in-eurovision-song-contest/103801224", "title": "Why is Australia in Eurovision?", "body": "The Eurovision Song Contest is back for another year and, once again, an Australian act will be taking to the stage.\n\nIt may seem a bit weird Australia is a competitor in a contest that starts with \"Euro\" given we're so far away from the continent.\n\nBut we've been competing for years now.\n\nIn short, because Australian broadcaster SBS has been such a big supporter of the event.\n\nIt's been covering the contest since 1983 - a whopping four decades - but Australian acts have only been taking the stage for 10 years.\n\nIt kicked off in 2014, when iconic Australian singer Jessica Mauboy was invited to be a guest singer during the interval.\n\nThe following year, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) invited Australia to compete as a wildcard entry.\n\nThis was back during the contest's 60th birthday and was all about \"building bridges\".\n\nThat year, we sent Guy Sebastian to compete and he came in fifth place.\n\nAfter this success, the SBS struck a deal with the EBU for Australia to stay on the bill until 2023.\n\nThere was a question mark about Australia's future in the contest after Eurovision 2023, but in early December it was confirmed that Australia would take part this year.\n\nBut Australia isn't the only non-European country in the contest, with nations like Ukraine and Armenia also competing.\n\nThis year, there are 37 Eurovision Song Contest participating countries:\n\nIsrael agreed to modify the lyrics of its original song, which was called October Rain and is now titled Hurricane.\n\nThe EBU said the original lyrics referenced the Hamas attacks on an Israeli music festival on October 7, which triggered Israel's war in Gaza.\n\nThis year, Israel will be represented by Eden Golan, who did not write the song.\n\nShe was selected to be Israel's contestant after winning a televised singing contest.\n\nGolan didn't attend the opening ceremony on Sunday due to Holocaust Memorial Day in Israel, Swedish broadcaster SVT said.\n\nBut she spoke to Reuters in an interview on Monday.\n\n\"I come here to show my voice, to share my love, my gift from God and to hopefully make people feel something and leave a mark in their souls and to unite by music,\" she said.\n\nBecause its broadcaster is a member of the EBU, so it has a place in the competition like Australia.\n\nExcept while Australia is only relatively new to the competition, Israel has been competing in Eurovision for more than 50 years.\n\n\"Israel made its debut in the Eurovision Song Contest in 1973 as the first non-European country granted permission to participate in the event,\" the Eurovision website says.\n\n\"The EBU allowed Israel to participate since the country's broadcaster was already one of its members.\"\n\nAs this year's contest approaches, there are growing calls from some critics to ban Israel from the competition, in the same way Russia was banned in 2022.\n\nThe EBU told international news syndicate Agence France-Presse it decided late last year that Israel could participate.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a non-political music event and a competition between public service broadcasters who are members of the EBU,\" the union's director-general, Noel Curran, said.\n\n\"It is not a contest between governments.\"\n\nMr Curran said in the case of Russia, it was the Russian broadcasters themselves who were suspended from the EBU \"due to their persistent breaches of membership obligations and the violation of public service values\".\n\nHowever, this hasn't stopped the calls for Israel to be banned, with protests expected at the event.\n\nGolan was asked how she felt about the possibility of demonstrations.\n\n\"It's up to the people what to do,\" she said.\n\n\"They have the right to speak their voice, but I'm focusing on my part, which is giving the best performance, and on the good, on the good vibes, the good people.\"\n\nMalm\u00f6 is bracing for possible unrest during the week, although police have said there have been no concrete threats against the event.\n\nThe first semifinal will be held in Sweden on Tuesday night but, because of the time difference, it'll be Wednesday morning in Australia.\n\nSo you can watch it on free-to-air television or SBS On Demand.\n\nWe'll also be live blogging the finals, so if you're planning an early-morning viewing party, we'll be on hand to keep you company.", {"uri": "8117832173", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:38:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:38:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:38:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-13395157/eurovision-readies-bambi-thug-baby-lasagna-olly-alexander-abba.html", "title": "The Eurovision performers ready to impress at the music contest", "body": "There's only a few days left until performers representing 26 countries from across Europe and beyond take to the stage at the final of the 68th Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nOn Tuesday, the annual music competition kicked off with its first of two semi finals in the Swedish city of Malmo - with ten of the 15 acts performing voted through to Saturday's finale by viewers.\n\nThe second semi final on Thursday will further narrow the original field of 37 competing nations to 26 for the highly anticipated final, where frontrunners include Croatia's Baby Lasagna and Switzerland's Nemo.\n\nIreland's entry also left viewers predicting the country could win the contest after non-binary artist Bambie Thug, 31, from County Cork, delivered a sensational performance of their song Doomsday Blue for the crowd on Tuesday.\n\nHere, FEMAIL reveals all about the contestants still competing in one of the world's most flamboyant events as the over-the-top music competition marks 50 years since ABBA's win with Waterloo...\n\nUnited Kingdom\n\nOlly Alexander\n\nOlly Alexander representing Britain with the song 'Dizzy' performs during the first semi final of the 68th Eurovision Song Contest\n\nChart-topping pop star Olly Alexander will be flying the flag for Britain in this year's Eurovision Song Contest this weekend - despite describing himself as 'ambivalent' about the Union Jack.\n\nHe is hoping to become the UK's first Eurovision winner since Katrina and the Waves in 1997 after overcoming his ordeal of being bullied at school to find fame and success as both a singer and an actor.\n\nAlexander, 33, from Harrogate in North Yorkshire, released two albums which got to number one with his band Years & Years and also won acclaim for his performance in Channel 4 drama It's A Sin.\n\nBut there has been controversy in the build-up to the final - after Alexander attracted attention with remarks made about Israel as well as his latest comments about the Union Jack.\n\nHis dance-infused Eurovision entry Dizzy is not among the bookies' favourites to triumph this Saturday.\n\nMeanwhile, the star has told of being bullied as a youngster, including homophobic taunts, but found strength from taking up performing.\n\nHe said: 'At school I was picked on and I just felt like something was wrong with me - like I was just different from other people in a way that was really bad.\n\n'People would make fun of me and call me gay even before I had any idea of my sexuality. But music and performing and drama - like, the weirder you were, the more unique you were. It kind of worked in your favour.\n\nAlexander, seen here in the dress rehearsal for the first semi final in Malmo, previously reached number one once in the UK singles chart and twice in the albums chart\n\nAlexander, left, starred in Channel 4 drama It's A Sin, alongside Nathaniel Hall, right\n\nSir Elton John and Olly Alexander performed the Pet Shop Boys song It's A Sin at the 2021 BRIT Awards at the O2 Arena in London\n\n'If you stood out, people remembered you, and I'm actually really good at something - I have this secret power, so I really just followed that feeling and I haven't stopped.'\n\nHis outspoken comments have also attracted attention away from his performances on stage and screen.\n\nHe described himself as 'ambivalent' about the Union Jack, saying it can feel 'divisive' and 'nationalist'. He said: 'I hope to, like, reclaim the Union Jack, in a positive way.\n\nRead More Graham Norton thinks 'bona fide pop star' Olly Alexander can win Eurovision for the UK - after last year's entry Mae Muller finished second from last\n\n'When I'm going to be out there waving my flag at the parade, it's for all the good things that have come from growing up in the UK and being British.'\n\nAlexander's political views previously came under the spotlight after it emerged he had signed a letter that branded Israel an 'apartheid regime' and condemning 'Zionist propaganda'.\n\nIn March, he declined calls from campaigners that he should boycott the contest in protest at Israel taking part amid the ongoing bombardment of Gaza.\n\nHe previously he broke down during an interview when asked about how activists had put pressure on him to boycott the show.\n\nHe told the Times, when asked about looking downcast during a pre-Eurovision party in London: 'Yes, I struggled that day. I was holed up in a room trying not to have a breakdown.\n\n'Normally, you get on stage and turn it on, but I felt really unable to do that.\n\n'It was tough - I just could not get it together and then I felt ashamed of myself and embarrassed.\n\n'Obviously there are a lot of things I wish were different and this is so much bigger than me and Eurovision, it really is.\n\nThis year's competition is taking place in Malmo after Swedish singer Loreen's song Tattoo won the contest last year\n\n'Obviously, I wish there wasn't a war or this insane humanitarian crisis. I wish for peace and I have found this experience, at times, extremely - I've just felt really sad and distressed.\n\n'But I still believe it's a good thing when people come together for entertainment - that's why I wanted to do Eurovision.'\n\nBorn in North Yorkshire, Alexander went to school in Coleford, Gloucestershire, and then in Monmouth, in Monmouthshire, Wales.\n\nHe studied performing arts at the Hereford College of Arts but dropped out to pursue an acting career, with early parts in films such as Summerhill and Bright Star.\n\nIreland\n\nBambie Thug\n\nBambie Thug representing Ireland performs on stage during the first semi final of the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest, in Malmo, Sweden\n\nBambie Thug won a place in Saturday's final with a mesmerising execution of their song Doomsday Blue at the semi final on Tuesday in Malmo, Sweden.\n\nThe Cork-born singer, 31, who uses the pronouns they/them, has a chance to take Ireland to victory, which the country has not achieved since 1996 with Eimear Quinn's The Voice.\n\nRead More Eurovision Song Contest 2024: Iconic British actress is announced as the UK jury spokesperson\n\nThe artist, whose black costume was removed during the performance to reveal a second outfit in the colours of the trans flag, said that they were completely 'disassociated' and having an 'out of body experience' after making Saturday's final.\n\nHowever, Bambie Thug criticised the organisers of the competition for asking them to alter a pro-Palestinian message.\n\nThe singer told a press conference in Malmo they were forced to change their body paint in Ogham script - an early Medieval alphabet - which translated to ceasefire and freedom, a nod to the situation in Gaza and amid Israel's inclusion in the competition.\n\n'It was very important for me because I'm pro justice and pro peace,' they said. 'Unfortunately, I had to change those messages today to \"crown the witch\" only (which was an) order from the EBU.'\n\nA spokeswoman for the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) said: 'The writing seen on Bambie Thug's body during dress rehearsals contravened contest rules that are designed to protect the non-political nature of the event.\n\n'After discussions with the Irish delegation, they agreed to change the text for the live show.'\n\nThe body had previously warned that Palestinian flags and symbols would not be allowed in Malmo Arena.\n\nDespite this, former Swedish Eurovision contestant and opening act Eric Saade had a symbol, commonly used by people who want to show they are pro-Palestinian, on his arm.\n\nThe EBU said that it 'regrets' that Saade chose to wear the keffiyeh pattern material and 'chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event'.\n\nCroatia\n\nBaby Lasagna\n\nCroatian singer Marko Purisic, aka Baby Lasagna, representing Croatia with his song 'Rim Tim Tagi Dim' at the first semi final\n\nCroatian singer-songwriter Baby Lasagna's infectious electro number 'Rim Tim Tagi Dim' is the current favourite to win.\n\nHis real name is Marko Puri\u0161i\u0107 and he aims to convey a deeper message about the worries and suffering of the environment within his music.\n\nHis track is about a young Croatian who leaves his home aspiring to become a 'city boy' with better opportunities.\n\nThe singer, from Umag, Croatia, often performs as part of duo Mono Inc. with his younger brother Martin, who is also in the music industry.\n\nPuri\u0161i\u0107 took part in the Croatian selection process for Eurovision with the song that has got him through to the final and it became the first track of his to enter the charts in Croatia.\n\nAccording to Croatia outlet Vecernji List, Puri\u0161i\u0107 got the name Baby Lasagna when he was walking around the supermarket looking for pills to take to cure his headache.\n\nIt suddenly popped into his head and it stuck, despite him not being a fan of the Italian dish. 'If I was named after the food I prefer, then I should have been Baby Pizza,' he said.\n\nSwitzerland\n\nSwitzerland's Nemo (pictured) is one of the favourites to win the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest - but has said that they do not feel 'pressure' of having the momentum to triumph\n\nSwitzerland's Nemo is one of the favourites to win the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest - but has said that they do not feel 'pressure' of having the momentum to triumph.\n\nNemo Mettler from Switzerland's operatic-dance track The Code - which draws on their identity as a non-binary performer, will be performed in the second semi final on Thursday.\n\nRead More How Israel's Eurovision contestant has faced death threats and fears of a terror attack, but declares: 'I'm not worried - but I am prepared'\n\nThe 24-year-old Swiss rapper and singer has been given odds of 3/1, which is just behind Croatia's Baby Lasagna's Rim Tim Tagi Dim on 2/1, according to Coral Bookmakers.\n\nNemo, who uses the pronouns they/them, told journalists on Monday: 'At the moment, I think I don't feel that much pressure if I'm honest. I think I'm really just very excited about everything.\n\n'And I mean, from the first moment I stepped into this I just wanted to create something that really reflects the song on stage and that enhances the song and just have fun with it and create something beautiful that means a lot to me and I think we really managed to do that.'\n\nNemo also said that if they 'knew the recipe' to be a strong contender, then they would make 'a lot of money' out of writing Eurovision songs.\n\nThey added: 'I think all that you can do as an artist in general, like even outside of Eurovision, is just listen to your heart and write about things that really mean something to you.\n\n'And if you write about something that means a lot to you. And it's personal, I think chances are there that people can relate to the feeling and people.\n\n'And I'm super grateful for all the amazing reception and all the love people give me and the song and to see how many people really, truly connect with it has been amazing.'\n\nThey were also part of several competitors who called for a ceasefire in the Gaza strip ahead of Eurovision, but rejected calls to boycott the event over Israel competing.\n\nNemo said that 'it was very important to not just stay silent' and they hope that people are encouraged to 'inform themselves about the whole situation and not just turn a blind eye on it and ignore it or try to push it away'.\n\n'Really, just remember information is power and inform yourself,' they added. 'I think it's important to, to use our platform to raise awareness, in all kinds of... all kinds of things.\n\n'For me, it's a lot of what I talk about... being queer, being non binary and, just honestly, like being myself at Eurovision in hopes that it inspires other people to be themselves as well and feel seen.\n\n'And I think it's amazing that we have lots of queer representation this year, for people to see, I think it's a lot about seeing other people that are like you.\n\n'I mean, it helped me in my life to truly realise who I am, like, through seeing other people that I that I could admire or like that I could look up to. So I think that's a big part of what I'm trying to do here.'\n\nSweden\n\nMarcus & Martinus of Sweden perform the song Unforgettable during the first semi final\n\nMarcus & Martinus are competing in the Eurovision contest on behalf of Sweden with their song 'Unforgettable'.\n\nThe pair are no stranger to fame and have achieved a top 10 hit in Norway aged just nine years old called Dr\u00e5per Vann.\n\nThe twins already have a large following in Scandinavia as they had a second consecutive hit, 'Elektrisk', which was in the Norwegian charts for a whopping 66 weeks.\n\nThis isn't the first time that the duo - who are used to playing at sold out arenas and have more than 1.5 billion streams - have tried to represent their Swedish neighbours at Eurovision.\n\nThey attempted to get onto the show last year but were beaten by Loreen and her song 'Tattoo' which went on to win Eurovision.\n\nThey told the Independent: 'To get through and represent Sweden is amazing, it's a dream come true to represent a country with such a big legacy at Eurovision.'\n\nUkraine\n\nalyona alyona & Jerry Heil of Ukraine perform the song Teresa & Maria during the dress rehearsal for the first semi final\n\nAlyona Alyona, a 32-year-old rapper is collaborating with singer Jerry Heil, 28, for Ukraine in this year's contest.\n\nThe pair will sing a song called Teresa & Maria, which was written to remind people that everyone is capable of achieving great heights and that 'all the divas were born as human beings.'\n\nAlyona - real name Aliona Olehivna Savranenko - is a co-founder of the local major label that Eurovision Song Contest 2022 winners Kalush Orchestra are signed with.\n\nAmong her numerous awards, Alyona also won a Public's Choice Award in 2021 at the Music Moves Europe Talent Awards contest.\n\nJerry and Alyona also created a fundraiser through UNITED24 to rebuild the Velykokostromska School in Dnipro after it was destroyed by Russian missiles in October 2022.\n\nJerry told Euronews that education is crucial to the long-term war effort because it will be the 'children who rebuild the country after us. So we have to provide them with a childhood.'\n\nRussia was excluded from Eurovision in 2022 shortly after they invaded Ukraine.\n\nThe pair spoke to the outlet about why it is important for Russia to remain out of the competition. Alyona said: 'Why should the destroyer of other cultures be given the chance to spread their culture?'\n\nThe duo said that giving the country an international platform like Eurovision would 'undermine' the efforts the West has taken.\n\nFinland\n\nFinland's Windows95man appeared not to wear underwear on stage as he competed in the latest round of the Eurovision Song Contest\n\nFinland's Windows95man appeared not to wear underwear on stage as he competed in the latest round of the Eurovision Song Contest.\n\nThe DJ and artist, whose real name is Teemu Keisteri, used clever camera angles to make it look like he was in the nude at Malmo Arena during Tuesday's semi final.\n\nPerforming his track No Rules!, Windows95man first emerged from an egg-shaped patchwork blue jeans enclosure before later in the song being given short cut-off denims that were attached to ropes that had sparks coming out of them.\n\nEarlier during the rehearsals, Windows95man was clothed in pants that were open at the back.\n\nThe ode to the 1990s also features a Microsoft Windows 95 T-shirt that has previously had to be blurred on TV as it features a brand.\n\nHis singer Henri Piispanen climbed on top of the egg-shape during the start of the act before getting to the end of the stage and delivering powerful vocals which complemented Windows95man shouting 'no rules' at various intervals.\n\nIsrael\n\nMuch focus is expected to be on Israel's Eden Golan (pictured) and her song 'Hurricane' in the second semi final on Thursday\n\nMuch focus is expected to be on Israel's Eden Golan and her song 'Hurricane' in the second semi final on Thursday, with bookmakers placing her among the top 10 to win the competition.\n\nEden Golan, Israel's contender in the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest, hopes to unite people through her music when she performs this week in Malmo, Sweden, she said in an interview.\n\nThe 68th version of the world's biggest song contest takes place as protests occur in many countries against Israel's military campaign in Gaza triggered by Hamas militants' Oct. 7 attack on Israel.\n\nRead More UK's Eurovision star Olly Alexander says he is 'ambivalent' about the Union Jack flag as it can feel 'divisive' and 'nationalist'\n\nGolan, 20, is competing with the song 'Hurricane' which initially went under the name 'October Rain.'\n\n'I come here to show my voice, to share my love, my gift from God and to hopefully make people feel something and leave a mark in their souls and to unite by music,' Golan said on Monday.\n\nIsrael tweaked the song after the European Broadcasting Union, which organises the competition, took issue with verses from the original submission, which appeared to reference the Oct. 7 attack.\n\nThe EBU's decision not to exclude Israel from this year's contest over the war has met protests, and Malmo is bracing for possible unrest during the week although police have said there have been no concrete threats against the event.\n\nAsked how she feels about the possibility of protests in Malmo, Golan said: 'It's up to the people what to do.\n\n'They have the right to speak their voice, but I'm focusing on my part which is giving the best performance, and on the good, on the good vibes, the good people.'\n\nThe competition is hugely popular in Israel, which has won it four times. Bookmakers rank this year's entry in the top 10.\n\n'It's a super important moment for us, especially this year,' Golan said. 'I feel honoured to have the opportunity to be the voice of my country.'\n\nNetherlands\n\nJoost Klein\n\nThe Netherland's contestant Joost Klein poses during a press meeting ahead of the concert at the Nordic Eurovision Party in Stockholm on April 14, 2024\n\nAnother top contender is Joost Klein, 26, of the Netherlands with his playful pop-rap song 'Europapa' which mixes tunes of pop with happy hardcore.\n\nKlein, who lost his parents at a young age, says the song is about an orphan who travels around Europe trying to find himself, as his father taught him to believe in a Europe without borders.\n\nWhen finding out he would represent The Netherlands in 2024, Joost said: 'Taking part in the Eurovision Song Contest is a dream come true.\n\n'I used to watch it together with my parents, glued to the screen, year after year. It's an honour to represent the Netherlands, and I'm committed to giving my all for the best possible outcome.'\n\nIn the Netherlands, Joost regularly tours with his band, playing festivals like Lowlands and Pinkpop.\n\nLast summer, the artist achieved a number one hit in Germany, Switzerland and Austria with Friesenjung, reported the Eurovision website.\n\nThe tune - which is also liked in Italy and Ukraine - has had over 100million streams worldwide and won Best Song in Germany's 1LIVE Krone radio awards.\n\nItaly\n\nAngelina Mango\n\nItalian TikTok star Angelina Mango (pictured), 23, will perform her song 'La Noia' which translates to 'Boredom'\n\nItalian TikTok star Angelina Mango, 23, will perform her song 'La Noia' which translates to 'Boredom'.\n\nThe popular artist, who reportedly likes to address themes relevant to her in her tunes such as anxieties of Gen Z, love and freedom, has four platinum records, two gold records, and a completely sold-out tour.\n\nHer songs are influenced by Italian and American rap, R&B and instrumental music and she's increasingly popular on social media.\n\nThe Italian artist has a musical family, with her mother also said to be a singer and her brother playing the drums in bands.\n\nShe practised dancing for ten years as a child, before joining her brother in a band, when they would perform in clubs around their hometown of Maratea.\n\nLithuania\n\nSilvester Belt\n\nSilvester Belt representing Lithuania performs during the first semi-final of the 68th edition of the Eurovision Song Contest\n\nLithuania's Silvester Belt went down a storm on Tuesday's semi final when he carried out a highly synchronised and mind-bending rendition of his song Luktelk.\n\nFor much of the staging, he was clad in red and black lights as dancers did almost robotic moves beside him.\n\nSilvester - a graduate of the University of Westminster - placed sixth in X Factor Lithuania, reported The Telegraph, and competed in Lithuania's pre-selection competition for Junior Eurovision in 2010.\n\nHis music is often said to be inspired by his personal life experiences, including exploring his sexuality while growing up in a homophobic environment.\n\nHis Eurovision song Luktelk, which when translated means 'wait', is about being stuck between two stages of living and barely existing.\n\nPortugal\n\nIolanda\n\nPortuguese crooner Iolanda (pictured) studied songwriting at BIMM Music Institute in Sussex in the UK, after moving from Lisbon, reported the Eurovision website\n\nPortuguese crooner Iolanda studied songwriting at BIMM Music Institute in Sussex in the UK, after moving from Lisbon, reported the Eurovision website.\n\nThe singer-songwriter, who first started writing tunes when she was just 14, released her debut EP 'Cura' in March 2023.\n\nShe is a former contestant on The Voice Portugal and her Eurovision song 'Grito' translates to shout - despite it being a soft ballad.\n\nFrance\n\nSlimane\n\nFrance's Eurovision contestant, Slimane, who will perform the tune Mon Amour, won series five of The Voice France in 2016\n\nFrance's Eurovision contestant, Slimane, who will perform the tune Mon Amour, won series five of The Voice France in 2016.\n\nSince then, he's sold two million albums, released four chart-topping LPs, has seven million followers on social media and two billion worldwide streams.\n\nThe singer wrote the lyrics to his Eurovision entry and co-composed the tune with his friends, Yaacov and Meir Salah, with whom the artist has worked with to make music since the age of 15, reported the competition's site.\n\nAhead of his life-changing win on The Voice, he would perform at piano bars in Paris but now takes to the stage at sell-out tour dates.\n\nHe remarked about performing at the contest on Saturday: 'It's hard not to look in the rear-view mirror now that I know I'll be representing my country at Eurovision!\n\n'It's completely crazy when I think about it. My first concerts in the bars of Pigalle, it seems like yesterday. My father taking me to my first casting. And then The Voice. My encounter with the public.\n\n'The wonderful public that gave me the strength and desire to take on one of the greatest challenges of my career. It's an immense source of pride. A real responsibility too.'\n\nHe added that he would be singing for his parents and his daughter and for his country.\n\nGermany\n\nIsaak\n\nGermany's contestant Isaak will be performing Always On The Run at the final this weekend, where the country will be hoping to improve on their last place position in 2023\n\nGermany's contestant Isaak will be performing Always On The Run at the final this weekend, where the country will be hoping to improve on their last place position in 2023.\n\nThe artist featured on X Factor Germany in 2011 but first started his career in music as a street musician at the age of 12, according to the event's website.\n\nHe plays the guitar, piano, ukulele and drums - and his big break finally came when he secured the top place on the talent programme Show Your Talent.\n\nThe devoted family man - who stills takes to the streets even now to surprise fans with performances - thanks his wife for improving his fashion.\n\nSpain\n\nNebulossa\n\nSpain's entry this year has caused controversy in the country - because the title of their entry 'Zorra', can be translated as either 'vixen' or 'b****' and is seen by some as a sexist slur\n\nSpain's entry this year has caused controversy in the country - because the title of their entry 'Zorra', can be translated as either 'vixen' or 'b****' and is seen by some as a sexist slur.\n\nHowever, the masculine version of 'zorra' - 'zorro' - harmlessly means 'fox', according to Euronews.\n\nHence some fans see the tune - performed by Nebulossa - as an anthem for the country's feminist movement as they 'reclaim' the word. However, others aren't so keen on the idea.\n\nSpanish Prime Minister Pedro S\u00e1nchez reportedly said he liked the song, adding 'feminism is not only fair, it can be fun'.\n\nDespite concerns Eurovision organisers wouldn't accept the tune due to the language used, the European Broadcasting Union said the song would not need to change its lyrics.\n\nTheir statement, published by Euronews, read: 'The EBU understands that there are many interpretations of the title of the song presented by RTVE to represent Spain in this year's Eurovision Song Contest.\n\n'Taking into account its intended use in the context of the lyrics and message of the song, as explained to us by RTVE, we have concluded that the song is eligible to participate in this year's contest.'\n\nSerbia\n\nTEYA DORA\n\nSerbia's entry is Ramonda, performed by TEYA DORA, who last year had the most-streamed song in the Balkans with her TikTok hit D\u017eanum\n\nSerbia's entry is Ramonda, performed by TEYA DORA, who last year had the most-streamed song in the Balkans with her TikTok hit D\u017eanum.\n\nThe title refers to the flower of the same name, which is considered a symbol of Serbia's fight in the First World War.\n\nPeople wear an artificial ramonda as a symbol of remembrance in the week leading up to Armistice Day.\n\nTEYA recently boasted the most monthly listeners on Spotify in the Balkans, reaching more than three million.\n\nSlovenia\n\nRaiven\n\nSlovenia is being represented by Raiven, who performs Veronika\n\nSlovenia is being represented by Raiven, who performs Veronika. she's worked with world-renowned choreographers in Australia and America, performing on The Jennifer Hudson Show, and featured as the lead character in short film Pearly Gates.\n\nShe also regularly presents Nick News for Nickelodeon and was even nominated for the Kids' Choice Awards in 2023, according to the Eurovision website.\n\nGrowing up, she performed in nursing homes and children's hospitals and was the lead singer for the Australian Youth Performing Arts Company (AYPAC).\n\nIn 2022, she launched her debut song, Who Am I?, which astonishingly she had written when she was just 12 years old.\n\nLuxembourg\n\nTali Golergant, an Israeli-born singer currently based in New York, will fly the flag for Luxembourg this year\n\nTali Golergant, an Israeli-born singer currently based in New York, will fly the flag for Luxembourg this year.\n\nIt is the first time in 31 years that the five-time winner has entered the competition, and the European country no doubt hopes the 23-year-old can being back another triumph.\n\nTali wrote her first song when she was only 16 years old and has been on tour in New York with her band.\n\nThe singer was born in Israel to an Israeli mother and a father from Peru. their hit song Vay Aman in 2020.\n\nThe duo's popular eponymous debut album - produced under the French label PIAS - followed in 2023.\n\nThe title of their song, 'Jako', refers to the singer's Kennedy Center in Washington with the World Jazz Nonet.\n\nEstonia\n\nEstonia has sent both hip-hop band 5MIINUST and techno group Puuluup to Eurovision to take to the stage together\n\nEstonia has sent both hip-hop band 5MIINUST and techno group Puuluup to Eurovision to take to the stage together.\n\nThey perform (Nendest) narkootikumidest ei tea me (k\u00fcll) midagi, with the song discussing a drugs bust, according to The Telegraph.\n\nPuuluup was founded in 2014 by duo Ramo Teder and Marko Veisson and are inspired by surrealism and modern folklore.\n\nHip hop group 5MIINUST formed in 2015, with the members consisting of Kristjan Jakobson, Mihkel Tamm, Karl Kivastik, and Priit Tomson. They previously had a fifth member, Pavel Bot\u0161arov, who left the group in 2023 to start a solo career.\n\nGeorgia\n\nNutsa Buzaladze is representing Georgia with the song Firefighter - and she's no stranger to big events\n\nNutsa Buzaladze is representing Georgia with the song Firefighter - and she's no stranger to big events.\n\nThe singer performed on American Idol 2023, where she duetted with Kylie Minogue on the popstar's popular track Can't Get You Out Of My Head.\n\nShe's also enjoyed a residency in the UAE and won the Albanian music competition K\u00ebnga Magjike in 2021.\n\nIn 2019, she launched her debut album under the name Nutsa22 and soon had a tour across the country.\n\nWhen speaking to Eurovision, she described herself as an 'energetic girl who is a real hard worker and at times even something of a workaholic'.\n\nLatvia\n\nLatvia has decided Dons will represent them at the competition this year - with the former DJ and reality TV star performing power-ballad Hollow\n\nLatvia has decided Dons will represent them at the competition this year - with the former DJ and reality TV star performing power-ballad Hollow.\n\nHe has previously lived in London, and reportedly used the stage name 'Art Singer' when performing in the British capital.\n\nDons is one of the nation's most-awarded artists of the last decade, having sold-out arena and stadium shows.\n\nMalta\n\nSarah Bonnici is no stranger to the Eurovision Song Contest - and this year, she'll be performing Loop for Malta's chance at a victory at the event\n\nSarah Bonnici is no stranger to the Eurovision Song Contest - and this year, she'll be performing Loop for Malta's chance at a victory at the event.\n\nThe daughter of a prominent Maltese businessman, she finished third at the Malta Junior Eurosong in 2009 and was a backup singer and dancer at the Junior Eurovision in Belarus the following year for her country.\n\nHer song for this year was penned by herself as well as Eurovision Song Contest 2015 winning writers Linnea Deb and Joy Deb, together with Leire Gotxi Angel, Sebastian Pritchard-James, Kevin-Lee and Michael Joe Cini.\n\nNorway\n\nG\u00e5te is hoping to be Norway's ticket to success this year - performing their folklore-inspired song Ulveham at the highly anticipated annual event\n\nG\u00e5te is hoping to be Norway's ticket to success this year - performing their folklore-inspired song Ulveham at the highly anticipated annual event.\n\nBefore heading to Sweden, the band, from Tr\u00f8ndelag, competed in the nation's Melodi Grand Prix, where they competed again 17 other artists for a place at Eurovision.\n\nThe group, formed in 1999 and consisting of Gunnhild Sundli, Magnus B\u00f8rmark, Jon Even Sch\u00e4rer, Mats Paulsen and John Stenersen, released five albums before taking a 12-year break from the band. They reunited in 2017.\n\nSan Marino\n\nSpanish rock band Megara, from Madrid, are bringing their 90s style track 11:11 to the Eurovision this year as the represent San Marino\n\nSpanish rock band Megara, from Madrid, are bringing their 90s style track 11:11 to the Eurovision this year as the represent San Marino.\n\nThe group - who dream of collaborating with Lady Gaga - twice unsuccessfully {"uri": "8115970643", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:56:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:56:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:56:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.thepinknews.com/2024/05/07/olly-alexander-eurovision-as-gay-as-possible-bambie-thug-nemo/", "title": "Olly Alexander plans to make Eurovision performance 'as gay as possible'", "body": "Olly Alexander is about to make Eurovision 2024 really, really gay. (Eurovision/European Broadcasting Union/Peppe Andersson)\n\nOlly Alexander is gearing up for one of the biggest weeks of his career to date as the UK's 2024 Eurovision Song Contest entrant - and he plans to make it \"as gay as possible\".\n\nOn Tuesday night (7 May) Alexander will take his song, the Danny L Harle produced pop bop \"Dizzy\", to the Eurovision stage in Malm\u00f6, Sweden, for the first time during the first semi-final.\n\nFans have already had a taste of what's to come thanks to footage from the rehearsals, and his staging looks, for want of a better term, gay as hell. And that's exactly what he hoped for.\n\nSpeaking to PinkNews and other media, Alexander describes why he wanted the staging he has - which includes him performing in a filthy post-apocalyptic locker room, surrounded by shirtless men in skimpy boxing shorts.\n\n\"I think if you're going to take a song to Eurovision, the last thing you should do is be safe. As an artist, I love to provoke a little bit, just cause a little bit of discussion, intrigue,\" he shares.\n\nOlly Alexander has form for upsetting miserable prudes watching the BBC: back in 2021, almost 200 people complained that he was being \"too sexual\" during his performance with Kylie Minogue and The Pet Shop Boys during the BBC's Big New Years & Years Eve Party.\n\nAs he said back then, and he maintains now, he will never stop incorporating queerness into his performances.\n\n\"I said right in the beginning of this process, I plan to be as gay as possible - and what's gayer than a locker room?,\" he laughs.\n\n\"I just want mainly to entertain people and to give a really fab performance. Of course, not everyone's gonna love it. But I think that's a sign of a strong performance, really.\"\n\nAnyway, this isn't Alexander's most daring performance look to-date, not by a long shot: he's wearing a tatty white singlet, red trousers, and boots.\n\n\"It's not my most outlandish outfit I've ever worn, but it's more in keeping with the story and the narrative, this sort of post-apocalyptic locker room,\" he explains.\n\n\"It's distressed, maybe I've been through a fight and I fought my way to the Eurovision stage, ready to slay with my boxing gym boys.\"\n\nEurovision 2024 is already set to be one of the queerest in the contest's history: alongside Alexander, there are two other non-binary artists in Ireland's Bambie Thug and Switzerland's (front-runner) Nemo. Other acts including Drag Race Belgium judge Mustii, Australia's Electric Fields, Lithuania's Silvester Belt, and Denmark's SABA also identify as LGBTQ+.\n\nBeing surrounded by queer energy has been imperative for Alexander throughout the process.\n\n\"Historically, Eurovision has been a great place for queer performers, obviously for queer audiences,\" he says.\n\n\"This year, I've really made friends with a lot of contestants, but I've definitely connected a lot with Bambi, with Nemo, with Silvester. Just having that community with each other has been really important. We've been able to support each other a lot.\"\n\nDespite Eurovision being dubbed the gay Olympics, Alexander knows that queer artists still face judgment from viewers outside of the LGBTQ+ community, while some of the countries participating are far more intolerant of LGBTQ+ people than others.\n\n\"We know that, obviously, all of us as contestants when we're in the spotlight, we're going to get judged harshly. For the queer performers, we're going to get a lot of backlash and hate just for being queer and just for being kind of out there visible,\" Alexander reflects.\n\nHe and his fellow queer performers won't be cowed by what any viewers have to say about them, though.\n\n\"There's a lot of value in being your authentic self, being out on a stage and being proud of who you are... we've all had some really good discussions about what it's taken for us to come here to perform at Eurovision. Having each other, it's been really good.\"\n\nWhile taking part in Eurovision is what counts, the question of winning isn't off the table yet either, despite what some betting odds are saying.\n\nAlexander urges fans not to \"count [him] out yet\" but ultimately, but he isn't feeling the pressure about bringing the Eurovision crown back home to the UK.\n\n\"I'm just not going to focus on where I place in the final because as long as I just do a performance I'm proud of, do my best, then that's all that matters,\" he says.\n\n\"Of course I'd love to have a good result, but you just never know what's going to happen on the night. So many things are out of your control... so, whatever will be will be, and I've made my peace with that.\"\n\nOlly Alexander will perform at the first Eurovision semi-final on 7 May, and then again {"uri": "8112269447", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "11:35:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T11:35:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T11:35:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/eurovision-organisers-say-israel-exclusion-would-have-been-political-decision/a749329048.html", "title": "Eurovision organisers say Israel exclusion would have been 'political decision'", "body": "There have been calls for fans and participants to boycott the music competition taking place in Malmo, Sweden, next week after it was confirmed Israel would be competing amid the ongoing conflict in the Gaza strip.\n\nSpeaking on Sunday Morning With Trevor Phillips, Jean Philip De Tender, the deputy director general of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) which organises Eurovision, said it based its decision to include Kan on the competition rules in place.\n\nHe said: \"I fully agree it is a family event and the great thing about this music competition is that it's all about values.\n\n\"It's about uniting onstage all of these young talents, these participants, and they do great. It's about diversity and inclusion.\n\n\"But there are competition rules and you need to follow the competition rules and take decisions based on these competition rules.\n\n\"If you were to exclude Kan outside of these competition rules, that would have been a political decision, as such, which we cannot take.\"\n\nHe also noted the EBU, an apolitical member organisation, is \"in line\" with other international federations including sports bodies who are allowing Israel to participate in events.\n\nFollowing the outbreak of the Israel-Hamas war, Queers for Palestine circulated a letter signed by actors Indya Moore, Brigette Lundy-Paine and Maxine Peake calling for UK entrant Olly Alexander to stop participating.\n\nIn March, Alexander along with Irish hopeful Bambie Thug and other Eurovision artists released a joint statement, backing \"an immediate and lasting ceasefire\" but refusing to boycott the event.\n\nThat same month, Israel unveiled its new entry song as Hurricane, performed by singer Eden Golan.\n\nHer original track, October Rain, had caused controversy as the lyrics were thought to reference the Hamas attacks of October 7 before being changed following the backlash.\n\nDiscussing the backlash, De Tender said: \"We do understand the concerns and the deeply held views that many people have around the war in the Middle East and I think nobody can remain untouched by the profound suffering of everybody involved in that war.\n\n\"The Eurovision Song Contest is a music event which is organised and co-produced by 37 public broadcasters, so it's not a competition between nations or governments.\n\n\"We do understand that there was some concern around Israel participating, but when our governing bodies, because we're a member led organisation, reviewed the participation list of this year, they concluded that Kan, which is the Israeli public broadcaster, met all of the obligations compared to the competing rules.\"\n\nIn 2022, EBU announced that Russia would no longer be participating in Eurovision following the invasion of Ukraine.\n\nA statement at the time said the EBU's executive board had made the decision following a recommendation by the Eurovision governing body, known as the reference group, based on \"the rules of the event and the values of the EBU\".\n\nOn Sunday, De Tender said the situation between Russia and Israel was \"different\" as in Russia's case there was a \"broad consensus within the membership of the EBU that they could not participate\".\n\nHe added that the three Russian members of the EBU had already been \"excluded\" from the EBU membership in the weeks after the war broke out due to breaching \"member obligations\".\n\nThe 37 Eurovision entries are set to perform across two semi-finals next week on Tuesday and Thursday in a bid to compete for a place in the grand final on Saturday.\n\nAlexander is set to perform his dance-infused track Dizzy on behalf of the UK during the Tuesday semi-final, but he is already through to the final along with the other members of the \"big five\" - France, Germany, Italy and Spain - as well as last year's winner Sweden, who get to go through automatically.\n\nDe Tender said the preparations are going \"very well\" as they have been planning the music spectacle in Sweden for the past year after Loreen won the competition with her hit song
