{"uri": "8115710899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:07:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:07:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T14:06:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/artists/eurovision-uk-entries-winners-where-now-bucks-fizz/", "title": "Britain's Eurovision Song Contest entries: what happened next?", "body": "Britain has a chequered record in Europe's trashiest competition. Here are the highs and lows in full - and what came next\n\nGuaranteed to provide a lift in dark times, Eurovision 2024 is set to flounce back on to screens. It started on May 7, with the final taking place this Saturday, May 11.\n\nBritain's representative this year is 33-year-old singer and actor Olly Alexander. Star of It's A Sin and the lead singer of Years & Years, his entry - a thumping bassline electro feverdream, Dizzy - is exactly the sort of thing which Eurovision specialises in. It's camp, catchy and, looked at for more than three seconds, as flimsy as a feather boa on the breeze. Dynamite.\n\nFind out whether the judges in Malm\u00f6 feel the same way by turning into the Grand Final on Saturday May 11, which will be broadcast live 8pm on BBC One. Representing the host nation of Sweden, the event will be MC'ed by Hollywood actress Malin \u00c5kerman (best known for Watchman), who is joined by comedian and Eurovision regular Petra Mede. And, as usual, Graham Norton will be on hand for eyebrows-raised presenting duties. This year, Joanna Lumley will be UK's spokesperson.\n\nBut what happens when the lights fade out? Life as someone who \"once made a t__ of themselves on Eurovision\" can be a bleak place. (Just ask Jemini.) So from the famous to the infamous, it's time to look back at what happened next to all the British acts who've graced the Eurovision stage.\n\nWhere are the Eurovision Song Contest entries now?1957: Patricia Bredin, 'All'\n\n\"All the golden dreams of yesterday,\" crooned Patricia Bredin, the young actress and amateur opera singer from Hull who became Britain's first ever Eurovision contestant, when we joined the contest for its second year. (We would skip the next one, too.) At a nifty one minute and 52 seconds, All remains the UK's shortest Eurovision entry.\n\nBorn in 1935, Bredin went on to appear in several films alongside Sid James and Ian Carmichael, before taking over from Julie Andrews as Guenevere in a Broadway production of Camelot with Richard Burton. She then emigrated to Canada and took to raising cattle.\n\nShe was still performing as recently as 2007, and looked back at her Eurovision appearance fondly, although she was a bit baffled when she was first approached to take part in the contest. She had never watched TV before, and wasn't sure what it involved. \"Television? I'd never heard of it! I didn't know what they were talking about,\" she recalled in 2016. Bredin died on August 13, 2023, aged 88.\n\n1959: Pearl Carr & Teddy Johnson, 'Sing, Little Birdie'\n\nVery much the Beyonc\u00e9 and Jay Z of their day, Carr & Johnson were both popular and independently successful singers before their marriage in 1955. They arrived on Eurovision at the peak of their fame, which clearly helped: they placed second in that year's contest.\n\nAfter Eurovision, Johnson went on work as a Radio 2 DJ, and appeared in the TV children's programme Crackerjack. In 1987, the couple starred together in a West End revival of Stephen Sondheim's musical Follies. For many years, they lived together in Brinsworth House, an actors' and artists' retirement home in Twickenham. Teddy Johnson died in June 2018, and Pearl Carr followed in February 2020. They were both 98.\n\n1960: Bryan Johnson, 'Looking High, High, High'\n\nOur 1959 contestant Teddy Johnson had auditioned to represent the UK again in 1960, but found himself pipped to the post by his own brother, Bryan, an out-of-work actor. Like Teddy the year before, Bryan finished in second place.\n\nBetter known for his stage roles than his singing, Johnson gave several acclaimed performances in Shakespearean productions, taking comic roles alongside the famous (and famously histrionic) actor-director Sir Donald Wolfit. Recalling his part in Wolfit's King Lear, the impresario called Johnson \"the best Fool I ever had\". He died in 1995.\n\n1961: The Allisons, 'Are You Sure?'\n\nDespite being unrelated (their real names were John Alford and Bob Day), \"John and Bob Allison\" were marketed as Britain's answer to the Everly Brothers, a pair of clean-cut crooning siblings. They came in second place at Eurovision with a distinguished 24 points, and Are You Sure? became a minor hit. The pair climbed back into the top 40 singles chart the following year with Lessons in Love, but disbanded in 1963, making only a few reunion appearances. They gave their last concert together in 2012; Bob Day died a year later.\n\n1962 & 1963: Ronnie Carroll, 'Ring-A-Ding Girl' & 'Say Wonderful Things'\n\nThe Belfast-born plumber's son Ronnie Carroll is the only singer to have represented the UK for two straight years, reaching fourth place both times.\n\nHe went on to make a living performing on luxury cruise ships including the QE2, and released a comeback album, Back on Song, in 2005. He went bankrupt twice; after the second time, he set up a food stall in Camden Market.\n\nMore surprisingly, Carroll brought his sense of humour and showbiz to the world of British politics. He stood for as a candidate for the tiny Rainbow Alliance party in the 1997 General Election, and again in a 2008 by-election for the Make Politicians History party. That name proved horribly prophetic: when he tried his luck again in the 2015 general election, he died four days after nominations closed, but crucially before polling day. As a result, \"The Eurovisionary Carroll\" was a candidate on the ballot.\n\n1964: Matt Monro, 'I Love the Little Things'\n\nAt the time of his Eurovision appearance, London singer Monro (nicknamed \"the man with the golden voice\") had already lent his vocal talents to a Bond movie, singing the theme tune for 1963's From Russia with Love.\n\nAfter placing second in Eurovision, he went on to sing the Oscar-winning title song for 1966 drama Born Free (about the life of Elsa the Lioness), and continued to record and perform until his death from liver cancer in 1985.\n\n1965: Kathy Kirby, 'I Belong'\n\nOnce the highest-paid female singer of her generation, the Marilyn Monroe-esque Kirby brought a radical touch of Sixties spice to Eurovision in 1965, only to finish in second place behind a still more controversial song, Serge's Gainsbourg's edgy and satirical Poup\u00e9e de cire, poup\u00e9e de son, performed by Luxembourg's entry France Gall.\n\nPost-Eurovision, Kirby had two prime-time BBC television hits, The Kathy Kirby Show and Kathy Kirby Sings. She toured with stars including Cliff Richard and Tom Jones, and reportedly had an affair with Bruce Forsyth.\n\nBut after the death in 1971 of her manager and lover Bert Ambrose (42 years her senior), Kirby's career suffered. She was declared bankrupt in 1975, and, having been diagnosed with schizophrenia, she was admitted to a psychiatric hospital in 1979. After being discharged, she moved in with a female fan called Laraine McKay, and caused a media storm when she announced they were planning to marry each other; the relationship came to an end when McKay was arrested and imprisoned for fraud.\n\nKirby retired from singing in 1983 after a glitzy farewell concert in Blackpool, and died in 2011.\n\n1966: Kenneth McKellar, 'A Man Without Love'\n\nScottish pantomime star McKellar shocked Eurovision audiences by performing in a kilt (a last-minute costume decision). It went down badly: he placed ninth, Britain's worst result at the time.\n\nDespite his Euroflop, McKellar's eclectic singing career endured until the mid-Nineties, highlights including an acclaimed musical setting of Robert Burns's poems, and his popular recording of Song of the Clyde, used as the opening theme for 1963 film Billy Liar.\n\nMore surprisingly, he recorded an Afrikaans-language album in 1970, and wrote a comedy sketch that Monty Python performed at the Secret Policemen's Ball. He died in the USA in 2010, and was brought back home to be buried in Paisley.\n\n1967: Sandie Shaw, 'Puppet on a String'\n\nBritain's first Eurochamp was a likely winner from the outset; she'd already had a UK number one in 1964, and having also recorded her hit singles in French, Italian, German and Spanish, she was equally popular on the continent.\n\nBut she wasn't proud of her Eurovision-winning song. \"I hated it from the very first oompah to the final bang on the big bass drum,\" she once said. \"I was instinctively repelled by its sexist drivel and cuckoo-clock tune.\" Still, it didn't hamper her pop career, with further hits well into the Eighties (prompting fan-mail from The Smiths' Morrissey and Johnny Marr).\n\nSince the Nineties, however, Shaw has worked as a psychotherapist; she finally announced her complete retirement from music in 2013. In 2017, she received an MBE for services to music. She has also been a political campaigner: in 2012, she joined an Amnesty International push against human rights abuses in Azerbaijan, that year's host country; and she campaigned against Brexit in 2016.\n\n1968 & 1973: Cliff Richard, 'Congratulations' & 'Power to All Our Friends'\n\nBorn Harry Webb in Lucknow, now Sir Cliff (OBE), the octogenarian is still going strong, having sold over 21 million singles in the UK across his half-century career. He did rather well at Eurovision, too, reaching second (1968) and third place (1973).\n\nHe has been a fixture of British cultural life ever since. In 2018, he released his first studio album of new material for 14 years, Rise Up, which dealt with his acrimonious legal battle with the BBC. (In 2014, Richard had been investigated as part of Operation Yewtree over allegations of historical sexual abuse, but he was never arrested for any offence. The BBC controversially broadcast a search of his home, and have since been forced to pay out substantial damages.)\n\n1969: Lulu, 'Boom Bang-a-Bang'\n\nScottish pop supernova and TV personality Lulu won 1969's Eurovision in a four-way tie with Spain, France and the Netherlands.\n\nShe went on to score number one singles in the UK and America, and sang the theme for 1974 Bond movie The Man with the Golden Gun. (That said, in America she's perhaps better known as the voice behind the chart-busting title theme for the 1967 film To Sir, With Love.)\n\nIn 2011 she took part in Strictly Come Dancing, and in 2014 sang at the closing ceremony for the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow. In 2018 she returned to the London stage in West End musical 42nd Street, and was a special guest on Take That's Greatest Hits Live tour. She was honoured with a CBE in 2021.\n\n1970: Mary Hopkin, 'Knock, Knock, Who's There?'\n\nWelsh folk singer Hopkin gave the UK another second place at Eurovision, after a string of hit singles including Goodbye (written and produced by Paul McCartney).\n\nAfter she married top producer Tony Visconti in 1971, she withdrew from the limelight, but still sang on several albums he produced, including David Bowie's Low. After a late-Seventies comeback, she joined a group called Oasis (not the Gallaghers' band), and sang on Vangelis's soundtrack for Blade Runner. .\n\nIn 2018, to celebrate the 50th anniversary of her break out single Those Were the Days, produced by Paul McCartney, Hopkin released a new acoustic version of the track. She is still recording, and released her last studio album in 2023 on her 73rd birthday with her daughter Jessica Lee Morgan\n\n1971: Clodagh Rodgers, 'Jack In The Box'\n\nYoung Northern Irish singer Clodagh Rodgers received death threats from the IRA when she agreed to represent the UK at the 1971 Eurovision, staged in Dublin. She took the stage nonetheless, and finished in a decent fourth place.\n\nShe only had one post-Eurovision chart single (Lady Love Bug, in late 1971), but continued a ropey recording career for several years, releasing her last new studio album in 1977. She would have better luck on stage, touring with the West End musical Blood Brothers in the Nineties before retiring from the music business in 2015.\n\n1972: The New Seekers, 'Beg, Steal or Borrow'\n\nThe New Seekers were only tenuously linked to their Australian parent-group by original Seeker Keith Podger, who left the band before it brought Britain yet another second-place result with its saccharine harmonies. They disbanded in 1974, but have reappeared in various shifting incarnations over the years, most recently in a 2006 tour, which only featured one member of their Eurovision line-up (Paul Layton).\n\n1974: Olivia Newton-John, 'Long Live Love'\n\nAfter taking Britain to fourth place in Eurovision (beaten by ABBA's Waterloo), Newton-John was immortalised on the big screen as Sandy in 1978's Grease. She found further chart success with the soundtrack to Electric Light Orchestra musical Xanadu in 1980 (though the film itself was a flop) and solo recordings including I Honestly Love You and Physical. She won four Grammys and became one of the best-selling female artists of all time. Newton-John was first diagnosed with breast cancer in 1992 and became a passionate advocate for cancer research. She battled the disease three times before her death aged 73 in 2022.\n\n1975: The Shadows, 'Let Me Be The One'\n\nFormerly Cliff Richard's backing band, The Shadows were best known for instrumental hits such as Apache, but made an impressively laid-back foray into vocal harmonies for Eurovision, placing second (again!) despite obviously forgetting the words at one point.\n\nThe band went on to considerable worldwide success, and the then-current members were all offered OBEs in 2004 (though lead guitarist Hank Marvin declined his). They played their farewell tour in 2009. \"Everyone thinks screaming was invented with Beatlemania,\" the band told The Telegraph, \"but Cliff had his own mania.\"\n\n1976: Brotherhood of Man, 'Save Your Kisses for Me'\n\nAfter winning Eurovision, the ABBA-esque Save Your Kisses for Me became the biggest-selling Eurovision winner to date, prompting a series of international tours, but the Brotherhood's hits dried up by the end of the decade. They have reunited sporadically since splitting up in 1984 but decided to retire from touring in 2022.\n\n1977: Lynsey de Paul & Mike Moran, 'Rock Bottom'\n\nBritain came second (yup, it's catching) with this jaunty honky-tonk duet, though after a few follow-up singles the pair went their separate ways. Afterwards, Moran became the producer of the long-running children's music TV show Get It Together, while de Paul (after a few pop releases) moved into classical music, releasing albums of Bach and Handel. In 1982, she starred with Ian McKellen, Joanna Lumley and Helen Mirren in a West End panto production of Cinderella.\n\nDe Paul also made a police-approved self-defence video, worked as OK! magazine's staff cartoonist, and once released a concept album of children's pop songs about the Channel Tunnel. She died in October 2014.\n\n1978: Co-Co, 'The Bad Old Days'\n\nOriginally called Mothers Pride and finishing in 11th place, Co-Co split up soon after their Eurovision humiliation, having only released one album. But their real importance is as a prelude: band member Cheryl Baker would be back just three years later with her new group, Bucks Fizz, and would win the competition.\n\n1979: Black Lace, 'Mary Ann'\n\nNovelty foursome Black Lace may have made little impact at Eurovision (placing seventh), but they would achieve undying notoriety five years later, when they released the hellishly catchy earworm Agadoo (once heralded by Q Magazine as The Worst Song of All Time, according to a panel of expert music writers). Another dubious career highlight came in 2003, when band member Colin Gibb put out an X-rated Black Lace album called The Blue (released in Tenerife). In 2016, he reunited with singer Gordon King for what was billed as the band's 40th anniversary tour. Alan Barton died in a coach crash in 1995 while touring with Smokie, while Rob Hopcraft died as a result of a fall in May 2020.\n\n1980: Prima Donna, 'Love Enough for Two'\n\nPrima Donna were part of a tangled Eurovision dynasty: one singer Danny Finn, was formerly in The New Seekers, our 1972 entry, while fellow band-member Lance Aston was the brother of Bucks Fizz singer, and future 1981 winner, Jay Aston. Prima Donna's Sally Ann Triplett, meanwhile, would return to Eurovision two years after that, as one half of UK entry Bardo.\n\nUnable to hold together such a powerful nexus of Europop talent, the band's flame burned only briefly; our 1980 hope had disbanded before the year was over.\n\n1981: Bucks Fizz, 'Making Your Mind Up'\n\nNotorious for their skirt-ripping dance routine, Bucks Fizz not only blazed to victory at Eurovision but also went on to sell 15 million records worldwide, with further UK number one hits including The Land of Make Believe and My Camera Never Lies.\n\nBut in 1984, tragedy struck: a bus crash broke the spine of band member Cheryl Baker, and sent fellow singer Mike Nolan into a three-day coma, causing injuries from which he has never fully recovered. Creative difference led to a legal battle over the rights to the band name in the late Nineties and early Noughties, in what The Telegraph later called \"one of the messiest break-ups in music history\".\n\nGoing by The Fizz, Baker, Nolan and Aston got back together in 2009 and embarked on a UK-wide tour. In the 2019 general election, Aston briefly became a politician when she stood for Nigel Farage's Brexit Party in Kensington, but received less than 1 per cent of the vote. Their third studio album, Smoke & Mirrors, was released in March, reaching 29th in the charts. They are currently back on tour.\n\n1982: Bardo, 'One Step Further'\n\nCrackerjack presenter and former Prima Donna member Sally Ann Triplett only reached seventh place with this duet, joined by her real-life romantic partner Stephen Fischer. Fischer went on to work as a keyboardist with Boy George and Bob Geldof, while Triplett has found success in Broadway musicals and on the West End stage.\n\n1983: Sweet Dreams, 'I'm Never Giving Up'\n\nThis now-forgotten teenage pop trio finished in sixth place. When their follow-up single failed to chart, the band split up just a few months after Eurovision. Pretty boy Bobby McVay became a local radio presenter, before joining Bucks Fizz on their 2015 reunion tour, while fellow dreamer Carrie Grant became a vocal coach, returning to Eurovision in 2014 to head the UK's expert jury.\n\n1984: Belle and the Devotions, 'Love Games'\n\nThe poor behaviour of British football fans at a 1983 Luxembourg match meant that this trio were greeted with boos as they took the stage in Luxembourg for Eurovision 1984. Their Supremes-like love song finished in seventh place, and the band split up soon afterwards, though \"Belle\" (real name: Kit Rolfe) would return to Eurovision in 1991 as a backing singer for Britain's Samantha Janus. Rolfe also recorded an unsuccessful novelty single with failed Olympic skier Eddie \"The Eagle\" Edwards.\n\n1985: Vikki, 'Love Is...'\n\nVictoria Watson was our first female Eurovision entry to perform a self-penned song. Her ballad only came in fourth place, but Watson has since used her ethereal vocals to great effect, after changing her name, moving to Los Angeles and rebranding herself as an Celtic-influenced ambient folk singer.\n\nShe hasn't made much of an impact on the pop world, putting out a string of online-only releases before a 2015 comeback album. But she's a big name in Hollywood sound-design: her atmospheric, wordless vocals have been used on more than 70 film trailers, including The Hobbit: Battle of the Five Armies and the 2016 Dan Brown adaptation Inferno.\n\nShe now performs under the name Aeone (pronounced \"ay-own\"). According to her website, the new name means \"an endless period of time that is essentially female, feeling without thinking\".\n\n1986: Ryder, 'Runner in the Night'\n\nThe pop sextet Ryder (led by singer Maynard Williams) were manufactured created purely to take part in Eurovision. The result was a disaster: their song only placed seventh in the competition, and didn't even scrape into the top 75 in the UK singles chart, making it the worst commercial flop of any British Eurovision entry. In 1987, Williams sang the theme tune for the BBC sitcom Truckers, also better forgotten. After popping up in a 1996 episode of Heartbeat, he seemingly retired from showbiz for good.\n\n1987: Rikki, 'Only the Light'\n\nLike \"Vikki\" before him and \"Emma\" after, the mononymous Scottish singer Rikki seems to have chosen his name with a view to future anonymity: it's not so much a pop rebrand as a Eurovictim protection programme, helping failed entrants to hide their shame.\n\nBorn Richard Peebles, he arrived at the door of Eurovision having previously written a few songs for a middle-of-the-road pop band called Middle of the Road. Rikki finished in 13th place, and never made it into the UK top 75 chart. After a botched 1987 debut album, he has avoided the limelight, writing songs for club performers.\n\nWhen The Mirror tracked him down for a 1996 interview, he recalled how badly he had been hurt by Eurovision. \"I cried,\" he said. \"I thought I had let my country down in front of all those millions of viewers. I would never, ever do it again.\"\n\n1988: Scott Fitzgerald, 'Go'\n\nThe overwrought ballad Go was yet another second-place near-miss for the UK. It was written by Bruce Forsyth's daughter Julie, who joined Scottish singer Fitzgerald onstage for Eurovision in Dublin. Fitzgerald was raised on a Glasgow tenement where, in his early childhood, he befriended a girl called Marie Lawrie - who grew up to become the 1969 Eurovision winner Lulu. His own pop career stalled after his silver medal 19 years later, but his son Ki Fitzgerald has fared better - he's a founding member of Noughties boy band Busted.\n\n1989: Live Report, 'Why Do I Always Get it Wrong?'\n\nFor Eurovision voters, Live Report clearly got something right, receiving the most perfect 12-point scores from judges. Sadly, it wasn't enough to win: Britain came second (there's a theme emerging, here) to Yugoslavia. The band's lead singer Ray Caruana is actually Maltese, and was later a runner-up in the contest to represent Malta for Eurovision 1994.\n\n1990: Emma, 'Give a Little Love Back to the World'\n\nAt just 15 years old, Emma Booth remains Britain's youngest Eurovision contestant. Her song finished sixth and broke into the UK top 40, but, in what was by now a fine British tradition, her follow-up single failed to chart.\n\nAccording to the local news site Wales Online, as of 2004 Booth was making a living singing on cruise ships. Her other post-Eurovision work involved touring with the Chuckle Brothers, and supporting Keith Harris and Orville the Duck.\n\n1991: Samantha Janus, 'A Message to Your Heart'\n\nAfter placing 10th in Eurovision, Brighton-born Samantha quit the pop world for a career in acting, playing Sandy in a West End revival of Grease. She is best known, however, for playing the icy Ronnie Mitchell in EastEnders from 2007-2017.\n\n1992: Michael Ball, 'One Step Out of Time'\n\nAlready a successful West End musical performer, Ball took the UK to second place (again!) in Eurovision, before hosting his own ITV music show, and releasing a string of gold-selling albums. He still performs regularly, and presents a show on BBC Radio 2. In 2015, he received an OBE for services to musical theatre.\n\nIn March 2019, Ball released the album Coming Home To You, which became his first number one album as a solo artist in almost three decades. The same year, he performed in a placeholder production of Les Mis\u00e9rables with long-time collaborator Alfie Boe, while the West End production moved theatres. His NHS-fundraising cover of You'll Never Walk Alone, with Capt Tom Moore, topped the charts during the coronavirus pandemic.\n\n1993: Sonia, 'Better the Devil You Know'\n\nLiverpool singer Sonia Evans came second (again!) in Eurovision with this rock 'n' roll number, having already racked up several UK chart hits (most notably 1989's You'll Never Stop Me Loving You). When her recording career hit a post-Eurovision slump, she took to the London stage, briefly playing Sandy in Grease (before handing over the role to our 1991 entry Samantha Janus).\n\nAfterwards, she slid into reality television (ITV's Reborn in the USA, a 2003 vehicle for has-been pop stars) and regional panto. But in 2012, she had a one-off return to a major stage, performing at London's O2 Arena for a Hit Factory Live concert alongside Kylie Minogue. She signed a new record deal with Energise Records in 2019, and released the single A Night That's Never Ending later that year.\n\n1994: Frances Ruffelle, 'We Will Be Free (Lonely Symphony)'\n\nAfter placing 10th in 1994 with We Will Be Free, Ruffelle followed several other Eurovisionistas into musical theatre. She has found success in the West End, appearing in Trevor Nunn's Tony Award-winning RSC Les Mis\u00e9rables, and playing the title role in Piaf. In 2017, she starred in the musical The Wild Party, at Andrew Lloyd Webber's West End venue The Other Palace.\n\n1995: Love City Groove, 'Love City Groove'\n\nBritain's first foray into Eurovision hip-hop reached number seven in the charts, but only placed tenth in the contest. The group's rapper Stephen \"Beanz\" Rudden has since found work as a jobbing producer, writing the theme tune for 1998's forgotten Kelsey Grammer comedy The Real Howard Spitz.\n\nMeanwhile, Paul Hardy (who sang the chorus) tried to rise from the ashes by rebranding himself Paul Phoenix and signing up to compete on BBC One's The Voice in 2016. Sadly, he didn't even make it through the initial blind-audition round.\n\n1996: Gina G, 'Ooh Aah... Just a Little Bit'\n\nBorn and raised in Australia, Gina Gardiner's saucy pop tune didn't go down well at Eurovision (placing seventh), but it became a UK number one. Despite a successful debut album, she left the music industry following a lengthy legal battle with her producer. She tried to make a comeback in 2005, competing unsuccessfully to represent Britain in Eurovision again. She then moved to Los Angeles to run her own record label, Stunt Girl Music.\n\n1997: Katrina and the Waves, 'Love Shine a Light'\n\nIn 1997, Katrina and the Waves were no longer Walking on Sunshine, with their Eighties heyday a distant memory. But winning Eurovision in 1997 brought them back into the limelight, giving them their biggest-selling UK single to date. Later that year, lead singer Katrina Leskanich caused a tabloid rumpus when she was photographed kissing comedian Caroline Aherne at a Sony Awards dinner. Leskanich left the band in 1998, finding work as a Radio 2 DJ, releasing several (non-chart) solo albums, and co-authoring a travel guide to London with her pet poodle, Peggy Lee. As of 2023, she was still touring.\n\n1998: Imaani, 'Where Are You'\n\nImaani's song Where Are You came a very respectable second to Israel's Dana International. Released as a single, it remained in the UK charts for over two months, but Imaani was dropped by EMI before a follow up single.\n\nShe continues to perform regularly alongside jazz-funk band Incognito. Her first solo album, Standing Tall, was released in 2014, but it failed to chart. No UK act since has exceeded her Eurovision score of 166, which remains her greatest career achievement to date.\n\n1999: Precious, 'Say It Again'\n\nGirl band Precious split up the year after they competed in Eurovision, having released just four singles. The song they took to Jerusalem in 1999, Say It Again, gained only 38 points.\n\nTheir best-known member was Jenny Frost, who went on to join Atomic Kitten in 2000. Replacing Kerry Katona, Frost released three number one singles with the group before they split in 2004. Her more recent exploits have included appearing in I'm A Celebrity... in 2005, presenting the BBC Three show Snog, Marry Avoid? and becoming the face of homeopathic medicine company Nelson's. She would, in turn, be re-replaced by Katona in 2012.\n\nAmong the other Precious members, Sophie McDonnell had a brief spell as a presenter on CBBC, while lead singer Louise Rose went into acting, and has appeared in Moving Wallpaper and Luther. Kalli Clark-Sternberg is now a session-singer, while Anya Lahiri is a boot-camp trainer.\n\n2000: Nicki French, 'Don't Play That Song Again'\n\nFrench sang Don't Play That Song Again to the crowds in Stockholm in 2000. They seemed to agree, awarding the UK just 28 points.\n\nThese days, French performs at Pride events across the world, and has appeared on British theatre stages too, starring in Menopause: The Musical in 2007. Despite not coming out top in Eurovision, her entry was nonetheless released in a 2015 special edition EP, along with a four-disc anthology album, One Step Further.\n\n2001: Lindsay D, 'No Dream Impossible'\n\nAt 16, Lindsay Dracass represented the UK with the song No Dream Impossible in 2001. The song placed 15th, and after one European tour and the single hitting number 32 in the charts, she went back to being a normal British teenager. She now works as a vocal coach. In November 2019, she released a new album, Waiting for You.\n\n2002: Jessica Garlick, 'Come Back'\n\nAfter being among the last 10 contestants on Pop Idol 2002, Welsh singer Garlick represented the UK in Tallinn. Her score of 111 points made her the highest scoring British act of the 2000s, and won her (joint) third place. She featured in a number of subsequent Eurovision analysis programmes, including the following year's UK selection show, A Song For Europe.\n\nShe embarked on a solo career in 2009, but has never really escaped Eurovision, releasing her first single the day before the semi-final, and giving her first live performance at the Eurovision Preview Party 2009. Other notable appearances include featuring on the identity parade in BBC panel show Never Mind the Buzzcocks in 2006.\n\n2003: Jemini, 'Cry Baby'\n\nAfter gaining notoriety for coming last in the 2003 contest in Latvia, gaining the dreaded score of \"nul points\" for Cry Baby, Liverpudlian duo Jemini were dropped by their record company. Gemma Abbey subsequently worked in a car showroom, while Chris Cromby found employment in a clothes shop.\n\nThat wasn't the end of their Eurovision career though. The pair were (for some reason) interviewed for the 2013 BBC special How To Win Eurovision, and reunited in 2014 for a Eurovision special episode of BBC game show Pointless Celebrities.\n\nIn 2016, Abbey was convicted of benefits fraud. The singer had claimed over \u00a367,000 in tax credits as a single mother, despite being married; officials found photographs of her wedding on Facebook.\n\n2004: James Fox, 'Hold On To Our Love'\n\nWelsh singer James Fox followed up his 16th-place finish by writing and recording the official 2008 FA Cup song for Cardiff FC. Since then he has become a fixture in musical theatre, recently playing Paul McCartney in the West End and Broadway runs of Beatles musical Let It Be. He has also supported a range of celebrities, including Tina Turner, Wet Wet Wet and Lulu. He is still energetically releasing new music.\n\n2005: Javine Hylton, 'Touch My Fire'\n\nIn a shock vote, Javine was chosen to represent the UK over Katie Price's autotune-defying offering Not Just Anybody. Her song, Touch My Fire, came 22nd (of 24) in the final. She continued a career as an R&B singer and television personality, appearing on Never Mind The Buzzcocks and Skins. She won Channel 4 game show The Games in 2006, and came second in Celebrity Come Dine With Me in 2010. She is now the face of Javine Total Fitness, her own sports and fitness brand.\n\n2006: Daz Sampson, 'Teenage Life'\n\nDaz Sampson represented the UK in Eurovision after releasing several reasonably successful dance tracks in the UK and Europe. His co-written entry Teenage Life, featuring backing dancers dressed as school girls known as The Sampsonites, perhaps slightly misjudged the age and sexuality of the average Eurovision viewer and only scored 25 points. It proved more popular with the home crowd however, charting at 8 in the UK Top 40.\n\nIn 2011 Sampson re-launched himself as a hypnotist, telling the Manchester Evening News he intended to \"quit the recording studio and help make the world become a happier and a healthier place.\" A Twitter feed associated with Daz (which describes him as a fortune-teller, inter alia), announced in May 2015 that he would soon be \"back in the studio [...] i want to say sorry in advance for what comes out. but i have a family to feed.\" No new tracks have since emerged, so Sampson's family are presumably still peckish.\n\nSampson also works as a professional football manager and scout, with links to Scottish Championship side Ayr United and Stockport County in England's National League North.\n\n2007: Scooch, 'Flying the Flag (For You)'\n\nIt may surprise viewers of Scooch's airline-themed Eurovision appearance to learn that this was not the group's first TV performance. In fact, in 1999 they won the opportunity to have a single released after beating a rival band in a competition on TV show Live & Kicking.\n\nDespite mixed sentiment surrounding Scooch's entry (Charlotte Church described the act as \"absolute s---\", and Swedish singer Pandora accused Flying The Flag of plagiarism), the act were the first in five years to receive \"douze points\" for the UK, winning the maximum score from Malta.\n\nDisappointingly, none of the band now work for an airline. Natalie Powers is a singing coach at a performing arts school, David Ducasse works at a vets while Caroline Barnes and Russ Spencer started a relationship post-Eurovision, and became one of the longest lasting couples on series 4 of Channel 4 game show Coach Trip in 2010.\n\n2008: Andy Abraham, 'Even If'\n\nX-Factor runner-up Andy Abraham's performance of Even If came joint last in Belgrade in 2008. But he remained on the UK stage, touring the show An Evening with Andy Abraham for two years after the contest. More recently, he played both Judas and John the Baptist in a touring revival of the musical Godspell, alongside his successor at Eurovision, Jade Ewen.\n\n2009: Jade Ewen, 'It's My Time'\n\nAndrew Lloyd Webber led the UK selection programme which voted Jade Ewen as the 2009 UK entry, and played piano alongside her in the song It's My Time. Ewen placed fifth in the end, gaining points from 31 countries.\n\nLike 1999 contestant Jenny Frost, she went on to join a three-piece girl band that has a fairly constant rotation of members: the Sugababes. In 2013 she was the first celebrity to be eliminated on BBC game show Splash!.\n\n2010: Josh Dubovie, 'That Sounds Good To Me'\n\nJosh Dubovie was the third UK entry to place last in 10 years, his song That Sounds Good To Me winning only 10 points.\n\nHe has since changed his stage name to Josh James, as searches including Dubovie only returned results relating to Eurovision, preventing him from forging a new reputation. His debut solo single was released in 2013, peaking at number 179. His website lists his current occupations as \"mindset coach, dreamer, dad and entrepreneur\".\n\n2011: Blue, 'I Can'\n\nTen years after the boyband formed, Blue marked their return to showbiz by performing the song I Can. The song placed 11th, and the band complained they were the victims of political voting.\n\nTheir limited company, Blueworld Touring No1 Ltd dissolved in 2014, and since then every member of Blue has declared themselves bankrupt. Blue had a one album and one single deal with Sony for 2015's Colours, which sold over 8,500 copies in its first week on sale. Following the tour of Colours, members Lee Ryan and Duncan James went on to have acting careers in EastEnders and Hollyoaks respectively. The group released their sixth studio album Heart & Soul in 2022.\n\n2012: Engelbert Humperdinck, 'Love Will Set You Free'\n\nTraditional crooner Engelbert Humperdinck was put forward to represent the UK through internal selection. Performing with no sequins on his outfit and no backing dancers at all, he placed second last with 12 points.\n\nNow in his eighties, Humperdinck has sold more than 140 million records and continues to tour, but Love Will Set You Free rarely makes an appearance on his set-lists.\n\n2013: Bonnie Tyler, 'Believe In Me'\n\nTyler may have been past her Eighties heyday (when she had a string of hit ballads such as Total Eclipse of the Heart), but she still won plaudits from the critics for her Eurovision single. Tyler was the first UK entrant to receive the Eurovision Song Contest Radio Awards for Best Song and Best Female Singer.\n\nThat didn't change the fact that her performance of Believe In Me came a lowly 19th. Unlike some previous entries, its poor performance at Eurovision was repeated in the UK market, only reaching a peak chart position of 93.\n\nNonetheless, she has continued to record and perform as if it never happened. She released her most recent album in April this year.\n\n2014: Molly Smitten-Downes, 'Children of the Universe'\n\nChildren Of The Universe, Molly's self-penned ballad designed to \"break down political boundaries\", seemed a subtle attempt from the UK internal selection committee to actually make an impact, and before the final the UK was among the favourites to win. It was not to be however, with Smitten-Downes winning only 40 points on the night.\n\nHer musical career hasn't progressed a huge amount since then, her only noteworthy release being a guest appearance on a 2015 track by German DJ Zwette.\n\n2015: Electro Velvet, 'Still in Love With You'\n\nThis likeable (and unfairly mocked) electro-swing duo comprised The X Factor and The Voice reject Bianca Nicholas, and Alex Larke, the Mick Jagger part of a Rolling Stones tribute act. Alas, after placing 24th in Eurovision, plans for a debut LP were shelved due to Nicholas's poor health. Nicholas, who suffers from cystic fibrosis, has become a prominent public face for people living with the condition, and in December 2016 she released a cover-version of Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas. In February 2017, Larke released his debut solo single, Shine On.\n\n2016: Joe and Jake, 'You're Not Alone'\n\nLight-rock duo Joe Woolford and Jake Shakeshaft (from Ruthin and Stoke-on-Trent, respectively) are still together and still gigging in small venues. In October 2016, the band played a charity fundraising gig at the Ruthin Farmers Auction to raise money for a local girl's medical treatment. That same month, they tweeted that they were recording \"lots of songs\", but only one follow-up to their Eurovision single has been released: 2017's Tongue Tied, which failed to chart.\n\n2017: Lucie Jones, 'Never Give Up on You'\n\nThe 27-year-old X-Factor contestant was the bookies' fifth-favourite to win the 2017 Eurovision Song Contest, but the singer finished in 15th place, blaming Brexit for her disappointing result. Since the show, Jones has turned her attention to musicals, appearing as Holly in the UK tour of The Wedding Singer, and reprising her role as Elle Woods in a nine-month run of Legally Blonde. In 2019, she was cast in the West End musical Waitress, and after a hiatus, returned to the role after the coronavirus pandemic closed the theatres. She won best takeover performance at the WhatsOnStage Awards in 2023, and starred in Wicked and Les Miserables.\n\n2018: SuRie, 'Storm'\n\nSuRie, born Susanna Marie Cork, finished 24th in 2018's Eurovision Song Contest. In 2015, she provided backing vocals for Belgium's Eurovision entry, and in 2017 she was the musical director for another Belgian contestant.\n\nHer own performance was notable for its interruption. SuRie was thrown off when a protester stormed the stage, took the microphone and shouted \"Modern Nazis of the UK media, we demand freedom, war is not peace.\" She was diagnosed with PTSD after the incident.\n\nHer follow-up singles have failed to chart in the UK.\n\n2019: Michael Rice, 'Bigger Than Us'\n\nMichael Rice finished dead last in the 2019 Eurovision Song Contest, the UK's fourth bottom-placed finish. Rice had previously won the BBC One singing competition All Together Now, and appeared in the 11th series of The X Factor in 2014.\n\nFollowing Eurovision, Rice released the single Somebody, which failed to chart, and performed in small venues across the UK. In the build-up to last year's aborted show, he appeared on a number of local radio stations to comment on James Newman's UK entry.\n\n2021: James Newman, 'Embers'\n\nNewman was due to represent the UK at the 2020 contest, but after that was nixed by the pandemic, he was instead chosen as our sacrificial lamb for Eurovision 2021. Sadly, a global pandemic didn't ameliorate Britain's chances and Newman's bland entry, Embers, joined a select club and scored \"nul points\".\n\nThe 37-year-old Londoner doesn't lack musical talent - he won a Brit award in 2014 for co-writing Rudimental's hit Waiting All Night - but his career hasn't exactly caught fire since Eurovision: to date, he has released no new music.\n\n2022: Sam Ryder, 'SPACE MAN'\n\nRecognition at last! British glitter lovers could finally hold their heads high again as the genial 33-year-old romped home to second place behind that year's predictable (and deserved) winners Ukraine.\n\nCatchy and heartfelt, with an Elton John-esque belter of a chorus, his ballad was undeniably the best song we've submitted for some time. (In fact, the last time we placed so highly was in 1998 with Imanni's Where Are You.)\n\nBut what sealed the deal for Ryder was his Tigerish bounce and unmistakable joy at the whole shebang. An inspiration.\n\n2023: Mae Muller, 'I Wrote A Song'\n\n... And what a bruising experience that proved. Muller's entry was a decent hit of affirmative revenge pop, sending up a needy ex-boyfriend in fine style - a nice representation of her appeal to the Gen Z, TikTok crowd.\n\nAlas, the UK's flame-out into second-last place all-but-killed her singing career. Muller released a follow-up album, but it was a damb squib and in January this year she dropped her label and announced her intention to work as a solo artist. So far, the 26-year-old singer has released no new music, though her social media has been teasing its appearance.\n\nBut if that comes to naught, she can always fall back on her acting: she appeared in street gang drama Gassed Up in February.", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tristram_fane_saunders@telegraph.co.uk", "name": "Tristram Fane Saunders", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prima_Donna_(British_band)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Prima Donna (British band)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patricia_Bredin", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Patricia Bredin"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Are_You_Sure?_(The_Allisons_song)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Are You Sure? "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Hollywood, Los Angeles"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clodagh_Rodgers", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Clodagh Rodgers"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crackerjack!_(TV_programme)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Crackerjack! (TV programme)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Fitzgerald_(singer)", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Scott Fitzgerald (singer)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Lace", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Black Lace"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rikki_(British_singer)", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Rikki (British singer)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jemini", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jemini"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandie_Shaw", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Sandie Shaw"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samantha_Womack", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Samantha Womack"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheryl_Baker", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Cheryl Baker"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grease_(musical)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Grease (musical)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Monro", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Matt Monro"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joanna_Lumley", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Joanna Lumley"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Shadows", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "The Shadows"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pantomime", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Pantomime"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Radio_2", "type": as song contest turns to 'X Factor' style semi-finals to entice Gen Z audience", "body": "Eurovision fans have blasted this year's song contest for being too 'provocative' and 'raunchy', claiming that the prestigious show is now pandering to Gen Z audiences with flashy 'X Factor' style semi-finals.\n\nFans of the competition, which will be hosted in Malmo, Sweden this year, have been critical of acts including Slovenia's scantily clad Raiven and Olly Alexander for outfits and dance routines that aren't 'family friendly'.\n\nOlly is representing the United Kingdom with his catchy tune Dizzy, and performed the song with plenty of raunchy dance moves.\n\nIreland's entry Bambie Thug, 31, a non-binary artist from County Cork has also been criticised for their performance which sees them joined on stage by a male dancer wearing demonic makeup and fake teeth.\n\nSome Eurovision fans tuning into the semi-finals have been left aghast by the adult content on display in the build up to the event and criticised organisers and performers for not reading the room.\n\nDuring the performance, Olly Alexander sensually runs his hands over the dancer's shirtless bodies before they thrust to the beat of the song together\n\nSlovenia's Raiven, who performs her track Veronika in an almost see through gown was also criticised online for her choice of attire\n\nIreland's entry Bambie Thug, 31, a non-binary artist from County Cork\n\nEnraged fans have claimed the singer's ritual is openly satanic\n\nOne said: 'In recent years, Eurovision has turned into a farce. Groups with provocative styles and appalling content aren't even trying to contribute to music; they're just shocking for the sake of shock.\n\n'This isn't talent, it's absurdity, which repels.'\n\nAnother complained: 'Olly Alexander's performance was much too raunchy. It needs to be toned down a lot.'\n\nThe routine, which is guaranteed to be in Saturday's final, sees the singer don a distressed vest and red trousers and a colour-coordinated jock strap over the top.\n\nDuring the performance, Olly sensually runs his hands over the dancer's shirtless bodies before they thrust to the beat of the song together.\n\nThings began to go pear-shaped during a performance this week when his microphone pack slipped from his trousers forcing him to continue the song while attempting to grab the pack which dangled underneath, no doubt contributing to the 'shaky' vocals some fans complained about.\n\nNoting the uncomfortable performance, one fan mused: 'It seems like some Eurovision fans are worried about Olly Alexander's vocals after his live performance of the UK entry.\n\n'The addition of shirtless dancers and raunchy moves may have distracted from his singing abilities. Hopefully he can work on improving his vocals before the competition.'\n\nEurovision fans have blasted the 2024 competition for being a 'provocative' and 'raunchy' x Factor rip off\n\nSlovenia's Raiven, who performs her track Veronika in an almost see through gown was also criticised online for her choice of attire.\n\nOne distressed fan said: 'Slovenia needs to really up their costume. Raiven please get better clothes.\n\n'Dress up for a family friendly show. Eurovision management do your job. Participants need to dress appropriately.'\n\nOther fans have accused the competition of overtly mimicking the X Factor in its presentation of acts, and suggested it is a bid to keep hold of the Gen Z crowd.\n\nThe competition has already been mired in controversy this year due to the inclusion of Israel, with some pro-Palestinians adamant they should not be invited due to their ongoing actions in the Gaza strip.\n\nEurovision organisers rebuked one of the Eurovision 2024 opening acts for wearing a keffiyeh during the first semi-final last night.\n\nSwedish singer Eric Saade, who was one of three former contestants opening the contest in Malmo, tied the scarf - which has become a symbol of support for Palestine amid the conflict in the Middle East - around his wrist.\n\nSaade, who is of Palestinian origin, came third for Sweden at the 56th Eurovision Song Contest in 2011 and has repeatedly expressed his opposition to Israel's involvement this time around.\n\nA spokesperson for the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises the event, said: 'The Eurovision Song Contest is a live TV show.\n\n'All performers are made aware of the rules of the Contest, and we regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.'\n\nSwedish singer Eric Saade has been rebuked by Eurovision organisers for wearing a keffiyeh while opening the first semi-final\n\nThe scarf which was tied round his wrist has become a symbol of support for Palestine amid the conflict in the Middle East\n\nSaade was joined by Eleni Foureira (left) and Chanel (centre) to open the event in Malmo, Sweden\n\nSaade was joined by fellow song contest alums Eleni Foureira, who came second in 2018 for Cyprus, and Chanel, who finished third for Spain in 2022, when he appeared with the keffiyeh wrapped around his wrist in clear view.\n\nIt is not the only difficulty the event has faced regarding the conflict in Gaza since opting to include Israel in the competition as usual.\n\nBritish representative Olly Alexander was one of nine entrants to sign a statement in March which read: 'In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent.\n\n'It it important to us to stand in solidarity with the oppressed and communicate our heartfelt wish for peace, an immediate lasting ceasefire, and the safe return of all hostages. We stand united against all forms of hate, including antisemitism and islamophobia.\n\n'We firmly believe in the unifying power of music, enabling people to transcend differences and foster meaningful conversations and connections.\n\n'We feel it is our duty to create and uphold this space, with a strong hope that it will inspire greater compassion and empathy.'\n\nThe Years & Years star had been under scrutiny as a group of 450 queer artists, individuals and organisations signed an open letter asking the singer to withdraw from the contest over Israel's war with Gaza.\n\n(L-R) Foureira, Chanel and Saade - without the keffiyeh - during a rehearsal of the semi-final\n\nBritish representative Olly Alexander (pictured) was one of nine entrants to sign a statement in March which read: 'In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent'\n\nHe also performed in Tuesday's semi-final, despite automatically qualifying for Saturday's showpiece\n\nIn an individual statement he wrote: 'I wholeheartedly support action being taken to demand an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza, the return of all hostages and the safety and security of all civilians in Palestine and Israel.\n\n'I know some people will choose to boycott this year's Eurovision and I understand and respect their decision.\n\n'As a participant I've taken a lot of time to deliberate over what to do and the options available to me. It is my current belief that removing myself from the contest wouldn't bring us any closer to our shared goal.'\n\n'I hope and pray that our calls are answered and there is an end to the atrocities we are seeing taking place in Gaza.\n\n'I'd like to thank the many signatories of this letter whose work I deeply admire and respect and hope that we can continue to work together in creating a better {"uri": "8117255125", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:21:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:21:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:20:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://theweek.com/culture-life/music/eurovision-2024-how-is-politics-playing-out-in-sweden", "title": "Eurovision 2024: how is politics playing out in Sweden?", "body": "One of the biggest fallacies about major cultural and sporting events is that they cannot nor should not be political.\n\nThe European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises the Eurovision Song Contest, has repeatedly insisted that the competition is purely a cultural event and has no place for politics. Its rules state that political statements or even slogans are not allowed.\n\nBut the event \"has always been politically charged\", said Bloomberg, \"and this year perhaps more so than ever\".\n\nAhead of Saturday's Eurovision grand finale, 100,000 visitors are expected to descend on Malmo in Sweden. The host city has a sizeable Muslim minority and many of those heading there will be taking part in protests against Israel's war in Gaza. Organisers say the demonstrations are intended to be peaceful.\n\nMeanwhile, the song contest itself has for months been \"on the defensive about Israel's participation\", said Bloomberg.\n\nJanne Heltberg, a Norwegian actor and one of the initiators of EurovisiOFF, a campaign calling for a Eurovision boycott, has argued that just as Russia was swiftly banned after its 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Israel should now be disqualified.\n\nThis \"almost happened\" earlier this year, said DW, \"but not as a direct reaction to the boycott calls\". According to the EBU, the original title of the Israeli entry, \"October Rain\", by 20-year-old Eden Golan was too reminiscent of the 7 October Hamas attacks that killed 1,200 people and saw hundreds more taken hostage.\n\nDespite calls to exclude Israel from the competition, in the end the title was changed, and Golan was allowed to participate.\n\nWhile a majority of people asked by YouGov said Israel should not be allowed to compete, \"the reasons why are often geographical rather than political\", said the polling firm. Those who actually intend to watch Eurovision were slightly more likely to say that Israel should be allowed in than not.\n\nFar from its stated reputation as a strictly \"non-political event\", wrote Jacqui Housden on the i news site, over the past 50 years Eurovision's stage has been a \"hotbed of controversies and political statements, from calls to recognise genocide, to hidden messages on referendums and more obvious messages about the Russian leader\".\n\nIn just the last 20 years, Georgia was excluded in 2009 following Russia's invasion for the song \"We Don't Wanna Put In\". Belarus was kicked out in 2021 after the contested re-election of authoritarian president Alexander Lukashenko, which precipitated a national crackdown on political opposition, while Russia was excluded in 2022 following its invasion of Ukraine, which went on to win the competition by a landslide.\n\nIsrael has been participating in Eurovision for over half a century, \"so it's not the first time the Middle East conflict has come into the spotlight at the event\", said DW.\n\nIn 1973, Israeli singer Ilanit performed amid tight security. In the wake of the 1972 Munich Olympics massacre of 11 Israeli athletes by Palestinian terrorists, the singer was forced to wear a protective vest, audience members were not allowed to stand and photographers had to take pictures of the ceiling \"to prove that their cameras were not camouflaged firearms\".\n\nFast forward to the present day and \"several prominent, artist-led campaigns argue that recent decisions to exclude Russia and Belarus set a precedent, and that Israel should be banned for human-rights violations\", said The New York Times.\n\n\"Eurovision officials reject those comparisons,\" said the paper, \"but when Golan performs in Malmo, it seems certain that many voters will be thinking about more than just her singing.\"\n\nThere has certainly been \"intense debate in the run-up to the competition about the dividing lines between music, art and politics\", said Politico. But at least when it comes to the event itself host country Sweden is the \"archetypal safe pair of hands for Eurovision\".", "source": {"uri": "theweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Week"}, "authors": [{"uri": "week_uk@theweek.com", "name": "Week Uk", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Eurovision Song Contest"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Israel"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"uri": "8115478010", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "11:46:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T11:46:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T11:46:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.thedrum.com/opinion/2024/05/07/artists-face-the-semis-let-s-gauge-which-sponsors-will-wow-eurovision-fans", "title": "As artists face the semis, let's gauge which sponsors will wow Eurovision fans", "body": "This time last year, all eyes were on Liverpool as the city proudly put on the 67th annual Eurovision Song Contest. Hosting the show for a record-setting ninth time, the UK quite rightly had a pep in its own step, having beaten a bad run to finish second the previous year.\n\nFor once, even among the media elite here in London, Eurovision felt like a positive force and something everyone could get behind. Indeed they did - having attended close to a dozen contests in person I've never seen a whole city embrace its responsibility so fully. There was branding everywhere, countless side events and an enormous public Eurovision Village that was packed every day.\n\nWhen I first became The Drum's Semi-Official Eurovision Correspondent a decade ago, it was purely so I could write passive-aggressive articles on how ridiculous it was that the marketing community was ignoring a cultural and entertainment moment bigger than both Beyonce and the Super Bowl largely because it wasn't 'cool.'\n\nFast forward to 2023, and things felt entirely different - Diageo, Google, Booking, TikTok and others all proudly had their names on their contest and their presence felt in the Eurovision village itself. Mondelez International, who, with a bit of arm twisting from my good self, had first dipped its toes in the Eurovision water back in 2016, had the contest's logo emblazoned on special bars of Cadbury Dairy Milk and Philadelphia in stores.\n\nSo what do we know about this year's contest, set to take place on Saturday, May 11, with semi-final shows on Tuesday and Thursday that week?\n\nFrom a UK perspective, the BBC is still backing it big, with the semis airing on BBC One again for the second time ever and surrounding it with a range of TV and radio programming. In much of Europe, most notably Iceland where it attracts a high 90% audience share, Eurovision remains the biggest night of TV of the year.\n\nThe contest will be hosted in Malmo, Sweden, this year, after Loreen's triumphant return with the song 'Tatoo' last year. Almost too conveniently for some, this brings the contest back to Scandinavian soil exactly 50 years after ABBA triumphed with the song 'Waterloo'. While it has denied any participation of the band, you can expect at least to see the considerable tribute paid on stage and, who knows, perhaps their ABBAtars appearing on screen, if nothing else.\n\nEurovision makes a strong point of saying it is non-political and banning any songs with overtly political meaning, but the contest itself emerged directly as a way of getting European nations to better work together in the aftermath of the Second World War.\n\nIn the past, it's been the trigger for a coup in Portugal, upset many a right-wing politician with its LGBTQ+ inclusion, and, of course, in recent years, seen Ukraine triumph while Russia was banned. You'll find far better accounts of the politics involved elsewhere, but whether the organizers admit it or not, the inclusion of Israel in the contest this year casts a very heavy political shadow over proceedings.\n\nIt seems uniquely detrimental for all involved, including the singer selected to represent Israel this year, that the participation is going ahead. There have been calls for artists and broadcasters to boycott, and despite exceptionally high security, it is highly likely to attract protests in many forms. In some corners of the fan community, it is being seen as an irreparable act of vandalism against the contest's reputation and newly permanent 'United By Music' slogan.\n\nI'm sure most advertisers weren't imagining that as a consideration when they negotiated or extended their partnerships last year, and for the most part, I imagine the casual viewer will enjoy the show very much as normal - and indeed as a reminder that casual audience was 162 million across all live shows in 2023, substantially more than the Super Bowl.\n\nMany of the same advertisers are back this year - headline sponsors Morocanoil, entertainment partners TikTok, and Diageo's Bailey's brand chief among them. While Mondelez and Booking haven't returned, the latter's travel sector is still well represented, with EasyJet and Royal Caribbean stepping in as official airline and cruise companies. Southern European real estate agents/property search company Idealista also returned as a sponsor for the third year.\n\nAlthough true fans understand Eurovision to be a six-month-long season starting with the earliest announcements and song selections at the end of the previous year, for most people, it's just one or two nights of good TV. That's always been one of the challenges of sponsoring the event, and why we'll also have to wait right until the last minute to see how brands are truly bringing their sponsorship to life this year. Stay tuned for what I discover online and on the ground in Sweden.", "source": {"uri": "thedrum.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Drum"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The war started on October 7 when Hamas militant group invaded Israel which resulted in the death of 1,200 people.\n\nWriting on Facebook, a Dreadnough pub co-owner said: \"A number of folk have contacted me and patiently explained why we shouldn't be broadcasting Eurovision this year. I get it.\n\n\"We show Eurovision every year because it's unifying, joyful and daft. It's not going to have that vibe this year, so we'll find something else to do instead.\"\n\nThey added: \"Here's hoping we'll be able to enjoy it, collectively, next year.\"\n\nSeveral regulars to the Leith pub commended the decision with one writing 'that's why you are the respected and loved bar that you are' with another adding 'I think this is the right call. I hope other places follow suit.'\n\nOne said they were boycotting the competition this year despite being a 'massive fan' adding 'human rights violations and war crimes can't be disguised with glitter and a song.\" Another added: \"You have the courage of your convictions in spite of the commercial pressure this can bring, that's why I love the Dreadnought Leith.\"\n\nIn the lead up to Eurovision 2024 people across Europe have protested the event calling for Israel to be withdrawn from the competition - with critics citing that the competition previously banned Russia in 2022 following its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nEarlier in the year, campaign group Palestine Solidarity UK launched a petition urging Olly Alexander, the UK's Eurovision contestant, to boycott the competition final that takes place in Malm\u00f6, Sweden on May 11.\n\nThe group, who say the petition has amassed more than 11,000 signatures wrote on social media: \"Palestinians have called for a boycott of this year's Eurovision Song Contest because of the refusal of its organisers to expel genocidal and apartheid Israel from the competition. {"uri": "8116493154", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "01:49:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T01:49:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:49:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/eurovision-2024-first-semifinal-results-ireland-luxembourg-1235676899/", "title": "Luxembourg, Ireland & 8 More Countries Advance to Eurovision 2024 Grand Final", "body": "Alyona Alyona & Jerry Heil Want People 'To Feel Empathy for Ukraine' With Their Eurovision 2024 Song\n\nThe first of three live broadcasts of the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest yielded the initial results of the competition, with 10 countries out of 15 moving forward into the grand final on Saturday (May 11) and five countries going home.\n\nMost notable among the 10 winning countries are Luxembourg, which returned to the pan-European competition this year after a 31-year absence, and Ireland, which holds the record for the most wins with Sweden at seven each.\n\nHowever, Ireland has failed to qualify for the grand final 11 times since the semifinals were introduced in 2005. Bambie Thug breaks that spell with \"Doomsday Blue,\" a self-described \"electro-metal breakdown.\" Thug (real name: Bambie Ray Robinson) is the first nonbinary artist to represent Ireland in Eurovision and will be the first Irish contestant in the competition since Ryan O'Shaugnessy placed 16th with \"Together\" in 2018.\n\nThug's entry is expected to place high in the grand final rankings. If they end up in the top five, it will be Ireland's biggest Eurovision success since Marc Roberts' \"Mysterious Ways,\" which finished second to Katrina & the Waves winning U.K. entry \"Love Shine a Light\" in 1997.\n\nTalia, an Israeli-born singer living in Luxembourg, will be the first person from that small European country -- the only grand duchy (a country ruled by a monarch with the title of grand duke or duchess) remaining in the world -- to sing in Eurovision since Modern Times placed 20th with \"Donne-Moi Une Chance\" in 1993.\n\nThe other eight countries that qualified for the grand final are Croatia, Cyprus, Finland, Lithuania, Portugal, Serbia, Slovenia and Ukraine. The five countries relegated out, by public vote during the live broadcast, are Australia, Azerbaijan, Iceland, Moldova and Poland.\n\nThe oddsmakers have Croatia heavily tipped to win; it would be that nation's first victory in 30 attempts, although Riva, a band from Croatia, triumphed in 1990 when their country was still part of Yugoslavia.\n\nA second semifinal will be broadcast live on Thursday (May 9). There will be 16 countries fighting for a spot in the grand final top 10 that night: Albania, Armenia, Austria, Belgium, Czechia, Denmark, Estonia, Georgia, Greece, Israel, Latvia, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, San Marino and Switzerland.\n\nPre-qualified, and thus able to skip the semifinals, are the host country (Sweden) and the \"Big Five\" (France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom), so-named because they contribute the largest amounts to the production budget.\n\nSemifinal No 2 of the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest will be live on Peacock in the U.S. on Thursday starting at 3 p.m. ET/noon PT. Groups with provactive styles and appalling content aren't even trying to contribute to music; they're just shocking for the sake of shock.\n\n'This isn't talent, it's absurdity, which repels.'\n\nAnother complained: 'Olly Alexander's performance was much too raunchy. It needs to be toned down a lot.'\n\nThe routine, which is guaranteed to be in Saturday's final, sees the singer don a distressed vest and red trousers and a colour-coordinated jock strap over the top.\n\nDuring the performance, Olly sensually runs his hands over the dancer's shirtless bodies before they thrust to the beat of the song together.\n\nThings began to go pear-shaped during a performance this week when his microphone pack slipped from his trousers forcing him to conntinue the song while attempting to grab the pack which dangled underneath, no doubt contributing to the 'shaky' vocals some fans complained about.\n\nNoting the uncomfortable of the performance, one fan mused: 'It seems like some Eurovision fans are worried about Olly Alexander's vocals after his live performance of the UK entry.\n\n'The addition of shirtless dancers and raunchy moves may have distracted from his singing abilities. Hopefully he can work on improving his vocals before the competition.'\n\nEurovision fans have blasted the 2024 competition for being a 'provocative' and 'raunchy' x Factor rip off\n\nSlovenia's Raiven, who performs her track Veronika in an almost see through gown was also criticised online for her choice of attire.\n\nOne distressed fan said: 'Slovenia needs to really up their costume. Raiven please get better clothes.\n\n'Dress up for a family friendly show. Eurovision management do your job. Participants need to dress appropriately.'\n\nOther fans have accused the competition of overtly mimicking the X Factor in its presentation of acts, and suggested it is a bid to keep hold of the Gen Z crowd.\n\nThe competition has already been mired in controversy this year due to the inclusion of Israel, with some pro-Palestinians adamant they should not be invited due to their ongoing actions in the Gaza strip.\n\nEurovision organisers rebuked one of the Eurovision 2024 opening acts for wearing a keffiyeh during the first semi-final last night.\n\nSwedish singer Eric Saade, who was one of three former contestants opening the contest in Malmo, tied the scarf - which has become a symbol of support for Palestine amid the conflict in the Middle East - around his wrist.\n\nSaade, who is of Palestinian origin, came third for Sweden at the 56th Eurovision Song Contest in 2011 and has repeatedly expressed his opposition to Israel's involvement this time around.\n\nA spokesperson for the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which organises the event, said: 'The Eurovision Song Contest is a live TV show.\n\n'All performers are made aware of the rules of the Contest, and we regret that Eric Saade chose to compromise the non-political nature of the event.'\n\nSwedish singer Eric Saade has been rebuked by Eurovision organisers for wearing a keffiyeh while opening the first semi-final\n\nThe scarf which was tied round his wrist has become a symbol of support for Palestine amid the conflict in the Middle East\n\nSaade was joined by Eleni Foureira (left) and Chanel (centre) to open the event in Malmo, Sweden\n\nSaade was joined by fellow song contest alums Eleni Foureira, who came second in 2018 for Cyprus, and Chanel, who finished third for Spain in 2022, when he appeared with the keffiyeh wrapped around his wrist in clear view.\n\nIt is not the only difficulty the event has faced regarding the conflict in Gaza since opting to include Israel in the competition as usual.\n\nBritish representative Olly Alexander was one of nine entrants to sign a statement in March which read: 'In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent.\n\n'It it important to us to stand in solidarity with the oppressed and communicate our heartfelt wish for peace, an immediate lasting ceasefire, and the safe return of all hostages. We stand united against all forms of hate, including antisemitism and islamophobia.\n\n'We firmly believe in the unifying power of music, enabling people to transcend differences and foster meaningful conversations and connections.\n\n'We feel it is our duty to create and uphold this space, with a strong hope that it will inspire greater compassion and empathy.'\n\nThe Years & Years star had been under scrutiny as a group of 450 queer artists, individuals and organisations signed an open letter asking the singer to withdraw from the contest over Israel's war with Gaza.\n\n(L-R) Foureira, Chanel and Saade - without the keffiyeh - during a rehearsal of the semi-final\n\nBritish representative Olly Alexander (pictured) was one of nine entrants to sign a statement in March which read: 'In light of the current situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and particularly in Gaza, and in Israel, we do not feel comfortable being silent'\n\nHe also performed in Tuesday's semi-final, despite automatically qualifying for Saturday's showpiece\n\nIn an individual statement he wrote: 'I wholeheartedly support action being taken to demand an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza, the return of all hostages and the safety and security of all civilians in Palestine and Israel.\n\n'I know some people will choose to boycott this year's Eurovision and I understand and respect their decision.\n\n'As a participant I've taken a lot of time to deliberate over what to do and the options available to me. It is my current belief that removing myself from the contest wouldn't bring us any closer to our shared goal.'\n\n'I hope and pray that our calls are answered and there is an end to the atrocities we are seeing taking place in Gaza.\n\n'I'd like to thank the many signatories of this letter whose work I deeply admire and respect and hope that we can continue to work together in creating a better The Rio Cinema will have its doors closed in Dalston, as will The Royal Vauxhall Tavern (RVT) in South West London.\n\nThe independent cinema isn't showing the contest as Israel remains in the competition, a demonstration of solidarity with the victims of the Gaza genocide. in January, charity Oxfam reported that Israel kills around 250 Palestinians every day, a daily death rate higher than any other 21st-century conflict, according to the charity.\n\nWith an average age of 18, around 13,000 children have died at the hands of Israel since October 7 last year, reported Reuters in March. As a result, The Rio Cinema in Dalston shared a statement on its position on the conflict.\n\nREAD MORE: Joanna Lumley chosen to announce UK's Eurovision points\n\nThe statement reads: \"Following discussion with the organisers of Eurovision Party London, we have collectively decided not to screen the Grand Final of the Eurovision Song Contest. We firmly believe that the Eurovision Song Contest has the power to bring people together across the world when its core values of inclusivity, equality and universality are upheld.\n\n\"We will continue to organise fundraising events for the charities we support, including Doctors Without Borders and Medical Aid for Palestine.\"\n\nThe RVT will also have its doors closed this weekend, although it hasn't specified why. A tweet read: \"Royal Vauxhall Tavern will not be open for any event on Saturday night 11th May 2024.\" This follows backlash on social media for a Eurovision event it had planned.\n\nThe RVT was contacted for comment.\n\nDo you know any other venues cancelling Eurovision events?
